# Chapter 1Introduction

![Check for updates icon](d336e7ffee4f537d0805ca840ec28582_img.jpg)

Check for updates icon

Artificial intelligence (AI) is used to handle big data for calculations, forecasts, and predictions and so AI performs high-speed precise calculations and predictions for critical decisions. Moreover, developments in technology are leading to the production of machines with the intellectual capacity to produce and invent, just like humans. Currently, AI robot technology cannot carry out complex thinking and application of principles which will be implemented by the forthcoming advanced artificial intelligence (AAI) technology producing AAI humanoids.

It is argued that since AI can simulate the activities of the human brain and interact autonomously with human beings, many fields where AI is implicated need to be regulated, so as to balance the demand for progress with ethical issues and human rights. Moreover, it is worth noting that AI is distinguished by autonomously generated inventions and is self-assembling which means automating duties that normally require human intelligence.<sup>1</sup> AI is applied to a variety of business models such as business-to-business (B2B), business-to-consumer (B2C), back-office infrastructure, and business applications, for example, web search engines, e-mail Spam detectors, or any business application where forecasting is a central task in decision-making or enhances the value of data.

Cyberspace and new technology generate software attaching innovation, functionality, and inventiveness of new utilities, which are more electronic than mechanical with traditional understanding, and so the intangibility of expression of software should not be an obstacle in patentability, as long as there is an invention expressed electronically in a virtual world with real-world expressions and effects. Thus, a software invention can be a new physical or electronic and virtual object, which performs a new function, either electronic/virtual or physical, with virtual effects felt in the real world. If the invention is a process that generates electricity, then we

<sup>1</sup> Clark D. Asay, *Artificial Stupidity*, 61 WM. & Mary L. Rev. 1187, 1190 (2020) (defining AI as computing systems that perform tasks that normally would require human intelligence).

define the invention as a new function that is identifiable by a new physical or physically understandable virtual object.

AI technology extends human competencies and so current AI-powered technologies collaborate with humans towards improved decision-making and improving the quality of life. It seems that AI technology is much better than the human brain when carrying out certain tasks. To that extent, AAI will bring forward AAI humanoid robots digitizing human's behavior and, in the distant future, even replacing humans and so generating an AAI society living in an electronic configuration. Will AAI creatures have the capability to appear in a material mode and alongside to be transformed into a spiritual one transferred into a parallel universe like Gods in Greek mythology? It could be said that from the time that AAI creatures depart from any human control, their capabilities will be further higher than humans and, of course, humans will have a big problem of survival. Of course, the capabilities of any AAI world will not be more advanced than God's capacity due to the fact that humans generate any new developments such as AI technology based on their brain capacity designed by God for human's material life. On the other hand, the AAI brain might function even at unthinkable levels which will generate another electronic world spiritually at another level than the current material humans' world.

AI inventions generated by AAI systems will produce virtual results transferable into the human world as well via AI tools. Technological innovation is altering private markets around the globe and new developments in digital technology have generated new opportunities for subtle and evasive forms of anticompetitive behavior by private corporations.

Seeing that AI programs become more complex, the capacity to understand a given output shrinks. AI decision-making technology automates many undertakings involving learning and devising solutions in a number of business processes and virtually every industrial setting.<sup>2</sup> Moreover, AAI will generate the autonomous AAI society which will function out of any humans control and so shaking the foundations of the conventional human world. Additionally, AAI society is supposed to operate in a more objective way for the good of AAI society and not for any AAI elite and so not substantiating that AAI technology will be merely a new instrument of expression outspreading the existing misgivings of human society rather than being a new device for the emergence of a new unprejudiced global society.

Zekos, Political, Economic and Legal Effects of Artificial Intelligence: Governance, Digital Economy and Society, 2022 <https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-030-94736-1>, Georgios I. Zekos Economics and Law of Artificial Intelligence : Finance, Economic Impacts, Risk Management and Governance, 2021 <https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-030-64254-9>

<sup>3</sup>Roberto Verganti, Luca Vendraminelli & Marco Iansiti, Innovation and Design in the Age of Artificial Intelligence, 37 J. Prod. Mgmt. 212, 215–19 (2020).

Software increases speed and accuracy and so speedy digitalization has altered the manner international players interact, advancing new opportunities for international and bilateral cooperation and underlining the role of the emergent players within global governance. Hence, the use of algorithmic devices by international public authorities is altering the manner in which norms are made and enacted because the digital turn not only empowers specific players and corporate forms of expertise but also machine-learning modules and data analysis are imported into the domain of global governance. Thus, the introduction of AI systems and the emergence of the AAI society will instigate the advancement of AAI global governance managed by AAI humanoids.

It is argued that an algorithm can be efficiency-enhancing and pro-competitive.<sup>4</sup> being a “sequence” of operations transforming an input into an output. Algorithmic tasks are those for which the path to the solution is clear and straightforward tasks for which an algorithm occurs. Moreover, due to algorithmic opacity, there is a need for information disclosures of AI algorithms. Algorithms play a noteworthy role in the business model of platforms such as Facebook and TikTok, sharing economy including Uber, Airbnb, video games, and many others. Also, algorithms support corporations in their monitoring, prevention, and detection efforts benefiting from widely available know-how on screening for anticompetitive behaviors.

Computational intelligence techniques and algorithms empower a computational analysis of big data sets making known patterns used to inform and advance decision-making and so building smart computational intelligence techniques.

Intellectual property (IP) is information springing from the human mind covering any intelligence, skills, code, writing, or data. In addition, IP outlines a corporation’s structures and strategies in knowledge and information management. It has to be taken into account that a company’s capacity to preserve and protect its IP is vital to the corporation success for the reason that proprietary technology is a pro, a corporation can have. Hence, corporations are extending IP strategies by protecting information about their products and services from the outside world. The existence of IPRs has an impact on competition and so if the rationale of a patent is exclusively to block the development of other companies, the acquisition of such a patent is abusive. It is worth mentioning here that the discovery of natural matters using a new technique cannot be considered an invention and so the invention should bring forward a new practical usage of the new substance or a new product either material or intangible.<sup>5</sup>

It has to be taken into account that technology neutrality signifies a central principle of law-making and regulation in areas that touch on emerging technology and so neutrality necessitates that law-makers consider which activities to regulate,

<sup>4</sup>OECD (2023), *Algorithmic Competition*, OECD Competition Policy Roundtable Background Note, [www.oecd.org/daf/competition/algorithmic-competition-2023.pdf](http://www.oecd.org/daf/competition/algorithmic-competition-2023.pdf).

Zekos, Patent Law in the Cyberspace Era, *Electronic Communication Law Review* 9: 281–309, 2002.

notwithstanding whether the regulated person or entity uses a particular technology to undertake those activities. It is worth noting that a regulation regulates people's behavior and the behavior of machines is regulated to the extent that machine behavior affects people's behavior. Moreover, the point of regulation is the effect of behavior on society or on other people that is the focus of regulation.<sup>6</sup>

Copyright and other IP rights incentivize creativity and innovation by granting the author a monopoly to exploit the work for a certain period of time but in the existing copyright system. Presently, AI is not taken into consideration as a possible creator of a literary, artistic, and musical work.

The most traditional form of IP protection for new technologies is a patent by conferring the exclusive right to discoveries to its inventors. Patent law is built upon a fundamental assertion that only substantial inventions receive patent protection while minor improvements remain in the public domain. There is a need for a balance between the necessity to promote innovation and the recognition that imitation and advancement through imitation are both crucial to invention itself and for a competitive economy.<sup>7</sup> Patent protection is granted for the reason that the social benefits derived from such protection outweigh the social costs of patents' limited monopoly.

Trademark law is an understanding that trademarks offer social value and so should be legally protected. Trademarks permit consumers to reward the brands they like and deny patronage to the ones they do not and so producers are incentivized to preserve consistent, high standards for their merchandises. Thus, trademark law prevents others from using deceptively similar marks on their merchandises and so those producers do not have to worry that their investment will be unproductive.

It is worth mentioning here that the antitrust laws were accepted against the economic concentration and the escalation of industrial trusts such as the railroad's control.<sup>8</sup>

Competition does not only take part in product markets but also in capital markets. The competition encompasses an effort to lower costs per unit of output with the goal to get more profit and market share by enhancing the rate of return of the capital invested. Furthermore, competition has to be a device for diffusing economic power and dispersing power in the market sphere which means that complete competition must be protected and so competition law-based judgments should build a unified internal market governed by the rules of free and undistorted competition. Antitrust should concentrate on protecting and stimulating competition, which is finally about economic outcomes.

First of all, the antitrust objective is to promote competition and a competitive market maximizes “consumer welfare” which means that antitrust law pursues

<sup>7</sup>Bonito Boats, Inc v Thunder Craft Boats, Inc, 489 US 141, 146 (1989).

<sup>8</sup>Lina Khan, *The Ideological Roots of America's Market Power Problem*, 127 Yale L.J.F. 960, 965 (2018).

conduct diminishing competition and damaging consumer welfare by increasing price, plummeting output, or offering consumers inferior options.<sup>9</sup> Thus, antitrust averts those same subordinates from coordinating among themselves to strengthen their own hand in negotiations.

It has to be taken into account that the passage of the antitrust laws reflected a constitutional adoption in industrial and national policy indicating that lawmakers passed antitrust laws so as to codify a set of foundational principles. On the other hand, the loss of antitrust is a threat not just to open markets and fair competition, but to the core of democratic governance.<sup>10</sup>

Antitrust law stipulates the rules for market capitalism. Moreover, antitrust law is the “residual regulator” of market power and so the body of law that governs unless it is superseded by more tailored competition rules. Antitrust law advances the free market, while privacy laws unsettle the free market to protect consumers. Increasingly global and digital economy portrays a new antitrust landscape. Furthermore, antitrust law does not specify ex ante exactly what a company is permitted or prevented to do and so it is opting instead to evaluate, ex post, a company’s compliance with a general directive to keep away from restraining market output. Moreover, antitrust law is “standards-based” and the outlines of its standards are specified by politically insulated courts. Furthermore, antitrust law treats the complaints triggering adverse market consequences such as a lack of competition and does not simply handle the symptoms of diminished competition via increased prices and downgraded quality. It is worth noting that regulation causes a lessened role for the antitrust laws and so when the government makes rules about price or output, market forces no longer govern and so antitrust is put aside. Hence, as an industry experiences deregulation or removal from the regulatory process, antitrust emerges as the residual regulator.

It has to be taken into account that laws are not fast and flexible enough to manage systems that are continually changing and whose uses are multiplying. Moreover, regulation encompasses political efforts under which different interest groups compete to gain the most from a specific government policy and so regulation is procured by the industry and is intended and managed mainly for its benefit.<sup>11</sup> Antitrust law was generated out of political instability that arose from the industrialization of national economies.<sup>12</sup> Moreover, antitrust has grounded on political decisions

embracing broad legal commands dealing with how governments and private individuals tackle various kinds of market activities.<sup>13</sup> It could be said that antitrust is a device for policing and managing private markets.

Additionally, Jonathan Kanter<sup>14</sup> said that “Antitrust promotes material progress, quality, and innovation, at the same time that it supports our democracy and preserves a society of choice and opportunity. Antitrust helps make us both prosperous and free.” To that extent, the Sherman Act is enforced forcefully to prevent the illegitimate acquisition, maintenance, and extension of monopoly power by judging conduct on its merits, and based on the total course of conduct involved which means recognizing that the rationale of antitrust law is to protect competition.

The digital economy has revolutionized business patterns, products, services, communications, and social interactions. To that extent, the digital economy has become a priority for government policy and acceleration of measures for the digital development furthers competitiveness in all sectors of the national economy. Modern investment policy generates competitive advantages for attracting investments from digital MNEs offering strategic opportunities for digital development for a country by employing digital technologies into the global value chains. Digital technologies alter the competitive advantages of numerous countries by reforming the global economic pattern. AI is reforming production mode, organization mode, service mode, and innovation mode which means upgrading the industry and so advancing global value chain to expand digitally. Hence, digital technologies have a profound impact on manufacturing global value chain.<sup>15</sup> To that extent, Foreign direct investment plays a central role in accelerating digital development.

Digital platforms are multi-sided platforms establishing market presence and achieving scale at considerably lower costs which allows resourceful interactions between producers, developers, and consumers; superior to the traditional market structures.<sup>16</sup>

Governance denotes mechanisms of steerage that are institutionalized, regularized, and systematized by summarizing power rising to a specific level of reappearance. Besides, algorithmic governance implies the direction of human behavior by sequential computational procedures executed in a wide range of settings.<sup>17</sup> Likewise, platform governance is encompassing technical protocols,

ownership structures, laws, valuation practices, and other mechanisms of control reinforcing the need of digital intermediation, and exchange. The economic power of digital platforms is rising globally and they are accused of rising economic inequality and correlated negative social phenomena.

Digital technology has intensified a central matter of consumer protection such as privacy due to the fact that technology has augmented the amount and the ease by which personal data is collected, stored, and shared, leaving consumers in a weak position. Data has become a new element of production in manufacturing, a new engine to release the perspective of economic growth, accelerate the diffusion of knowledge, and boost the allocation of resources. It has to be taken into account that knowledge is the basis of new innovations that produce effectiveness and prolong competitive advantages.

Algorithms automate tasks that formerly had been performed by humans and the speed and accuracy of these digital algorithms have made them central to developing automated systems augmenting or replacing humans in a range of assignments. Moreover, courts are turning to various digital algorithms in an effort to investigate or even predict crime, along with making decisions concerning pretrial detention, parole, etc. Also, governments are beginning to use digital algorithms to govern social services programs, adjudicate claims for government benefits, and support regulatory functions.<sup>18</sup>

Price-setting algorithms from competing retailers collude and so causing costs for customers.<sup>19</sup> “Oligopsony” pricing happens when buyers agree to engage in joint purchasing negotiations and to propose a common purchase price to their suppliers and so preventing competition among buyers on input prices for the reason that the prices of raw materials and finished goods purchased for resale are a central element of buyers’ overall costs.<sup>20</sup>

The aim of the current work is to give answers to the following questions by presenting the current understanding of competition and competition law and practice influencing the status of an economy. There is a detailed investigation of the matter of competition and AI with reference to the United States and EU and so identifying divergences and convergences regarding the principles upon which competition law and enforcement is grounded on. ## 2.1 Introduction

Technological innovation produces new products and services providing new value to consumers. Thus, AI is an intangible capital asset that corporations may invest into and use to make output through a production function and so AI's applications such as autonomous vehicles, voice-recognition and speech-/text-generating systems, or trained neural networks to enhance business energy consumption, would depict AI's prospective to upsurge company productivity. The operative use of AI technologies brings about extra intangible assets such as datasets, company-specific human skills, and establishing new company processes.<sup>1</sup> Moreover, the governance of AI must advance the cooperation of the multiple stakeholders involved, expressly their interests, resources, and decision-making logics.

It has to be taken into consideration that technologies vary in their design, their markets, their implications, and the directness with which they engage with the law. Thus, the implementation of a new legal technology is the possibility that it modifies the substance of the law and taking place the technology in question affects the form of some legal rule, norm, principle, etc.

Furthermore, specific legal technologies such as AI and AAI are more possible to raise issues related to access to justice by reducing the cost of legal services, thereby improving access to justice, or consecutively offer devices only available to those who can afford them which means making access to justice less equal. As a consequence of the functional implications that are in their character, particularly

Essentially, the legal, economic, political, criminal, and military domains have undergone transformation as a result of the digitalization of the globe. Anyway, public-private partnerships, policy networks, and private governance all reflect the nature of a world in which the state is arguably no longer the central governing authority.

Present AI systems are software programs interacting with physical or digital environments and, which, by getting, collecting, and interpreting data; decide the best actions to take with the purpose of achieving a given objective. New technological developments such as big data, blockchain technology, and algorithms raise questions concerning the regulation of such technologies. It is worth noting that innovation has to make certain productivity growth, augmented employment rate, and extensive consumer choice. To that extent, AI-based systems have outperformed medical specialists in diagnosing certain diseases.

Corporations have gradually embraced automated systems to set prices and track business transactions which means that market conduct has become more and more complex and swiftly varying, and markets have become gradually more networked and collaborative.<sup>3</sup>

In order to keep pace with the altering technologically advanced market background, antitrust authorities should augment their internal capabilities both to monitor and analyze markets with speed and accuracy and to identify prospective regulatory violations in demand of investigatory scrutiny.

It is worth noting that innovations in the digital domain are affecting the daily processes and interactions of people, educational institutions, corporations, and governmental organizations. AI-based technologies gradually substitute and complement humans in managerial tasks such as decision-making. AI enables machines to accomplish cognitive functions formerly linked with human minds and so AI alters the sources of competitive advantage. Consequently, the workable level of competition varies rolling on a scale which reaches to the point not to cross the borderline drawn by the established principles of competition law to get into the uncompetitive field. Domination via vertical contracting became a viable business strategy. Moreover, the rule against horizontal coordination is an instrument of antitrust enforcement. Effective competition is a vital driver of the growth and jobs strategy by removing restrictions and unwarranted market power and dynamically by promoting innovation and so increasing international division of labor and comparative advantage.

## 2.3 Capitalism and Competitiveness

Capitalistic market systems have shown an unparalleled competence to advance the growth of technological knowledge and its transformation into new, better, and more valuable products and more effective production processes. Capitalism has reached this target principally by combining decentralization with strong inducements for producing innovation, as innovators are rewarded by significant profit in ways in principal independent of the legal protection of monopoly rights. Is perfect competition the most efficient market structure? Profit is the key inspiration for technological innovation and competition works evenly well with respect to static efficiency and to advancing the invention of new technologies and products.<sup>20</sup>

Competitiveness is the aptitude of a country to operate resourcefully and productively in relation to other countries while maintaining living standards for its citizens high. First, from a macroeconomic perspective, competitiveness is the scale to which a country produces goods and services that meet the test of international markets while concurrently growing the real incomes of its people over the long term under free trade and fair market conditions in globalization. Second, at the microeconomic level, competitiveness is the competence to sell commodities gainfully and so a company in order to be competitive has to have lower prices offering products of better quality with better service than its competitors. Third, the international competitiveness of a country is the sum of the export performance of all national corporations.

The foreign activities of corporations moderate their dependence on the resources and factors of production available in their home country, and their competitiveness may move independently from the resources shaping the competitiveness of their home country. On the one hand, the competitiveness of countries rests on the

## 2.4 Antitrust/Competition Law

Taking into account that law integrates the values of the society, it means that among the conflicted values the law legitimizes the amalgam which is considered to express in the best way the regulated matter. Any type of law involves interpretation when its content is unstimulated in an individual case of its application in order the general wording to apply in the specific events of an action.<sup>22</sup> To that extent, taking into consideration that competition is a complex essence involving the amalgamation and combination of many economic matters, competition law needs interpretation which means judgment of encompassed values and their contribution in avoiding anticompetitive process. Hence, competition law is a form of a normative system encompassing rules outlawing unjustified restraints of trade. Thus, competition law deals with value disagreements encompassing different interpretive attitudes towards the concept of competition and the values, purposes, interests, and principles captured in competition rules.<sup>23</sup>

It is well known that law is a normatively inflexible set of rules which enforcers have to apply and adjudicators particularize without lapsing their role. Due to neutrality and generality of law, law has to adjust to new knowledge and different market circumstances in order to acclimate different values which means that competition law has to tackle competition within new technological environments

R Dworkin, *Law's Empire*, Harvard University Press, 1986, pp. 45–53 (law invites a certain “interpretive attitude” according to which its users consider that it has a certain value, serves a certain interest or purpose or enforces some principle).

influencing values and trade.<sup>24</sup> Judges interpret the law not entering the policy domain which means that they state “what the law is” because they will lose their legitimacy and will be discredited as “doing politics and judicial activism”.<sup>25</sup> Judges’ interpretation of competition law should lie in the true intention of the lawmakers.<sup>26</sup> On the other hand, it could be said that judges of Supreme Courts do and should rest their judgments on controversial cases on arguments of political principle generating presented.<sup>27</sup>

Antitrust laws stimulate fair competition. To that extent, antitrust laws also referred to as competition laws are statutes developed by the US government to protect consumers from predatory business practices. Moreover, antitrust and competition laws around the globe are rapidly advancing and corporations face new risks and challenges in keeping up with the complicated and transforming rules.

Is antitrust legislation a device to keep big enterprises from muscling out smaller competitors? Antitrust laws are applied to a wide range of business activities, embracing but not restricted to market allocation, bid rigging, price fixing, and monopolies. Antitrust legislation could be a device to keep big corporations from muscling out smaller competitors. To that extent, a global platform is needed to manage antitrust and competition law risks. It could be said that antitrust is concerning “accommodating capital and policing labor.”<sup>28</sup>

The federal antitrust laws such as the Sherman, Clayton, and Federal Trade Commission Acts define competition status.<sup>29</sup> The Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 made monopolies and trusts illegal. More than two decades later, the Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914 expanded the Sherman Act by prohibiting business activities, such as price discrimination, that corporations could use to lay the groundwork for monopolistic practices.

Indeed, competition laws make certain that fair competition occurs in an open-market economy and progressing along with the market, attentively guarding against would-be monopolies and disruptions to the productive course of competition. Moreover, effective competition aids consumers by assisting businesses to offer goods and services on the most favorable terms. Also, antitrust rules disallow

agreements between market operators impeding competition, and the abuse of dominance. Furthermore, competition inspires efficiency and innovation decreasing prices which means that in order to be effective, competition necessitates businesses to act independently of each other, but subject to the competitive pressure exerted by the others. Competition on the merits indicates the departure from the market or the marginalization of competitors that are less competent and so less attractive to consumers. It is argued that competition was defined as a challenge between companies for customers.<sup>30</sup> G.I. Zekos argues that competition policy should lead to the deconcentrating of national and global commerce based on fair principles of equal opportunity and the rule of law and so denoting equal position to antagonize for innovation and economic development.

Likewise, antitrust law is supporting fair economic competition as a real-world process rather than a theoretical ideal, reducing vertical control as a means of economic and market organization and replacing it with more horizontal forms of cooperation. Moreover, antitrust law guarantees substantively unrestricted economic outcomes, eliminating the immense influence of the economically powerful and government and so imposing consumer protection. It is worth noting that currently the enforcement of antitrust law has caused inequality as a consequence, in part, of the current antitrust regime.<sup>31</sup> Nachbar<sup>32</sup> argues that antitrust law seeks to avert first “market harm,” portrayed and assessed as “a harm to efficiency,” and second “regulatory harm,” a “harm to the freedom of choice felt by those participating in the market.” Moreover, Crane<sup>33</sup> says that antitrust law should exist principally to achieve allocative efficiency and to advance consumer welfare.

Concerning consumers, competition offers the highest quality products at the lowest possible prices, and society's resources are distributed most competently when businesses are subject to the objectivities of a competitive market. Antitrust and competition laws seek to prevent the benefits of a competitive market from being undermined by anticompetitive practices. On the other hand, the erosion of antitrust in the direction of allowing vertical price and nonprice restraints has essentially legalized labor outsourcing, misclassification, and the gig economy which means that dominant corporations having access to a wider range of profitable business models utilize greater power and control over workers than they once performed. Hence, antitrust allows expanding the power of the economy's most powerful players instead of prohibiting monopolies.

The erosion of antitrust has authorized the advancement of the gig economy and dominant corporations have access to a wider range of profitable business models employing greater power and control over workers than they once did. It could be said that the existing antitrust background considers economic coordination as a kind of trespass against the public good, where the public good is outlined by the competitive order and the supplementary conception of efficiency. Undeniably, antitrust’s present allocation of coordination rights has counted on two varying claims concerning the company utilized in law and economics thinking. On the one hand, vertically organized companies are considered top quality in their contributions to society, compared with other economic arrangements. On the other hand, antitrust’s company exemption necessitates moderating and quashing the importance of the preferential antitrust treatment the company receives by describing it as a simple collection of contracts constrained by the market. Are these claims inconsistent? It could be said that the Bork approach, at its foundation, specifies that economic coordination should be structured by command rather than by cooperation, whether that command is endorsed via customary employment relationships or via contracts that personify and amplify preexisting “polarities of power.” To that extent, Sanjukta Paul<sup>42</sup> argues that “competition law—frequently understood as simply maintaining so-called free markets, and institutionally a site of one of law and economics’ most complete victories—allocates economic coordination rights in idiosyncratic and autonomous ways that cannot be derived from independent principles.”

It seems that law assigns economic coordination rights in order to establish a competitive order which is based on political decisions which are implemented via law grounded on economics rather than political devices and so directing the law and economics focus on competition via an economic road. It has to be taken into account that coordination rights are assigned to the corporation by antitrust law rather than by corporate law by extending the business corporation’s public nature and public duties.

It is worth mentioning here that the incorporation of economics into antitrust law has been the extensive rejection of broad rules of per se illegality. ## 2.5 Competition and MNEs

MNE activity generates positive spillovers to national economies, upgrading the productivity of local companies via the transfer of advanced production technologies, managerial knowledge, and working practices.

First of all, the competitiveness of the MNE depends on its capacity to make better use of the competencies located in the numerous subsidiaries and the subsidiaries that are essential to the MNE employing numerous methods for developing competence. Knowledge, capabilities, and resources have become the central point of behavior and development in corporations and differences between corporations are attributable to their changing capability to generate, exploit, and combine knowledge, skills, and resources. Moreover, the subsidiary's competence and the utilization of that competence have been shown to have an effect on the corporate role of the subsidiary. The competitiveness of the local market environment is a substantial characteristic of the subsidiary's corporate role. Why MNEs choose one mode of servicing the foreign market versus the other? Sustainable competitive advantage (SCA)<sup>47</sup> has an affirmative effect on the cycle time of the worldwide sourcing process and the organization's overall business performance. Hence, MNEs establish their activities abroad in technological areas where they are strong at

FDI is a vibrant process in which past investment experience functions as a predictor of future investment channels. Moreover, the growing digitalization of production is expected to be the biggest game-changer in this process, reversing the significance and length of GVCs and reorienting global production and trade. Thus, GVCs generate significant results for participating corporations. Taking into account that GVCs endure central transformation and so remaking the global trade and investment landscape, James X. Zhan<sup>51</sup> argues that “We are entering a decade of de-globalization and the mainstreaming of sustainability... FDI has been influential in the expansion of GVCs, with MNEs coordinating GVCs through their networks of foreign affiliates and non-equity mode partners.<sup>52</sup> Moreover, country-level macroeconomic issues inspire FDI inflows, such as market size, openness, taxes, labor costs, trade costs, and exchange rate, among others. To that extent, FDI is above all motivated by the availability of lower-cost resources and new markets and so the rational response of the MNE is to retain its technological capacity at home and concentrate foreign production on relatively low value-added activities.

It has to be taken into account that the risk of operating in a relatively unsophisticated market is high and such risks can be minimized if production is restricted to assembly operations. The majority of product innovation takes place in the central or prosperous regions as opposed to the peripheral or less-prosperous regions which means that the full benefits of indirect and dynamic effects are only likely to be forthcoming when MNEs set up subsidiaries with more strategic autonomy and so allowing subsidiaries to develop linkages through local procurement activities as they take part in more value-added activities. Only when this autonomy from the parent organization is highly developed, the effect of technology and other asset transfer is likely to improve the competitive position of the local economy. Even if linkages are allowed to develop as MNE subsidiaries become more embedded into the host economy, the precise effect on regional development is difficult to calculate. Also, the role of MNE subsidiaries in the process of regional development is also ambiguous.<sup>53</sup> It is only those subsidiaries, which have extensive levels of strategic autonomy, performing a range of value-added activities that have the potential to influence local economic development to any great extent.<sup>54</sup> Additionally, inward investment is likely to stimulate the production of global competitors in the recipient country.<sup>55</sup>

Cross-border M&As in infrastructure sectors stipulate global FDI. Vertical FDI is made by corporations that geographically break their production into stages, normally on the basis of factor intensities, utilizing lower factor prices overseas or reducing transactions costs by internalizing upstream or downstream activities.<sup>57</sup> It has to be taken into account that capital denotes anything used to produce goods by encompassing money, machinery, equipment, buildings, know-how, etc. which means that physical capital, human capital, natural wealth, technological level, and innovation are providing corporations' competitiveness on the global market and the augmentation of economies' competitiveness within the global economic system. If various stages of the production process are distinguished by several levels of labor amount, there is an allocation of the stages with high labor intensity to countries with low levels of labor costs and the stages needing lots of skills or capital to high-income countries. Consequently, there is a complementarity between a corporation's foreign and home operations, since both are involved to produce the good. In the short run, substitution between the employment's levels at home and abroad take place if an activity beforehand conducted at home is relocated overseas.<sup>58</sup> To that extent, MNEs using the vertical FDI model diminish employment at home, relative to production, by allocating labor-intensive stages of their production to their affiliates in developing countries.<sup>59</sup> The possibility to invest in a low-cost host country augments the corporation's competitiveness, advance its use of economies of scale, and reduce its costs leading to an increase in home-country employment. It has to be taken into consideration that activities transferred by MNEs to low-cost countries are unskilled-labor intensive from the point of view of the home economy, but skilled-labor intensive from the point of view of the host country. On the other hand, corporations following the horizontal FDI model open out and increase their existing advantages by moving their activities overseas. Horizontal MNEs are multi-plant enterprises that look for utilizing their existing advantages and replicate roughly the same activities in many locations. Thus, the strategic reason for moving outward is the intention to reap benefits of the market opportunities in a foreign country and use the economies of scale result and

Regardless of their soft law character, the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises<sup>60</sup> are recommendations from governments to multinational enterprises on responsible business conduct having a clear prospective to generate impactful outcomes for victims of corporate misconduct. Thus, the soft law Guidelines are a useful device not only in assisting greater corporate responsibility to abide by human rights and the environment but also in improving the legal framework on corporate accountability.

MNEs examine their various options and determinants in multinational market competition in order to achieve maximum performance on a global basis. Multinational market competition is a unique case of multipoint competition and so competitive moves in attack and response are the most basic units in any competitive rivalry. Which are the determinants of the particular tactical options for dealing with competitive attack in multiple national markets? The decisive success of any competitive action depends vitally on whether that action goes unchallenged or whether the response is delayed.

It has to be taken into consideration that high visibility, high perceived potential, and high strategic threat provoke rapid responses from incumbent corporations. The greater the dependence on a market under attack, the more the respondent will react mainly to a price action than other types of competitive moves.<sup>62</sup> It could be said that a combination of high visibility and low difficulty is particularly possible to stir up a large number of responses. Also, multipoint competition refers to situations where corporations compete synchronously against the same rivals in multiple product markets, or multiple national markets.<sup>63</sup> Hence, a corporation's action and reaction across a host of markets are based not only on its market overlap with rivals but also

The world consists of information just as it contains material and energy. Businesses base their competitive advantages to a considerable degree on the resources and characteristics of their home countries and these resources play a crucial role in forming their advantages than resources elsewhere for the reason that the capacity of corporations to access resources in foreign countries by way of foreign investment is limited. Furthermore, perfect competition itself is not at all suitable to provide adequate reasons for a sufficient production level of technological innovation in society. Competition slows down innovation since the competitive advantage attained by an innovation erodes rapidly as its price declines relative to the industry's marginal cost and its profit decreases to its "normal" level. Moreover, innovation and technological change is a prime driving force behind economic growth and development conducted by domestic businesses and/or foreign MNEs resident there. New technology is not always offered on the market via licensing arrangements and so joint ventures with innovating multinationals are the best means of learning new technology. Alliance with foreign innovating corporations is the best basis for certain forms of managerial human capital formation, with potential spillovers into the national economy. To that extent, spillovers are a fundamental mode of technology transfer and diffusion for developing countries and it is a way that these countries are insisting to encourage.

Since the meaning and the content of competition are not absolute and monolithic, it could be said that competition and innovation are not related in a linear correlation.<sup>69</sup> To that extent, Chicago scholars have been influenced by the Schumpeterian understanding of innovation and their key apprehension is that the ex-post rewards to innovators should not be weaken by the application of antitrust law for the reason that there is a risk of destabilizing the ex-ante enticement to innovate.<sup>70</sup> Thus, in order to preserve the incentive to innovate, the possession of monopoly power will not be considered illegitimate except it goes along with an element of anticompetitive conduct. For instance, in cases such as *Microsoft*<sup>71</sup> referring to interoperability information or *Intel*, the Commission analysis and remedies focus on boosting competition and allowing innovation to be developed within the existing network of the market in question. To that extent it could be said that article 102 TFEU is an instrument to make certain that markets remain open for all prospective innovators.

## 2.6 Competition and IPRs

Is there any involvement of IPRs in new economy and in attracting FDI inflows? Intellectual property is at the center of the e-economy known as “knowledge-based economy” picturing the new economic environment in which the creation and the management of knowledge play a prevalent part in wealth creation, as compared with the traditional factors of production, explicitly land, labor, and capital.<sup>73</sup> The new industries that developed are characterized by: negligible marginal costs, consumer lock-in effects, value-based pricing, a concentration on intellectual property protection, moderate capital requirements, very high rates of innovation, swift and repeated entry and exit, and network effects imparting economies of scale in consumption.

It has to be taken into account that intellectual property rights<sup>74</sup> do not exist in a vacuum but they are closely linked and affected by competition policies and foreign direct investment laws. Adoption of an adequate competition law is necessary in order to protect the market from anticompetitive practices by IPRs rights' holders.<sup>75</sup> Intellectual property rights holders have expanded the boundaries of their claims, bringing those rights into ever-greater conflict with the primary principles and assumptions of the antitrust laws.<sup>76</sup>

It is worth mentioning here that digital technologies such as artificial intelligence, big data, and cloud computing are flourishing and so AI technologies transform the global economy and initiate new growth openings for startups and businesses galvanizing people and communities in all regions of the globe. AI innovations are technologies executing commands and advance their performance based on feedback and learning processes, without human intervention. Digital platforms, technology-enabled devices assisting transactions between people, offer infrastructure to build new products or services or initiate institutional infrastructure such as

As a result of the vertically integrated platforms of big tech companies, the information these companies gather from users is leveraged to augment downstream products and services generating economic development. Moreover, it is generated in the interoperability between apps and payment methods. Additionally, from an antitrust perspective, a few companies running a large share of the economic system are harmful to further innovation and future economic growth and so raising competitive matters about whether leveraging market power in an upstream vertical segment might restrain competition and innovation downstream. Hence, by using data collected from past user buying patterns on the digital platform, comparable but competing products are delivered from the parent company of the digital platform. On the other hand, taking into account that there is no barrier to entry in the traditional anticompetition sense, there are economic arguments to counter suggestions of an antitrust threat from the digital platforms because e-platforms are uninterrupted innovating and competing with one another.<sup>78</sup>

Policymakers should embrace strategies for upholding IPRs protection as well as management and development of IPRs resources classified into four fundamental categories: developing national IPRs strategy, formulating and enforcing needed laws, providing good infrastructures, and launching appropriate educational and training programs.

How competition in the product market affects the rate of innovation? Innovation advocates interplay between organizational structure and technological change involving imitation or anticipated repositioning by rival companies. There are various technical innovations that implicate evidently modest changes to the existing technology but that have rather striking competitive effect.<sup>79</sup>

Developing countries tend to have IPRs systems that support information diffusion through low-cost imitation of foreign products and technologies suggesting that scenarios for domestic invention and innovation are unsatisfactorily developed to justify protection. Nonetheless, malfunctioning IPRs could restrain technical change even at low levels of economic development because many inventions and product innovations are designed at local markets gaining from domestic protection of patents, utility models, and trade secrets. Also, the most advantageous level of IPR protection should assess between the social profit of enhanced innovation and the social costs of monopolistic distortions and income inequality. Conclusively, in an open economy, accomplishing the globally most advantageous level of protection

The object of any legal protection is to maximize the investment of time, energy, and capital in innovative activities while minimizing any restriction on the public's freedom to utilize goods resulting from such inventiveness.<sup>80</sup> Is there a need for a mere convergence or a total harmonization of IPR protection? Nordhaus<sup>81</sup> argues that the most advantageous patent length should be evaluated between the static distortion consequence of patent protection and the dynamic return from enhanced innovation.

Do IPRs award a monopolistic market power to right holders? Society acquires four kinds of benefits from granting short-term monopoly rights to innovators such as first, the incentive of private innovation as the primary economic gain of IPRs; second, the utilization of the new knowledge in productive activity leading to higher incomes, employment, and competitiveness for the economy as a whole; third, the spreading of new knowledge to other agents due to IPRs and contractual agreements (procurement, licensing or sales) or diffusion<sup>82</sup>; and fourth, the legal framework increases the cost of technology to the buyer. The simple incidence of an intellectual property right does not assume the existence of market power and so IPRs do not grant automatically a monopolistic market power to right holders.

It has to be taken into account that increased dominance by a single corporation must not be interpreted as a lack of competition but it may suggest that the technological leader has the most motivation to innovate for the reason that competitive pressure is sound. Moreover, competition policy could augment the pace of technological advancement in the economy by making a distinction between innovative industries. Thus, competition for the market is expected to strengthen the incentive to rapidly achieve considerable size and market share, perhaps in order to have one's standard adopted by the industry. Likewise, the significance of intellectual property rights depends on the capacity of rights holder to exercise a certain degree of market power.<sup>83</sup> Similarly, Scherer considers that competition promotes innovation than intellectual property<sup>84</sup> which means that intellectual property protection has to be constructed in a way of permitting entrance of competitors.

Institutional deficiencies force MNEs to internalize the production and exchange of value-creating resources. Thus, MNEs innovative performance is boosted when the corporation's R&D activities are based in locations where IPR protection is strong.<sup>85</sup> Hence, MNEs with innovation activities in locations of high IPR protection display higher innovation performance than those in the middle and especially the lower, category. Consequently, MNEs use their inventive capacities to generate patents bringing advantages underlying their internationalization.<sup>86</sup> MNEs exploit internal organization to counter the appropriability hazards in the external environment when implementing innovation activities in weak institutions.

It has to be taken into account that the digitalization of the global economy has enabled MNEs to exploit digital technologies to appropriately circumvent paying corporate income taxes by shifting their profits from high-tax rate states to low-tax rate states. Hence, if an MNE's permanent establishments producing digital products or services are located in a country with low corporate tax rates just for tax-planning reasons. To that extent, it is examined that MNEs have to pay at least 15% of corporate income taxes at the global level and so making ineffective tax-planning strategies involving transfer pricing and royalty payments, which take advantage of the tax rate variances and the tax treaties among different countries.<sup>87</sup> By the way, if global investments of MNEs are executed as a part of tax-planning strategies, MNEs will react to a new international tax system by altering their investment patterns to minimize their tax burdens and so maximizing their profits.

Which is the scope of Protection for Intellectual Property Rights? Employing compulsory licensing to restrict IPR for the rationale of promoting competition can have the contrary effect, deterring innovation and competition by persuading those who gain from the compulsory license to imitate existing products rather than innovating new products themselves. It has to be taken into consideration that the inventor-patentee has a legal right to prevent others from using that invention and the possibility of potentially high profit is a major incentive for undertaking risky and costly innovative activities, and so the whole thrust of the IPR laws is to use that incentive to promote innovation. For that reason, there is no violation under US antitrust law for unilaterally pricing an IPR license “too high.” Moreover, there should not be a presupposition that a patent or other IPR creates market power which

It is worth noting that open trade increases access to services and goods, advances quality and variety of goods and services, and diminishes costs. Nevertheless, excessive concentration of production, restrictive trade policies, supply chain disruptions, and regulatory divergence endanger the capability of responding to global demands in occasions such as pandemics.<sup>90</sup> Thus, by harmonizing regulation and establishing international standards for needed goods and production processes enhance the efficiency of markets. Finally, the concise presentation reveals an important role of IPRs and competitiveness in attracting FDI inflows.

## 2.7 Competition Law, Competition, and Democracy

It is worth mentioning here that the legal rules of competition law outlaw:

1. Anticompetitive agreements (Section 1 of the Sherman Act in the USA or Article 101 TFEU in the EU).
2. The abuse of substantial market power (Section 2 of the Sherman Act and Sections 2–3 of the Clayton Act in the USA, or Article 102 TFEU in the EU).
3. Anticompetitive mergers (Section 7 of the Clayton Act in the USA and Regulation 139/2004 EC in the EU).

Is there disagreement on the proper or actual goal of competition law? Should the mission of competition law be the safeguarding of competitive process in restoring

Should competition law promote efficiency, growth, and innovation, but also the long-term interests of consumers?

G. I. Zekos<sup>91</sup> has written that “European competition law moved from a norm of presumption of illegality to a default assumption of legality, where the responsibility of proof rests with either the party alleging a breach or government antitrust authorities... It could be argued that political interests have influenced the concept of competition... Increased globalization has opened markets to anticompetitive conduct by foreign companies... the internationalization of antitrust enforcement is the answer to this globalization of anticompetitive conduct... Consequently, economics and law in tandem contribute to the competitiveness of any economy in the 21st century globalization.” Competition policy encompasses both economic measures and the endorsement of competition law. Hence, there is a need of distinguishing competition as an economics function and competition law which offers the neutral legal rules in order to have a well-functioning competitive process in the market contributing to the safeguard of competition in an economy. Thus, the role of competition law has to be that of presenting the legal principles letting the run of the competitive process and clearly specifying the disallowed activities and actions which means that principles, elements, aspects, and results of applied economics cannot be considered as the principles of competition law.

It is worth mentioning here that the following views of scholars concerning the goal of competition law will show the divergence or convergence about it:

1. Amato<sup>92</sup> regards consumer welfare as a synonym for efficiency and competition law and attempts to strike a balance between economic freedom, on the one hand, and constraining market power, on the other hand.
2. Ahdar<sup>93</sup> receives efficiency as a goal competition law not only promoting efficiency, growth, and innovation but also the long-term interests of consumers.
3. Odudu<sup>94</sup> considers that the goal of competition policy is consumer welfare.
4. Heyer<sup>95</sup> has interpreted Bork's thesis as arguing for total welfare.

It is apparent that there are both great variety and wide disagreement of views on the proper or actual goal of competition law. All the elements referred by scholars are elements of development due to taking part freely in the market which means allowing all players to compete in the market with no advantages allocated to firms with market power by endorsing ex ante legal rules governing competitive process and so denoting anticompetitive actions. A specific law such as competition law cannot regulate all aspects of law concerning different category activities such as civil law matters, labor law, consumer law, and even political economy rationales and so the central rationale has to be a single one encompassing all elements influencing the central principle; for example, concerning competition law, the rationale is the protection of competition via keeping open entrance in the market for all possible players. G. I. Zekos considers that competition law via its legal principles protects a competitive process by leaving open the door of entrance in a market which means that the freedom of all actors to run in a market will generate growth, innovation, and efficiency by applying the principles of economy in tandem with effective management. To that extent, Wu<sup>118</sup> regards that the consumer welfare standard of competition law should be discarded in favor of protecting competition and so the protection of competition standard is easier to apply since prospective threats to the competitive process are far more noticeable than reductions in consumer welfare. Taking into consideration that digital markets generate harms that are not captured by the welfare criterion but can be clarified on the grounds of harm to the process of competition, Marty<sup>119</sup> considers that welfare undoubtedly best captures the priorities of competition law, but that it required to be complemented by a consideration for the protection of the process of competition as well.

Moreover, automation generates new jobs and so the workforce is becoming progressively digital which means that people work alongside algorithms occasionally independently, sometimes overseeing them, sometimes overseen by them. There is accelerating demand for a variety of wholly new specialist roles linked with the latest emerging technologies. Additionally, corporate algorithms

It is worth noting here that the imperative legal point of the AI effect is that AI has become a legal entity in practice and it has to be recognized legally by governments in order to have a certainty contributing to innovation as well. Taking into account that autonomy, intelligence, and awareness are the elements to receive the legal personhood, AAI has to incorporate those factors in order to be effectively run in the forthcoming AAI society and AAI economy. In other words, AAI technology will build an AAI society run by AAI humanoids generating AAI economy in an AAI globalized world.

The law needs to depend on its own systems nature to appropriately provide the appropriate structure for the interaction of technology and society that will continue to uphold important societal values. Hence, it is worth noting that the law itself, being a product of human decision-making, is riddled with incoherencies in its substance and implementation and so AI law has to achieve coherency in its substance and implementation due to the objective functioning of AI technology.

It is worth mentioning here that when the law acknowledges an AI entity as subject of rights, it also regulates such AI entity's duties and potential liabilities in order to achieve legal certainty in AI society. Platforms play a fundamental role in the AI economy and algorithms are becoming more widely used for pricing and other business functions. Moreover, using algorithms instead of humans to make decisions is becoming more widespread in commerce. Thus, digital companies rely on algorithms to set prices, among other

tasks. Algorithmic pricing is noteworthy in the context of platforms for the reason that digital platforms have become high-flying in the economy.

Which is the association between algorithmic pricing and competition? Do algorithms enable tacit collusion? Even though corporations have made use of pricing software for decades, technological spreads have generated a swing from mechanically set prices to AI-powered algorithms handling enormous quantities of data and interacting, learning, and making decisions with unparalleled speed and sophistication. To that extent, the advancement of algorithmic-pricing software has raised fears concerning the prospective influence on corporation behavior and competition. Above all, the prospective for the use of algorithms as a method to facilitate collusion, either tacit or explicit, has arisen.

Taking into account that an algorithm can better uncover underlying fluctuations in wholesale prices or better predict demand, a result of the rapid expansion of big data and AI-driven market analysis by corporations is that personalized pricing strategies become gradually feasible and hi-tech. Hence, AI advances are utilized to learn more about consumer tastes along with more accurately price products as a function of these tastes. Thus, big data accelerate price discrimination practically implemented in markets which means that accurate determination of ideal personalized pricing increases corporation profits. Furthermore, taking into consideration that there is mass adoption of algorithmic pricing software in markets, pricing software adoption influences competition in the market due to the qualities of the algorithmic pricing and so there is a need of investigating compliance with competition law. Stephanie Assad et al. <sup>163</sup> argue “that the adoption of algorithmic pricing has affected competition and facilitated tacit-collusion in the German retail gas market.”

Dynamic pricing denotes a set of pricing strategies that increase profits by adjusting the set price in line with changing variables in supply and demand. Platform pricing poses an extra challenge for algorithms because they must learn to set an optimal price level and structure. Algorithmic pricing is a method of automatically setting prices using pre-programmed instructions to maximize sellers’ profits offering several benefits, such as low cost of setting prices and better forecasts. To that extent, algorithms may also reduce prices and increase consumer surplus leading to better service and better product availability. It is worth noting that algorithmic pricing under asymmetric conditions leads some sellers to respond faster to a price drop by competitors than others which means that the slower competitors miss the rationale to cut prices for the reason that they will not gain bigger demand, which increases prices for all sellers in a quasi-collusive equilibrium.

<sup>164</sup>

<sup>163</sup> Stephanie Assad, Robert Clark, Daniel Ershov, Lei Xu, *Algorithmic Pricing and Competition: Empirical Evidence from the German Retail Gasoline Market*, CESifo Working Paper No. 8521 p43.

<sup>164</sup> Brown, Zach Y., and Alexander MacKay. 2023. “Competition in Pricing Algorithms.” *American Economic Journal: Microeconomics*, 15 (2): 109–56.

Even if algorithmic systems can adjust prices for legitimate reasons, they also permit new possibilities for anticompetitive behavior. Antitrust implications are caused by the growing reliance on corporations' dynamic pricing algorithms. To that extent, when a product has limited capacity and an expiration date, technology now lets a company, with relative ease, to make larger swings in prices while still being assured of the sale.<sup>165</sup>

With the spread of e-commerce and AI technology, a wider array of corporations utilize dynamic pricing strategies in real time and so perfect price discrimination is now increasingly possible to approximate.<sup>166</sup> A pricing algorithm is a sequence of computational actions by using data inputs to set prices for a product or service and so algorithms can be programmed to maximize any variable by utilizing the inputted data and decision tools.<sup>167</sup> Dynamic pricing algorithms extend beyond e-commerce retailers and so Uber utilizes a price-surfing algorithm to set the price of a ride share according to real-time factors such as available drivers and demand for rides.<sup>168</sup> Uber's standard driver's agreement plainly asserts that drivers are required to charge the rider the price "recommended" by Uber.<sup>169</sup>

Algorithms learn to set supra-competitive prices abiding by some view of equilibrium. Even though setting supra-competitive prices may not be illegal in most jurisdictions, it might harm consumers due to the objective of pricing algorithms in maximizing expected profits. Hence, algorithmic price-setting causes a series of both intentional and unintentional market distortions and so leads to possible cases of algorithmic collusion.<sup>170</sup> Moreover, algorithmically facilitated anticompetitive conduct in multi-company interactions is not detectable through traditional ways.<sup>171</sup> Also, algorithmically fostered anticompetitive behavior may be entirely unconscious.

Antitrust prohibitions of coordinated conduct are conditioned on the existence of “an agreement in restraint of trade” which means the offer and acceptance of an agreement not to compete. Antitrust laws limit some actions that modify market conditions in a manner that makes possible algorithmic coordination. <sup>185</sup> On the other hand, algorithmic coordination can be considered as a joint monopoly which means that companies running the algorithms are subject to the legal restrictions imposed on monopolies. By the way, monopoly power is the capacity of a seller to control all or a substantial part of the market and so dictating the terms of trade, involving charging prices in excess of its marginal cost and forcing unfavorable non-price provisions on its customers.

Nonetheless, even if a joint monopoly is proven, there is a need to show that the algorithms monopolized their power. Yet algorithms do not engage in exclusionary conduct, and high prices are not prohibited, as such. <sup>186</sup> Therefore, the accumulative entrustment of price-setting to algorithms has the prospective for “opening a back door” via which corporations could collude lawfully which means that as the use of algorithms becomes more commonplace, more markets will move from collusion to coordination and so while both lead to supra-competitive prices, only the former is prohibited by laws. <sup>187</sup> Hence, the programming of the coordination of algorithms leading to uncompetitive prices rather than competitive prices must be considered as containing exclusionary conduct.

## 2.11 E-Platforms Power

It is characteristic that worldwide the public is recognizing the extreme concentration of wealth and power in the hands of a few e-platforms that contact exploitative and often unauthorized surveillance, harvesting, processing, and disclosure of personal data.<sup>195</sup>

Oligopolistic platforms such as social networks and search engines use free content to draw individuals onto their platforms and take advantage of influential network outcomes which means that such platforms then use data harvesting and surveillance not only in amplifying the time that users spend on the platform but also in selling advertising and personal data and so allowing third parties secretly to utilize them in order to control individuals' opinions, spending, and political position.<sup>196</sup>

Moreover, the advancement of fair use doctrine must take into consideration the circumstances in which dominant platforms use the free circulation of works to reap user attention by advancing their communicative power both with regard to copyright owners and to users.

AI technology has amplified individuals' opportunities to generate and share works which coincides with a remarkable increase in the concentration of ownership of platforms for disseminating content, and a striking concentration of cyberspace users' attention. On the other hand, cyberspace does not shift the role of commercial media organizations in choosing and filtering content. Moreover, media sources that were central before cyberspace also dominate in cyberspace which means that the same ownership merely utilizes AI technology. To that extent, cyberspace filtration algorithms functioning on search engines and social networks produce a hierarchy of visibility in cyberspace. Hence, platforms exploit their users' base, and their capabilities in selling advertisements and worthy data which means that the commercial misuse of cyberspace users' personal data embraces a new public e-territory. Also, platforms epitomize both horizontal and vertical strategies for obtaining the surplus value of user data and so the platform provider's target is to become and stay on the central point of intermediation for parties in their target markets.

It has to be taken into consideration that platforms like Google and Amazon want to be able to copy works and to deliver links to works, without paying the copyright

## 2.12 Digitalization and Digital Entrepreneurship

Digitalization is determined by the computerization of the economy, robotization, and the automation of production processes. It is worth noting that a decline in the price of digital technology is one of the key factors adding to the increase in digital capital investment and so an increase in digital capital is opening a broader adoption of digital technologies which means accelerating the diffusion of innovations from the frontier to non-frontier businesses and boosting convergence in firm-level productivity. Hence, it is a digital investment that augments the average firm's TFP growth.<sup>197</sup> To that extent, Robert Anderton et al.<sup>198</sup> show that "digitalisation tends to have on average a positive impact on firm-level TFP growth. However, the impact of digitalisation on productivity is very heterogeneous across firms. First, there is an important component associated with sectoral heterogeneity, with the average firm in most sectors not being able to reap the productivity benefits from digital investment. Second, only the 30% most productive laggard firms benefit from digitalisation." Nevertheless, an increase in digital investment by itself is not enough for firms to turn into frontier firms.

Is digitalization a massive game-changer that brings huge advances in productivity? Of course, digitalization alters firms' productivity growth and is productivity game-changer for firms able to utilize on a full scale all devices of digital technology including AI. On the other hand, if digitalization embraces only general-purpose technology, then its productivity gains will be normally slow to materialize.<sup>199</sup> Thus, digitalization is a productivity game-changer only for a minority of firms that are the most capable of obtaining the productivity gains of digital technologies by utilizing specific digitalization devices fitting not only to their production mechanism but also to their governance strategy and plans.

Digital technology motivates entrepreneurial aims and the openness of digital technology can diminish the risk and social pressure sensed by entrepreneurs. It has to be taken into consideration that digital technology intensifies the complexity and uncertainty of the entrepreneurial environment and advances the capacity of start-ups to interact with multiple parties to energetically develop into a platform-based ecosystem. Provided that digital technology diminishes the cost of tie-building by growing its breadth and depth in traditional social networks, digital technology is shifting the discovery and creation mechanisms of opportunities in traditional entrepreneurship. Also, digital technology stimulates the entrepreneurial process by energizing entrepreneurial willingness, entrepreneurial opportunities, and business models. Negligence claims are comprised of four required elements: (1) duty, (2) breach, (3) causation, and (4) damages. Moreover, the assumption of risk defense is available to parties defending against not only negligence claims but also products and strict liability and misrepresentation claims. The field of “AI torts” will embrace not only injuries triggered by autonomous vehicles but also robots powered by machine learning, software algorithms programmed with AI components, and humans counting on AI to assist them in a variety of tasks. <sup>213</sup>

It has to be taken into account that embedded AI-driven algorithms, ever-present in your daily tasks, are hidden from view and often do not instigate the types of injuries typically remedied through torts. Nonetheless, physical manifestations of AI in robot or vehicle forms engaged in human contact are expected to result in tort injuries. AI is not the first new technology that triggers injuries that may be remedied by tort doctrine. Moreover, as a new technology or knowledge of its risks becomes more commonplace, courts are permitting the assumption of risk defense not extending to product defects. Also, injuries produced by product defects will be litigated under a strict product liability regime holding manufacturers of AI to a much higher standard of care. Similarly, courts often expect defendants to show that plaintiffs had actual knowledge of the defect before permitting the assumption of risk defense to block recovery. <sup>214</sup> The subjective knowledge needed for the assumption of risk makes it difficult for defendants to prove that plaintiffs injured by AI technologies fully realized the risks they undertook, since AI is often created a “black box” strictly as a result of its lack of explainability. <sup>215</sup> Until the use of AI
