## 3.1 Introduction

Globalization refers primarily to the progressive elimination of barriers to trade and investment and unprecedented international mobility of capital. Moreover, globalization is a complex, forceful legal, and social process that takes place within an integrated whole without regard to geographical boundaries. Globalization of the world economy boosts the flow of capital investment among countries.

Economic globalization denotes the intensifying flow of trade, goods, and services among countries via FDI. Effective public policies must improve the regulatory environment in view of attracting international capital flows and improving the financial viability of the industrial sector. <sup>1</sup> Political globalization signifies cumulative interactions between states in their common interest and so there is regional and international cooperation in different pursuits. Ultimately, social globalization indicates the development of a common culture and a decrease in the differences between people. Economic and political globalization inspires governments to adopt e-governance technology in order to handle the constant demands for efficiency and speed in an ever-changing environment.

It is worth noting that globalization is an imperative part of both the internal and the external environment. To that extent, public administration does not exist in a vacuum dealing with the environment, both internal and external, to perform the duties of the government. Public organizations are inspired by global phenomena and so globalization instigates the leadership challenges and responsibilities. Moreover, leadership scrutinizes the transformations happening in the world in order to take suitable decisions touching the public. Leadership no longer possesses the monopoly in the control of public life and so several players have a stimulus on the events in any country in which the leaders become reactive rather than the active

<sup>1</sup>Lapatinas, A., Kyriakou, A and Garas, A., 2019. Taxation and economic sophistication: Evidence from OECD countries. PLoS One 14(3): e0213498.

policymaker. Furthermore, globalization has presented new contests of ethics and accountability by confronting organizations with complex and interdependent matters. Globalization has caused revolutionary alterations in information and communication technologies that have altered the globe's political and economic landscape.

The transmission of modern technology in the globalization course is fundamental in developing technological and research capabilities via technology transfer. Also, technological advancement helps to accumulate physical capital which is a precondition for developing and exporting more sophisticated products. Stéphane Nguea and Hervé Fotio<sup>2</sup> argue that “a higher level of the overall globalization index significantly enhances economic sophistication. Besides, economic and political globalization, and de facto measures of social globalization have a positive and significant effect on economic sophistication.”

Increased globalization has led to a “borderless world,” in which an ever-increasing percentage of a nation’s workforce is employed by foreign-owned enterprises, foreign subsidiaries have thus become more and more important contributors to a nation’s competitiveness by providing product and process technology and technical and managerial skills. It is characteristic that privatization as part of the globalization procedure often leads to the modernization of productive infrastructures for bringing forth resource-complementarity in the economy.

Globalization entails an increase in the spillovers reinforcing a global financial cycle. While globalization has expedited global risk-sharing and diversification, national financial conditions are driven by a “global financial cycle,” distinguished by large common movements in asset prices, gross capital flows, and leverage. Moreover, globalization has been an imperative factor influencing the properties of business cycle dynamics, the sensitivity of activity, inflation, and financial settings to external circumstances. Hence, globalization plays a role in letting a better understanding of the monetary policy transmission mechanism, the reaction role of the central bank, and the monetary policy advancements.<sup>3</sup> It could be said that globalization has transformed the interrelationships between economies and between sectors within economies and so commercial globalization has had a positive influence on global productivity by enhancing allocative competence and external competition. Nonetheless, the support to productivity growth is declining, as trade integration slows, and the contestability of global markets swings towards winner-takes-all dynamics.

Digital technologies boost globalization as they make it easier to trade services across borders upsetting the employment and wages of some workers. Hence, digitalization touches the relative shares of employment along the skill and wage distribution, directly widening the distribution of labor income. Digitalization enables automation of various tasks and while digitalization does not automatically

<sup>3</sup> Occasional Paper Series, The implications of globalization for the ECB monetary policy strategy, No 263 / September 2021.

lead to an overall loss in employment, it not only leads to a replacement of existing jobs but also generates new jobs through reinstatement and through employment gains stemming from higher productivity. Also, automation and digitalization amplify wealth inequality and so there are per se changes in earnings inequality but automation boosts the return to capital, which in turn leads to an increase in wealth inequality.<sup>4</sup> It could be said that current AI run according to the human decisions that structured them in the first place. Even though current AI cannot eventually reach the depth and breadth as humans, it enables automation by replacing traditional labor to perform routine and non-routine tasks and so to some extent, such development brings numerous benefits to corporations, as augmenting productivity and efficiency due to the fact that AI permits the capturing, consolidation, and processing of large amounts of information on clients, suppliers, and competitors. Moreover, corporate capability to replace workers with AI technology touches managerial investment decisions. Also, corporations with the capability to replace labor with AI automation embrace more aggressive financial policies.<sup>5</sup>

Digital technologies do not only present cost and/or efficiency advantages but also have many applications due to the fact that they are combined with many other more specific technologies, for the benefit of further innovation which means that digital technologies are prospective catalysts for technological advancement and far-reaching growth in the medium to long term. Of course, the value added by AI is not endless but it adds to the previous technology and so, with the capability of AAI technology utilized by humanoids and working on their limits of capability in an objective way, AAI will add something more.

## 3.2 Technology and Governance

Governance<sup>6</sup> roles encompass the capacity to take part in policy-making at any stage. Power relationships refer to the relative power that a player, or a certain role, has over other players within policy-making and its enforcement and so within various modes of governance, different aspects of power relationships are regarded relevant.

<sup>4</sup>Hubmer, Krusell and Smith, 2020 Hubmer, J., Krusell, P. and Smith Jr, A. A. (2021). Sources of US wealth inequality: Past, present, and future. NBER Macroeconomics Annual 35(1), 391–455. It has to be taken into consideration that governance mechanisms have been modified as a result of globalization, augmented technical specialization, and functional differentiation. Nonetheless, governance adapts to the technical innovations of the digital domain in general, and to the increasing use of blockchain and AI technology.

AI technologies impose their own governance norms and so the altering functions of governance players and so governance mechanisms compel reconceptualization due to the fact that legal norms are lagging behind regarding the pace of technical innovations, but also for the reason that the prospective illegitimate uses of big data cause a great threat to fundamental rights demanding some form of regulation.

It is worth noting that public players, customarily regarded as protectors of public interest, lack the means to successfully govern the spaces generated by many technological innovations. Additionally, public players have been subject to critique for the extensive collection of the data of people, and the leaks of such data as well.

It has to be taken into account that the digital domain needs regulation and governance so as to establish a more legitimate and constructive balance of power. Thus, alterations in policy-making and governance initiate new concepts signifying a change in policy-making as subject to nonstop change of patterns of interaction and relations among players. Horizontal modes of policy-making have emerged due to the demands of globalization and the operational differentiation of sectors of society.

It is worth noting that digital power is flexible, as different actors perform different governance roles within different contexts and so there are times when the networks through which roles are issued function as governance actors themselves. Zwittner and Hazenberg<sup>7</sup> argue that “The integration of actors into governance mechanisms, based on their ability to achieve policy outcomes, runs the risk of privatizing oversight into the hands of those with the most power.”

## 3.3 Algorithmic Governance

Algorithmic governance reveals central questions about the role of participation in a democratic society as well as companies are converting into noteworthy sites of democratic contestation.<sup>8</sup> Moreover, the emerging forms of power and control appearing from AI technologies are privatization, informality, and flexibility in government service provision and so generating concerns of transparency, accountability, and fairness grounds.

Additionally, algorithmic governance<sup>9</sup> makes government more effective, more accurate, and fairer. Moreover, the advent of automation in governance rests on public-private collaborations, intensifying both public and private power and augmenting transparency and accountability gaps. AI technologies are shaping law enforcement giving rise to algorithmic justice via robo-courts and consequently the emergence of robo-justice. To that extent, competition enforcement has become more “technocratic,” entrusted to industrial-policy specialists, and compartmentalized as a regulatory discipline.<sup>10</sup>

As mentioned earlier, transparency<sup>11</sup> is central to a legitimate government and a fair society by offering a basis for more expressive public participation in all facets of governmental decision-making. Hence, the decision maker should state the reasons for his/her determination denoting the evidence he/she relied on and so in the case of AAI decision-making, the same principle has to be applied going along with the objectivity of AAI technology.<sup>12</sup> Thus, algorithmic governance poses real concerns about transparency grounded on matters of algorithm’s source code and its objective function.<sup>13</sup> In other words, algorithmic governance has to follow the law’s demands for transparency while still augmenting efficacy, efficiency, and even legitimacy in government.

Also, algorithmic governance advances<sup>14</sup> without the approval of those whom it most profoundly influences which means that algorithmic mechanisms support existing hierarchies<sup>15</sup> but the emergence of AAI systems has to bring objectivity to the functioning of the market. ## 3.4 Cyberspace and AAI

Cyberspace contributes to enhancing the development of global markets for products, services, information, and capital. The creation of new products and the development of new technologies also contribute to the globalization of markets. It is worth noting that digital services penetrate virtually every aspect of modern life, and the digital economy contributes more than \$2 trillion to the annual GDP of the United States.<sup>21</sup> ICT devices and their development have presented diverse and extended routes for information diffusion through cyberspace. Globalization is enhanced as a result of ICT adoption which in turn augments economic growth as a result of improvements in economies of scale. Likewise, ICT could rather be harmful to economic growth particularly in the absence of economic transformation.<sup>22</sup>

As a result of cyberspace running, digital platforms generate markets and so they offer infrastructure and act as umpires to develop and enforce governing norms by which platform users must abide. On the other hand, Amazon, Google, Apple, and Facebook also utilize their platforms to deliver their own services to end-users and in direct competition with third-party sellers. Moreover, Amazon sells products in its own name on Amazon Marketplace competing with third-party traders on the platform. Also, Google and Apple both run app stores presenting applications from countless independent developers along with Google's and Apple's own applications, such as the G-Mail or Apple Music apps.<sup>23</sup> Likewise, Amazon is holding a position of “super dominance” in the Italian market for marketplace intermediation services, as confirmed on the basis of different indicators<sup>24</sup> and so online platforms generate extreme forms of economic power.

## 3.5 Supply Chains and AAI

Globalization homogenizes economies diminishing the country specificity of shocks fostering FDI and so the current FDI promotes future FDI. It has to be taken into consideration that economic and political globalization boosts economic sophistication. Moreover, financial globalization, trade openness, and FDI enhance economic sophistication.

Global supply chains (GSCs) have become a tool for development and so corporations have increased resilience in GSCs by making them more domestic, shorter supply chains through regionalized production, more diversified by cutting dependence on one or a few countries, and more electronic by using digital technology to track the supply chain better. It is characteristic that the central product in GSCs often is not the finished product, but rather key components or raw materials such as semiconductor shortages being critical inputs for many end-product industries, from advanced electronics to automobiles and home appliances or pharmaceutical ingredients being essential for medicines. Moreover, contemporary GSCs can be remarkably complex, necessitating cross-border trade and investment collaboration. To that extent, supply chains augment strategic competitiveness and so creating a workforce with the needed skills for the AI era is the best path for effective international and public-private partnerships.

The digital economy is globalizing and FinTech is being developed in line with the global trends in digital transformations, thus becoming a new foundation for economic globalization. FinTech is exemplified by a high level of internationalization and globalization offering the needed context for its development.<sup>29</sup> The digital economy advances new avenues not only for innovation but also for monopolization and so companies leverage data to reduce or exclude competition which means that by accumulating and analyzing user data, corporations can predict consumer behavior, recognize loyal and profitable customers, start customized marketing campaigns, and foresee their competitors' business strategies getting the upper hand in negotiating with suppliers and business partners. Thus, firms successfully eliminate competition and exert anticompetitive impact long before their dominance is echoed in market share or price control.

It is worth noting that the consumer generates data largely unconsciously, through every observable activity. To that extent, as data analytics devices become more

advanced, companies that control data<sup>30</sup> will have the capability to exert enormous impact and extract excessive profits from consumers. It could be said that antitrust enforcement should consider a company's "data share" to ascertain its monopoly power. The FTC has also begun to take notice of the link between data ownership and monopoly power.

It could be argued that control over data in a given market is equivalent to monopoly power and so storing and utilizing data might undermine competition which means that direct ownership of data generates difficulties for competitors to get or use and which can be utilized to create barriers to competition. On the other hand, GDPR is a device against anticompetitive behavior.

It could be said that the augmenting complexity of business behavior and its dependence on high-level digital technology is expected to make the antitrust regulator's task respectively complex, such that the government would benefit from the use of digital technology too.

It is worth noting that COVID-19<sup>31</sup> has distorted globalization, and the threat of additional pandemics may cause further changes in international trade and travel. Moreover, the global pandemic has reformed the importance of global supply chains due to the fact that manufacturing and shipping and material shortages are fueling inflation. Besides, the global economy will persist, and its technologies will continue to advance. To that extent, AI has introduced new ways of globalization leading to AI globalization. Will AAI technology and AAI humanoid robots generate AAI globalization due to the automation and the nature of AAI technology and consequently the materialized AAI society? The connectivity and applicability of AAI technology globally will unavoidably produce AAI globalization. It seems that the forthcoming AAI technology will overtake any national policies against globalization due to the nature of AAI systems. In addition, it is expected that the forthcoming AAI globalization will bring forward objectivity considering the needs of the inhabitants of AAI society. It is uncertain that humans can survive in an AAI society governed by AAI systems and ruled by autonomous AAI humanoid robots which will be transformed into AAI humanoids due to advancements in AI technology. Will AAI life exterminate human life? Let us hope that humans will not lose control of technology and that AAI technology will remain a device for improving and not eliminating human life.

## 3.6 Governance and Public Administration

First of all, globalization has raised the concern of government effectiveness resulting from an increased level of competition in the world. To that extent, governance refers to the strategies of governments and non-governmental organizations intended at initiating, facilitating, and mediating network processes and so it could be said that network management is regarded to be a “meta-governance.” Accountability and openness are fundamental for the promotion of good governance and accountability. The technological revolution has enabled the people to deal with many matters. Both public and private organizations are compelled to advance performance to stay competitive. Besides, the government is responsible for providing improved services to the people. The rise of the global society has brought about the revolutionary trades in the world.

Furthermore, governance is a way to reposition public administration as a pre-eminent discipline grounded on the new global realities and so the fundamental mission of public administration is to implement policies. In a globalized world, no state should live in isolation because of opened-up opportunities for the public concerning the affairs of government and greater openness and accountability. The increasing demand for preserving sustainability and dropping income inequality has added new pressures to the government and so the stakeholders are not limited to the territorial boundaries of a country.<sup>32</sup>

Globalization has expedited greater openness and transparency of the affairs of government and so intensifying competition among the territories of the globe to achieve an advantage in the international marketplace. Thus, the non-stop demand for free trade, assisted by the open borders policy, strengthens the levels of competition. Additionally, globalization has tolerated the easy movement of capital, which has permitted MNEs to invest and transfer their capital anywhere in the globe. Simultaneously, it has opened up opportunities for people to buy and sell products and services stimulating market liberalization as a device of capitalism which means that no country can operate in isolation in a global economy. Hence, globalization has made public services more transparent, which is a stage toward greater accountability. Also, accountability and openness are fundamental for the promotion of good governance and accountability. On the other hand, corruption triggers inefficiencies by dropping competition and favoring insiders with information and so bringing about additional transaction costs. G.I. ## 3.8 MNEs and Knowledge

MNEs capability to source knowledge is crucial to the success of subsidiaries due to the fact that knowledge is the basis of new innovations generating efficiencies and sustaining competitive advantages. Moreover, MNEs' selection of whether to internally or externally source knowledge is formed by the decision to focus on managing knowledge through global value chains or promoting knowledge development in the host region by supporting new ventures and R&D activities. Thus, as MNEs become gradually centralized and headquarters get more monitoring and control competencies, knowledge-sourcing decisions are progressively centralized, degrading the capacity of subsidiaries to independently source knowledge in their host environments. It has to be taken into consideration that subsidiaries amalgamate the international competencies of the MNE with host region-exclusive advantages due to the fact that subsidiaries have embeddedness being in and of the MNE and the host

It is worth mentioning here that the transfer of knowledge through different distant or local sourcing activities is based on trust. Moreover, trust models the knowledge environment vital to MNE subsidiaries' technology sourcing and innovation. Nonetheless, trust also interacts with external characteristics embracing host region government support for the knowledge economy to shape innovation performance demanding different knowledge acquisition by MNE subsidiaries.

It has to be taken into account that upon investment in a country, an MNE becomes exposed to a prospective degradation of the host country institutional quality and probable confiscation of local host-market assets. Thus, in countries with weak property rights, economic policy uncertainty produces uncertainty not only about policy alterations but also taking risks owing to prospective changes in investor protection laws, regulatory regimes, and monetary and fiscal policies.<sup>41</sup> In addition, foreign investors have limited protection from host countries' legal and political institutions. To that extent, subsidiaries in high EPU settings undergo slower asset and employment advancement and so EPU shocks in one market are linked with the reallocation of resources to subsidiaries in other countries. Finally, direct and indirect spillover effects from rising EPU in host countries initiate a noteworthy drop in firm-level investment and growth. Lin et al.<sup>42</sup> argue that “rising EPU in host countries leads to significant declines in MNC value. The effect is more pronounced for intangible capital-intensive and financially constrained firms.”

## 3.9 AI Monetary Policy, Banks, and Competition

The Federal Reserve sets monetary policy to accelerate economic activity during downturns and avert overheating during expansions. Also, the Federal Reserve does not control the money supply directly relying on private banks to transfer its wanted monetary conditions to the broader economy.

The Federal Reserve motivates banks' behavior by adapting the interest rate it pays on banks' reserve balances and by purchasing and selling securities in the open market.<sup>43</sup> In addition, intensifying concentration in the banking sector unsettles the transmission of monetary policy because in uncompetitive markets, banks do not adjust their behavior in reaction to Federal Reserve policy alterations which means that monetary policy does not have its wanted outcome. Moreover, when the Federal Reserve loosens monetary policy to inspire economic activity, lenders in concentrated areas utilize their market power by keeping high-interest rates rather than passing on cheaper rates to borrowers. Consequently, banks capture bigger profits but, in the process, they hinder the Federal Reserve's objective of spurring borrowing and economic activity.<sup>44</sup> Additionally, when the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy to avert overheating, banks in concentrated areas utilize their market power by keeping their deposit rates rather than passing on higher interest rates to depositors. Furthermore, bank consolidation endangers competition by escalating risks to financial stability and so large bank mergers augment financial instability.<sup>45</sup> While the Dodd-Frank Act guided the banking agencies to think about financial stability in connection with merger applications, the agencies' appraisals to date have been primary. Additionally, the DOJ's bank merger framework disregards financial instability regardless of the threat that financial crises cause to competition. Speeding up bank concentration inhibits monetary policy transmission reducing the Federal Reserve's capacity to accelerate economic activity when conditions warrant.

It is worth noting that online-only financial corporations have occurred as competitors to traditional banks and so the expansion of these new financial corporations has stimulated endeavors to reduce the bank antitrust framework. To that extent, innovative financial technologies have altered the competitive dynamics of the banking sector and so digital financial service providers exhibit greater convenience and faster loan approvals. Hence, fintech corporations now command more than one-third of the personal loan market exceeding traditional banks.<sup>46</sup>

Fintech is doubtful to contest the anticompetitive outcomes of bank consolidation for the reason that digital financial services do not substitute for locally rooted banks.

The emergence of bitcoin and other crypto assets pressures the present perception of reference currencies, in which the public confidence gradually fades away as monetary policies standing behind them strive to excuse their “own low performance by euphemisms of non-conventional interference.” Also, the financial and banking sector is an area where AI applications are present and expanding.

New technologies and the globalization of the economy have facilitated tax avoidance through the shifting of profits by MNEs to low-tax jurisdictions. Hence, MNEs artificially transfer profits across borders and internalize these profit-shifting opportunities in their decision-making. In other words, the digitalization of world economies has empowered MNEs to utilize digital technologies to conveniently evade paying corporate income taxes by moving their profits from high-tax rate countries to low-tax rate countries.<sup>55</sup>

The emergence of cryptocurrency poses new and growing tax law challenges. To that extent, Jean Hindriks and Yukihiro Nishimura<sup>56</sup> argue that “low-tax countries may have a greater incentive to abandon enforcement cooperation in response to minimum tax... for intermediate tax differentials, the minimum tax can break down the enforcement cooperation making the high-tax countries (but not the low-tax countries) worse off.”

Strategic financial management is utilized in escalating profitability and market value of MNE via the implementation of long-term effective management of its assets and liabilities and so the role of strategic financial management is concentrating on augmenting the financial capacity of MNE which means its capability to use successfully its own financial resources and to attract debt capital. Consequently, the expansion and implementation of factors of financial strategy is grounded on the usage of methods of financial market forecasting. Thus, the central priorities in strategic financial management for MNE remain the globalization of its activities through foreign direct investment and international production encompassing AI technologies and networking.

## 3.11 Autonomous Private Money and Competition

Bitcoin is a private, decentralized digital currency, for which transactions are authenticated using cryptographic technologies. Unlike CBDC, private, centralized money produces income that stays in private hands and not the fiscal authorities.<sup>57</sup> It has to be taken into account that privately owned payment systems such as PayPal, M-Pesa, Alipay, and Square have acquired extensive popularity. Lately, cryptocurrencies, stablecoins, and decentralized finance have shown prospectively to broaden and disrupt the financial or monetary system. Moreover, countries and central banks around the globe develop their own digital currencies, markedly, Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs). CBDC is any widely held electronically recorded central bank liability available for transfer, whether recorded on a distributed ledger or a more conventional database. Moreover, CBDC is just one of many recent developments in payment technologies.

How do the emergence of cryptocurrencies and the development of CBDCs shape international currency competition? Does the quantity of private money represent an increase in the offered value by the economy? Does autonomous private money increase the quantity of money without any extra value produced in an economy? Is the issue of cryptocurrencies covered by value production? The cryptocurrency comprises an imperfect substitute for national currencies as a store of value or medium of exchange, yet it is not linked with a centralized government and undergoes fast advances in its technology comparative to other currencies. It has to be taken into account that the lack of strong national fiat currencies denotes a vacuum in the currency space which private cryptocurrencies fill. Prominently, the growth rate of cryptocurrency usage and convenience generates endogenously increase with adoption, giving rise to dynamic feedback and network effects. The cryptocurrency market has achieved extensive acceptance and so the digitization of money, via CBDC implementation, becomes manifest. The question is whether cryptocurrencies must be covered by a produced value in an economy because otherwise there will be a problem with value of the money.

It is characteristic that countries face competition from cryptocurrencies and other fiat currencies and their decisions to employ CBDCs are strategic. Thus, the United States and the US dollar benefit from regulation involving dollar stablecoins to be backed by US dollar reserves. The recent collapse of cryptocurrencies market denotes that cryptocurrencies cannot alter the role of money in an economy and the equitation of money and value of economy survives.

It has to be taken into consideration that government's objectives for the digitization of money have to do with an effort to boost the digital economy. Moreover, the digitization of money and cryptocurrencies are not parallel and the circulation of cryptocurrencies in parallel with fiat money has to follow the rules of monetary policy, etc. The economic implications of the issue of cryptocurrencies have to be examined.

<sup>57</sup> Maxi Guennewig, Currency Competition with Firms, Discussion Paper No. 378.

It is specified that “we are witnessing the birth of Bretton Woods III—a new world (monetary) order centered around commodity-based currencies in the East that will likely weaken the Eurodollar system and also contribute to inflationary forces in the West.”<sup>58</sup> Does money represent real value? The answer is no due to cryptocurrencies plus uncontrolled printing of money and there is an imbalance concerning the quantity of money on the market versus the value of economy.<sup>59</sup> Moreover, Zoltan Pozsar<sup>60</sup> argued that “commodities are collateral, and collateral is money, and this crisis is about the rising allure of outside money over inside money.” Thus, central banks have to cope with the inflationary shocks of the “commodities basis.”

Does the public currency lose its role as a medium of exchange due to cryptocurrencies and firms forming digital currency? The issue of electronic money by the central banks of different states following the monetary policy rules is different from the issue of cryptocurrencies regardless of any monetary policy rules and so producing a huge quantity of money regardless of any economic development and growth.

It has to be taken into account that in an economy with integrated international financial markets, monetary policymakers have the capacity to control their monetary tools to accomplish their objective. Also, having a global currency restricts central banks in pursuing their objectives by limiting the effect of their monetary policy instruments and so under competition with cryptocurrencies, the central bank can face some restrictions on interest rates and inflation if the government currency has to retain a role as a medium of exchange.<sup>61</sup> In addition, the role of money as a medium of exchange is altered by the uncontrolled issue of cryptocurrencies and CBDs. There is a need to investigate the effects of cryptocurrency competition with the international monetary system. To that extent, Pierpaolo Benigno et al.<sup>62</sup> argue that “the introduction of a globally used currency may substantially change the landscape of international monetary policy.” Furthermore, it has to be taken into consideration that even if a cryptocurrency token has no inherent or fundamental value, it may still attain a value role in an equilibrium as the unique token for permitting payments between agents.<sup>63</sup>

Moreover, cryptocurrencies are decentralized and so they are not issued or controlled by any government or other central authority which means that cryptocurrencies are managed by peer-to-peer networks running free, open-source software, known as the blockchain technology. In general, a central factor underlying cryptocurrencies is the mechanism of validating transactions in a decentralized way, with no central or trusted authority implicated. Furthermore, cryptocurrency is a digital representation of value that is widely used now to denominate the prices of goods or services and so operating as a “unit of account.” Hence, cryptocurrency is used to make payments and is subjectively recognized by the parties to a transaction as an alternative to legal tender and objectively treated as a “medium of exchange.” Thus, Bitcoin was envisioned from its outset to be used as a medium of exchange for financial transactions outside the domain of traditional institutions and government control. Likewise, Bitcoin is seen as a store of value as people put their savings in it and investors bet on its price, not mentioning that there are even financial products and derivatives that are connected to its price.

## 3.14 Crypto Assets, Cryptocurrencies, and Monetary Policy

As mentioned earlier, Bitcoin is a peer-to-peer electronic cash system enabling money in this cryptocurrency to be sent online, pseudonymously, and directly to a recipient without using a centralized intermediary, such as a bank. Currently, Bitcoin has transformed into an alternative hedge and safe haven for investors because of its speed in recovering from high volatilities which means that there is an allocation of investments in Bitcoin.<sup>103</sup> Moreover, Bitcoin's extreme rise has crushed investments in capital markets and commodity goods through altering investment decisions and managing investors' risks and so the explosive movement of Bitcoin has instigated instability in the capital market.<sup>104</sup> It is argued that placing Bitcoin as safe haven is very risky as a result of its speculative and zero fundamental nature and so possibly initiating an economic bubble in the future.

It has to be taken into account that cryptocurrencies are comprehended as an unambiguous challenge to perceived shortcomings in monetary policy and the existing monetary system due to Bitcoin price behavior underlining its large volatility and low connectivity to in actual fact any other traditional asset or macroeconomic activity. Cryptocurrencies have no inherent value and their perceived value is based largely on supply and demand in the market. Thus, monetary policy innovations by both the Fed and the ECB have a sizable influence on Bitcoin prices. Sören Karau<sup>105</sup> argues that “disinflationary euro area monetary policy shocks lead to a persistent fall in Bitcoin valuations, whereas inflationary central bank information shocks lead to a price increase. Conversely, I find a mirror image for US shocks: Bitcoin prices increase after the monetary contraction but fall following the expansionary central bank information shock.”

Crypto assets are a store of value which can be transferred or exchanged digitally and so they are intended to give individuals greater control over their finances, serving as a decentralized kind of electronic currency enabling peer-to-peer global transactions, without the input of a centralized authority such as a country or a bank. Moreover, crypto assets are a digital representation of value or contractual rights that

Crypto-assets transformed the prospective of decentralized systems in the financial sector. Augmenting popularity and high levels of market volatility have fostered the stakes of the digital asset experimentation. Prices of crypto-assets have been open to macroeconomic fundamentals such as monetary policy shocks and so they are exposed to liquidity risk. It has to be taken into account that creating a harmonized legal framework for crypto-assets results in greater legal certainty and so accelerating the adoption of crypto-assets in the EU financial services sector. To that extent, MiCA protects consumers against risks connected with the investment in crypto-assets and helps them avoid fraudulent schemes. With the new rules, crypto-asset service providers must follow strong obligations to protect consumers’ wallets and become liable in case they lose investors’ crypto-assets. Also, MiCA protects investors by augmenting transparency and putting in place a comprehensive framework for issuers and service providers embracing compliance with the anti-money laundering rules which means that this regulation safeguards financial stability, while tolerating innovation and promoting the attractiveness of the crypto-asset sector.<sup>112</sup> It is characteristic that MiCA backs innovation and fair competition, while safeguarding a high level of protection of retail holders and the integrity of markets in crypto-assets which means that crypto-asset service providers expand their businesses on a cross-border basis, expedite their access to banking services by empowering them to run their activities efficiently. Likewise, the act disallows insider dealing practices or use of inside information about crypto-assets to acquire, or dispose of, those crypto-assets, directly or indirectly, whether for that person’s own account or for the account of a third party.

## 3.15 Digitalization, DMA, MiCA, and Competition

It is worth mentioning here that the ongoing digitalization is leading to rapid transformations in the whole structure of the global economy. Two driving forces are obvious: first, digital platforms as the dominant business model, and second, an expanding role for intangible inputs such as data and software. Despite the fact that both pledge major productivity gains, warnings are growing that they also give rise to market power and enable anticompetitive practices.

It is argued that unregulated adoption of automation and AI leads to social, economic, and political harms by damaging competition, consumer privacy, and consumer choice, generating unduly automating work, accelerating inequality by pushing down wages, and deteriorating worker productivity. Thus, policies are required to tackle the side effects of digitalization by forwarding competition and market contestability building productivity against the background of increased market concentration. To that extent, the free entry of competitors is not only crucial to diminish monopoly rents but also to accelerate future technological advancement. Nevertheless, promoting competition in a world with fast-evolving technologies is demanding for regulators, principally since a coordinated cross-border regulation is required.

It has to be taken into account that a stable and sound regulatory framework promotes development and investment in AI technologies due to the fact that digital services are distinguished by a first-mover advantage and massive economies of scale magnetizing new entrants being a criterion for the creation of high-value-added jobs. Hence, the EU Digital Services Act is an essential step in this direction by simplifying the “start-up and scale-up” of digital services in Europe and so generating legal certainty, which offers security of investment against regulatory risks, and a common regulation effective throughout the EU, as only then the size advantages of the EU market are fully unleashed. It is worth noting that Microsoft is pushing ChatGPT to a new level by amalgamating it into its Copilot software, generating a “Chatpilot” being a software device for offering personalized assistance as part of various Microsoft applications.<sup>113</sup> Chatpilot might become a vital driver of innovation and efficiency, but it should also become a monitoring object for competition law enforcers and digital regulators because AI technologies might be used for anticompetitive activities allowing the controlling of the EU’s new Digital Markets Act (DMA) and general competition law in order to avoid being caught in contacting anticompetitive actions.

Digital markets are systematically well established by not many of the largest online platforms, which, as a result of a perfect mixture of their competence and luck, have monopolized most of the markets, transforming themselves into unescapable intermediaries, gatekeepers, contributing to consequently commissioning, shaping, charging, and handling each of the endless storms of digital transactions. It has to be taken into account that the strengthening of gatekeepers’ dominance<sup>114</sup> happens without a violation of ex post competition rules which means that once reaching their status as incumbents, these undertakings methodically control and outline the issues of competition without essentially engaging in any conduct prohibited by ex post competition law.

It has to be taken into consideration that DMA forwards the entrenched market positions of a small number of large digital 'gatekeeper' platforms by imposing a set of particular obligations that are planned to support both 'market contestability' and the 'fair treatment of business users' by these platforms. While large digital platforms have produced significant innovations and consumer benefits in the past, the existing concentration of market power is estimated to harm end users and business users, now and in the future.<sup>115</sup>

Does not competition law apply to big digital players? The gap between the entrenched systematically monopolized digital markets, on the one hand, and the available antitrust toolkits, on the other, indicates the obvious: the rules either must be fundamentally redesigned, or there is little sense in all the anticipation regarding the "new era" of digital competition policy at all. Of course, digital players have become big via AI technology which is supposed to function in an objective way adding to competition. On the other hand, an AI technology has to function objectively in order to be applicable in AI society run by AI humanoids which means that in case the functioning of AI and AI technologies is subjective, then the elite will have a new technology to implement its plans more effectively and decisively upon humans and their plans might include the elimination of people and their replacement with AI workers obeying and fulfilling the plans of a small elite on earth.

MiCA regulation sets rules for dealing with crypto assets in the EU and it is binding for all crypto assets that do not qualify as financial instruments, deposits, or structured deposits under the EU financial services legislation and that will be offered to EU consumers and investors or traded on an EU trading platform for crypto assets.<sup>116</sup> Moreover, the regulation is broad and covers the offerings and marketing of all crypto assets embracing utility tokens, asset-referenced tokens, e-money tokens, and the authorization and operation of crypto assets service providers. Furthermore, the central objectives of the regulation are to: offer legal certainty, maintain innovation, protect consumers and investors, and guarantee financial stability.

MiCA excludes new paradigms such as the DeFi (Decentralized Finance) industry and non-fungible tokens (NFT) and so MiCA leaves several components of the digital asset world outside its scope. Central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) also fall outside the scope of MiCA. Moreover, MiCA also sets conditions for crypto-asset issuers and crypto-asset service providers (CASP). Crypto-asset issuers must offer complete and transparent information about the crypto-assets they issue, and fulfil disclosure and transparency rules. Crypto-asset service providers must be registered and employ security ratios and anti-money laundering compliance.

Does MiCA regulation violate the principle of “technological neutrality”? It seems that MiCA regulation violates the principle of “technological neutrality” that establishes the core of the current e-money legislation, presenting doubts about whether a technically specific legislation for e-money tokens (EMTs) is required. Hence, departing from technologically neutral legislation initiates unnecessary complexity and so diminishing adaptability to future technological innovations by generating inconsistencies harming the businesses and customers that count on it. Furthermore, MiCA’s objective is to further innovation and makes certain fair competition. Fair competition denotes a condition where various companies compete on equal terms, without any unfair advantages or disadvantages. On the other hand, granting exclusive access to central bank deposit facilities to banks generates an uneven playing ground for other market participants competing with banks. Thus, banks’ privileged access to central banks’ deposit facilities grants a substantial competitive advantage and establishes unfair discrimination among market players which means that competitors not only have unequal access to the public resource of central bank deposit facilities, consequently infringing the equal access principle, but this also furthers augmented financial instability.<sup>117</sup> Additionally, the market will shift away from e-money tokens toward tokenized<sup>118</sup> commercial bank deposits as the preferred form of on-chain money as a result of banks’ access to central bank facilities. Likewise, banks will use their privileged access to central banks to engage in cartel-like behavior and crush external competition.<sup>118</sup>

It is worth noting that MiCA will make it highly difficult for small players to enter the crypto-asset market which means influencing competition in the market. Concerning MiCA, the regulation failed to realize the fact that the digital market is principally cross-boundary, meaning that a CASP in another jurisdiction who does not essentially intend to issue his tokens within the EU might have EU investors willing to invest. It could be said that MiCA prioritizes the protection of banks’ interests rather than advancing innovation and development in Europe and so its fragmentation undermines the current e-money legislation, setting antitrust concerns and escalating the prospective for financial instability. In other words, MiCA undermines its own objectives by backing particular market players rather than prioritizing the broader societal advantages of innovation and development in the European e-money token market.

## 4.1 Identifying Market Power

Market power is the capacity of a corporation facing little competition to boost its profits by cutting back on its output, either quantitatively or qualitatively. Moreover, while companies earn higher profits when they exercise market power, consumers undergo harm in the way of higher prices and/or diminished quality and so market power allows raising prices profitably by restricting output. On the other hand, market power occurs on the buyer side of the market, denoted as monopoly power, where a buyer exerting monopsony power holds back demand to drive down price and so augmenting its profits.<sup>1</sup> By the way, monopsony is the capability of buyers to dictate prices, working conditions and terms of employment that transfer some of the values generated by the employer–employee relationship to the employer. It could be said that monopsony power could diminish both consumer and aggregate welfare and so courts have denied holding monopsonists liable under Section 2 of the Sherman Act for harm to upstream sellers without convincing proof of consumer harm. The Supreme Court<sup>2</sup> found no violation when a plaintiff did not show a dangerous probability that monopsonist Weyerhaeuser could recoup from alleged predatory bidding on a key input by raising prices downstream and so the Court disallowed the premise that exercising monopsony power automatically harms downstream consumers as well as monopsonist suppliers.

It has to be taken into consideration that when economic power is concentrated, it damages not only economic freedom but also political freedom due to the fact that the rich and powerful utilize their resources to capture the government and swindle it in their favor which means that economic wealth shapes politics and politics

influence or form the law accordingly.<sup>3</sup> There was an effort of solving problems linked with the excessive power of large corporations<sup>4</sup> but regulations incorporate political imperfections permitting interest groups to control markets for their own advantage.

It could be said that regulators may advance immediately effective rules prohibiting dominant corporations from exercising their market power. Moreover, the principal limitation of ex ante conduct rules is that they often produce costly errors for the reason that the planners endorsing generally applicable, resource-allocating directives outside a specific, examinable factual context lack the information required to ascertain in advance which precise behaviors will diminish market output and which will augment it.

It is worth noting that markets may steadily fail to allocate resources in a manner that produces as much value as possible for the members of the society. To that extent, government interventions to correct instances of market failure might not take place as well. Thomas A. Lambert<sup>5</sup> argues that “Ex ante conduct rules are faster and more determinate, but they are more likely to generate high error costs because planners lack the information they need to determine, in advance and for a wide variety of actors, what behaviors will enhance or reduce social welfare.”

Again, digital markets currently feature a dominant provider such as Google for Internet search, YouTube for hosting user-generated videos, Amazon for online retailing, Google’s suite of advertising technology services for buying and selling digital advertisements, Facebook for social networking, and Apple’s and Google’s proprietary app stores for their particular mobile operating systems (iOS and Android) which means that the lack of competition in these markets has resulted in predictable market-power damages embracing higher prices and decreased quality. Presently, monopoly has generated supra-competitive prices for mobile-app distribution and digital-advertising services.

It is argued that monopolies drive evolution for the reason that the monopoly profits stipulate a powerful motivation to innovate which means that monopolies are innovating since profits empower them to make the long-term plans and to finance research projects that companies locked in competition cannot consider.

Customarily, governments have employed means to address market power concerns such as antitrust law remedying the circumstances in which market competition breaks down by collusion and monopoly.<sup>6</sup> Nowadays, Sherman Antitrust Act § 1 forbids agreements that “unreasonably” restrain trade, and § 2 prevents unreasonably exclusionary conduct generating market power. To that extent, in all cases, the reasonableness of a challenged act turns on its apparent impact on market output

Antitrust laws are meant to protect sellers and workers. Also, antitrust laws are intended to prevent harmful accumulations of market power implied from the seller's possession of a predominant share of the market but under current merger policy, the burden is on enforcers to make the case that merging corporations will possibly lessen competition and so resulting in lax merger review and uncontested large-scale acquisitions. To that extent, the Supreme Court has rationalized that underlying market power is the capacity to compel a purchaser to do something that he would not do in a competitive market.<sup>16</sup> Thus, the offense of monopoly under 15 U.S.C. § 2 has two components: first, the possession of monopoly power in the relevant market; and second, the willful acquisition or maintenance of that power as distinguished from growth or development as a consequence of a superior product.

Moreover, labor-market concentration utilizes downward pressure on wages and stimulates employers to shift the costs of training onto workers which means that greater inequality<sup>17</sup> among corporations hiring in a labor market arises.<sup>18</sup>

## 4.2 Antitrust and Politics

It is argued that, in enacting the antitrust laws, Congress made a political pick regarding the desirability of market competition and the undesirability of particular conduct harmful to it. Zingales<sup>19</sup> observes that concentration<sup>20</sup> levels in most industries have increased and so augmenting the capacity to collect supra-competitive rents which makes it easier to organize and lobby for laws and policies that will safeguard this rent collection capacity. Moreover, Ariel Katz<sup>21</sup> argues “that unchecked private economic power may be as injurious to individual freedom and other liberal values as unchecked political power, and that the two may be mutually constitutive.” It is characteristic that the Chicago School insisted that antitrust law could only be legitimately concerned with maximizing economic efficiency. It seems that antitrust law was always concerned not only with the economic aspects of competition but also with the connection between market competition and politics via the implementation of demands of the law.

The increasing power of computational technology has intertwined antitrust policy with international politics and national security. Electronic technology has augmented the ways of attack and altered traditional weapons of war. Thus, innovations in hardware and software have launched new techniques of espionage and cyberwarfare such as cyber propaganda, trolling, and sophisticated hacking and so technological acceleration has led to an international battle for technological supremacy generating a “technology cold war.”<sup>22</sup>

Risks of devious applications of AI for influencing public opinion and electoral interference need attention. When AI is in the hands of oppressive governments or unethically operating corporations, AI can be utilized for political gain, exploitation, and weakening of political freedom.

Antitrust regulation of technology is central to the economy because it is altering the future of the tech industry and having domino effects on sectors from healthcare and manufacturing to transportation and energy. It could be said that the undermining of antitrust as a check on concentrated private power has caused economic inequality.<sup>23</sup> Besides, boosting efficiency is not the single objective of

<sup>23</sup> Lina Khan & Sandeep Vaheesan, *Market Power and Inequality: The Antitrust Counterrevolution and Its Discontents*, 11 Harv. L. & Pol'y Rev. 235 (2017).

antitrust and identifying economic freedom but fairness is an additional desirable purpose. In addition, exercises of power by large companies operate as structures of private governance which means that antitrust law and policy must be a key means of democracy reforming.

It seems that antitrust has become much more technical, predominantly in subjects such as merger enforcement and exclusionary behavior, but also in more collateral matters such as judging causation and calculating damages.<sup>24</sup> Thus, due to the fact that its technical competence has amplified, its “movement” quality has declined and becomes a political matter and so technical antitrust has become less stimulating to politicians, who cannot win elections by talking about Indexes or average variable cost.

It has to be taken into consideration that laws organizing the economy, involving antitrust, should be concentrated on preventing economic domination. It seems that antitrust law is at its best a device for verifying the power of dominant corporations. On the one hand, competition cannot be reduced to its result such as allocative efficiency. On the other hand, competition has to be an instrument of dispersion of economic and political power which means that there can be no efficiency without free competition.

It is worth mentioning here that the Chicago School transferred the analytical emphasis away from the process required for competition<sup>25</sup> and towards an outcome such as consumer welfare. On the other hand, a valuable process concerning competition implementation results in competitive outcomes for the whole economy and subsequently to players of the markets such as consumers and customers.

It is worth noting that competition law's purpose ought to be to stimulate and protect a political economy offering a society's best amalgam of competition and cooperation, in view of its culture, history, technology, and political situation at a given period of time.<sup>26</sup>

Fox<sup>27</sup> advocates that antitrust law preserves the competitive process by maintaining the incentives generating productive, dynamic, and market efficiency which means that welfare, in the form of total welfare rather than just consumer welfare, encapsulates the priorities of competition law via the protection of the process of competition due to the fact that digital markets involve harms that are not portrayed by the welfare criterion but are clarified on the grounds of harm to the process of competition.

It is worth noting that corporations with market power can damage competition over a significant period for the reason that the marketplace finally will undercut the success of any anticompetitive restraints as consumers change to substitutes or new companies enter the market.<sup>28</sup> On the other hand, markets do not always respond as quickly as scholars assume because of market inactivity and information failures, a business can hamper competition over some period of time. An original objective of federal antimonopoly legislation was to promote fair competition and business practices, and to furnish a check on emerging consolidations of economic power in both inter- and intra-company arrangements.<sup>32</sup> There is a positive correlation between concentration and profits but concentration may mark superior efficiency rather than a lack of competition. In addition, consumer welfare cannot be the only criterion, as it does not capture all the damage to competition.

It is argued that the dominant technology companies hurt consumers, laborers, and small businesses by contributing to wealth inequality by earning monopoly profits for their shareholders and so excessive political power that undermines democracy.<sup>34</sup> To that extent, governments have used several different methods restricting welfare losses from market power such as antitrust law aiming at averting the creation or enhancement of market power by means other than competition on the merits. certain exercises of market power and promoting market competition. The state possesses the right to use means such as antitrust law in order to achieve its objectives translated into implementation of competition.<sup>35</sup>

It is worth noting that under the effective-competition standard, antitrust policy would protect individuals, consumers, workers, and others throughout the supply chain, but would also concentrate on upholding opportunities for competitors, stimulating individual autonomy and well-being, and de-concentrating private power. Hence, the protection-of-competition test examines consumer welfare harms,<sup>36</sup> but the ultimate concern would be “distortion or suppression of the competitive process.”

Again, antitrust does not prohibit the creation, maintenance, or improvement of market power by procompetitive means such as innovation or gains in productive efficiency and so it does not forbid a company that has acquired market power legitimately from exercising that power by charging supra-competitive prices. In other words, the simple possession of monopoly power, and the parallel charging of monopoly prices, is not only legal but also it is an imperative part of the free-market system. To that extent, in order to safeguard the motivation to innovate, the possession of monopoly power is not unlawful except if it is accompanied by an element of anticompetitive conduct.<sup>37</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that the accumulative concentration of market power has both a conceivable impact on efficiency by preventing prospective competitors from investing and from innovating but also on the vigor of democracy due to the fact that the higher the financial risks connected with adverse political choices, the higher the capability and the incentives to invest for utilizing an effect on political power.

Antitrust policy is a device in a complex global economy and political landscape being utilized in the context of a state's overall international policies and goals. National security is entangled with antitrust policy. In addition, antitrust law has always marked foreign policy being evident in the various international antitrust organizations and agreements in existence. Enforcement decisions have political and economic consequences for countries globally. Nonetheless, antitrust law plays a vital role in international politics nowadays as a result of the rise of technology not mentioning the emergence of AI and AAI. Thus, technology has transformed foreign intelligence and espionage and so countries have struggled for control of the technology industry instigating “the technology cold war.” Many countries such as the United States, Russia, and China have used antitrust regulation to advance their status in this technology war. Consequently, technological advancement necessitates

Competition law has to remain law regulating the equality of companies in looking for customers and not becoming a tool in the hands of politics. concentrations of immense power are indispensable components of democratic development. ## 4.3 AI Technologies and Labor

It has to be taken into account that greater globalization lets successful entrepreneurs grow their profits more rapidly and so putting further upward pressure on income inequality which means that when economies of scale are present, the integration of global markets results in a growing concentration of the market power among a few

<sup>43</sup> Zekos G, 'Internet or Electronic Technology: A Threat to State Sovereignty', Commentary 1999 (3) The Journal of Information, Law and Technology (JILT). <http://elj.warwick.ac.uk/jilt/99-3/zekos.html>. New citation as at 1/1/04: [http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/law/elj/jilt/1999\\_3/zekos/](http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/soc/law/elj/jilt/1999_3/zekos/)

worldwide leaders. To that extent, concentration is very salient in the case of IT enterprises such as Amazon or Alphabet, but also in other zones in which digital innovation is crucial, embracing pharmaceuticals or automobiles. Even though sometimes rental fees from innovation are shared with the workers, the labor share has lessened more in states with more digital innovation and innovative sectors with more market concentration.

Likewise, AI is a general-purpose technology influencing work in almost every occupation. Automation, involving AI-enabled automation, influences overall aggregate employment and aggregate wages, along with the wage and employment distribution. Moreover, new technology developments abolish jobs by automating tasks (displacement effect) or by complementing human labor which means permitting for a more flexible allocation of tasks and intensifying productivity (productivity effect) and so, in turn, contributing to amplified demand for labor in non-automated tasks. Also, some tasks and jobs are being replaced but new tasks and jobs are generated either owing to innovation or due to old technologies becoming so cheap that their demand starts rising and so facing the well-known “reinstatement effect.” Furthermore, there are several indirect means that act across industries such as the spillover effects, either by increases in productivity transmitted across businesses through the intermediate inputs or by upturns in incomes that generate higher aggregate demand. In other words, upsurges of automation and new technology have been convoyed with concern regarding the future of jobs and with fears about labor becoming redundant.

It has to be taken into consideration that there is an urgent need to improve the productivity outcomes from the digital economy, particularly through the completion of the Single Digital Market in EU.<sup>44</sup> AI coupled with analytics presents greater focus and contextual insights, permitting both technical and non-technical workers to function more competently. To that extent, G.I. Zekos considers that the current AI forces workers to become more skillful but not eliminating human work but the forthcoming AAI technology implemented by humanoids will put humanity in danger/jeopardy of its existence as a type of entity on earth because any autonomy of humanoids acting in a better way than humans mean no need of humans to exist according to the material concept of existence.

It is worth noting here that automation diminishes the labor share of value added as capital and so replacing labor. Simultaneously, automation augments a corporation's productivity and demand for labor expressed as a productivity effect. AI technologies generate new duties in which labor has a comparative advantage, altering the task content of workers, and escalating labor share and demand and so there is a disparity between technological prospective and its actual implementation for the reason that some technologies take time to circulate in industries. Moreover, workers do not stay inactive, but they learn new skills and adapt their set of duties in reply to automation showing worker flexibility which means that the introduction of

<sup>44</sup>Stefania Albanesi, António Dias da Silva, Juan F. Jimeno, Ana Lamo, Alena Wabitsch, New technologies and jobs in Europe, ECB Working Paper Series No 2831.

new technology augments the necessity for labor because of complementarity to the new tasks and improvement in corporation productivity. Thus, digital transformation fosters the requirement for highly cognitive and non-routine tasks, benefitting high-wage workers, and intensifying polarization and inequality. AI software and robots have displaced low- and medium-skilled workers. In this manner, while investment in digital technologies produces new economic opportunities, digital transformation stimulates reshoring. Will AAI technology and AAI humanoid robots eliminate human workers? Of course, in an AAI society, human labor will be replaced by AAI humanoid robots' labor.

It has to be taken into account that AI is a prediction technology, and predictions are at the heart of decision-making under uncertainty, making AI applicable to resolve a range of business problems with opposing prospective consequences on labor. On the one hand, corporations employ AI to automate certain duties by relocating labor and contributing to the ongoing trends of deskilling. On the other hand, investments in AI have been linked with product innovation demanding complementary investments which means that investments in AI are correlated with key alterations in corporations' labor composition and organization. Also, AI investments accumulate increasingly over time causing impacts that are not immediate, making the long-differences strategy well-suited for company venues in the AI era.<sup>45</sup> Nonetheless, failures of AI technologies causing harm undermine trust in such technologies impeding their development and use which means that AAI systems have to solve problems of malfunction of AI.

## 4.4 Labor and Antitrust

Antitrust enforcement has focused on anticompetitive conduct directed against downstream purchasers, not workers. It is representative that competition authorities have supposed that labor markets are rather competitive and that labor monopsony power is a comparatively infrequent phenomenon.

It seems that the Sherman Act was intended to treat combinations of capital and combinations of labor in the same manner. Hence, the Sherman Act's more general coverage and Section 7 of the Clayton Act, which applies to mergers, already ban the relevant anticompetitive outcomes in all markets by applying equally to sellers and purchasers, embracing purchasers of labor.<sup>46</sup> It could be said that the question is not about antitrust immunity for antitrust violations committed by labor, but rather about labor protection from antitrust violations committed by employers. Moreover, the

<sup>45</sup> Agraval, Ajay K., Joshua S. Gans, and Avi Goldfarb, "AI Adoption and System-Wide Change," Working Paper 28811, National Bureau of Economic Research May 2021. Series: Working Paper Series.

<sup>46</sup> Todd v. Exxon Corp., 275 F.3d 191, 195 (2d Cir. 2001). State by Raoul v. Elite Staffing, Inc., No. 1-21-0840, 2022 WL 1819541, at \*1 (Ill. App. Jun. 3, 2022) (applying an Illinois antitrust act to condemn a horizontal anti-poaching agreement under the per se rule).

anticompetitive behaviors embrace horizontal wage-fixing and anti-poaching agreements, along with vertical noncompeting agreements restraining employee mobility and mergers that have output-limiting results in both product and labor markets.<sup>47</sup>

In both North America and Europe, competition policy has focused on safeguarding well-functioning product markets and on capturing conduct on the supply side of the market.<sup>48</sup> Regardless that the EU and the US Horizontal Merger Guidelines stipulate for the application of competition law to both sides of the market, the basis of application is given on how the analysis should be performed in downstream markets. It is worth mentioning here that in the European Union, the EU competition rules are grounded on Article 3(3) of the Treaty on European Union, which stimulates “a highly competitive social market economy, aiming at full employment and social progress.” Also, in the European Union, no formal obstacle exists to recognize harm to workers as a standalone anticompetitive harm.

It could be said that anticompetitive conduct by employers colluding qualifies as “by object” under EU competition law embracing wage fixing, no-poach, no-solicitation agreements, as well as exchange of commercially sensitive information. Article 101 of the TFEU does not currently capture non-competes for the reason that they are concluded by the workers and the employers. The Court of Justice of the European Union has embraced that collective bargaining agreements between employers and workers adjusting salaries and other working conditions do not infringe EU competition law.<sup>49</sup> The European Commission has published guidelines to address this issue, noting that collective negotiation and bargaining between certain categories of “solo self-employed” and their counterparties is explicitly permitted.<sup>50</sup>

It has to be taken into account that the EU courts have never explicitly adopted the enhancement of consumer welfare as the main aim of EU competition law but the EU plainly stated that, in buyer power cases, it intervenes when the merger notably impedes competition, including by protecting the competitive process, “even if it cannot be demonstrated that such reduction of competition affects consumer welfare.”<sup>51</sup>

It has to be taken into account that managers need to be informed of the prospective of AI for boosting productivity and so increasing labor productivity by complementing human labor and automating specific tasks. Dirk Czarnitzki et al.<sup>53</sup> found that “employing AI technologies has a positive and significant impact on firm productivity. In particular, we showed that both the use of AI and the intensity with which firms exploit the potentials of AI significantly increases both sales and valued-added. This effect remains robust after controlling for several technological features of the firm.”

Does antitrust accommodate capital and control labor? It is worth mentioning here that antitrust has contributed to the increasing imbalance of power between employers and workers due to the fact that antitrust has legalized vertical restraints, permitting the economy's most powerful players to closely direct and supervise the behavior of less-powerful players and, second, antitrust has been used by those same powerful players to prevent less-powerful players from organizing and managing on their own behalf against such concentrations of power. Taking into account that antitrust harm in labor markets is independently actionable means that proving an unlawful restraint in a labor market does not necessitate independent proof of harm in the related product market. Clayton Act outlaws tying and exclusive dealing and explicitly applies only to sellers or lessors.<sup>54</sup> Nonetheless, tying and exclusive dealing are condemned under both provisions of the Sherman Act, which apply to buyers and sellers alike.<sup>55</sup>

Likewise, the court ruled that it cannot be exercised de facto control over “independent business men,” in contravention of the antitrust laws generating a sharp distinction and a comprehensive delineation between the realm of labor and antitrust: if subordinate entities are “independent business men” and not employees, it is illegal to exercise control.<sup>58</sup> Thus, the deployment of independent contractor status for workers, not just for the independent businesses who employ them, makes each individual worker an independent business, and so discarding of any protections under labor law.

The antitrust separation of workers from lead corporations is the erosion in the jurisprudence of the Sherman Act’s prohibitions on vertical restraints. It has to be taken into account that a vertical restraint is a contractual provision of operation inhibiting the autonomy of the counterparty in the case where each party activates at a distinct segment of the supply chain. Hence, if a contract imposes that the final retail price is vertical price-fixing and so other vertical restraints embrace the varieties of exclusive practices that suppliers might impose on their affiliated dealers or distributors, like compulsory purchase contracts—known as full-line forcing or requirements contracts.<sup>59</sup> It is worth mentioning here that calming<sup>60</sup> the law of vertical restraints is part of an overall allocation of coordination rights in which domination is preferred over cooperation as long as consumers are reaping the gains by the domination.

It could be said that the erosion of antitrust in the direction of tolerating vertical price- and non-price restraints has actually legalized labor outsourcing, misclassification, and the gig economy resulting in dominant corporations having access to a wider range of profitable business models that exert greater power and control over workers than they once did. Essentially, antitrust is increasing the power of the economy’s most powerful players instead of imposing fair competition. Besides, G.I. Zekos considers that high-quality goods and services at the lower possible price in the market should be the basis of competition regardless of the number of corporations in a free entrance market. The employment of AI and the forthcoming AAI should lead to an objective fair competition in trade against the current preference of the legally imposed competition in implementing the interests of capital via big corporations.

## 4.6 Bank Antitrust

There are increasing levels of AI technology implementation and financial investment.<sup>98</sup> AI in banking is maturing, bringing the prospective for higher-complexity solutions and so as AI gets popularity in banking, financial institutions (FIs) are building on their existing solutions to solve gradually multifaceted challenges. Certain AI use cases have acquired prominence across banks' operations, with chatbots in the front office and anti-payments fraud in the middle office as the most mature.

It is worth mentioning here that AI could be both useful and dangerous due to the fact that AI works by absorbing and analyzing data, picking up on patterns, and then predicting what comes next. To that extent, AI can be utilized in creating letters to require taxpayers to take certain actions like handing over personally identifying data or paying over assets and so there are AI-generated scams such as phishing and other fraud techniques.<sup>99</sup>

Banks use AI to change the customer experience but AI in banking applications is not just limited to retail banking services. Hence, the back and middle offices of investment banking and all other financial services for that matter are promoted from AI. AI is also being employed by banks within middle-office functions to evaluate risks, detect and prevent payment fraud, and advance processes for anti-money
