## 5.2 The Rule of Reason Competition Approach

It is worth noting that a rule-of-reason case is so costly to try which means that it is expected that fewer antitrust violations will be challenged. Is there a need to subject virtually all antitrust-relevant conduct to what antitrust calls the rule of reason? It has to be taken into consideration that the rule impedes a court from condemning conduct violating the antitrust laws until the court is convinced that the challenged conduct damages consumers in the specific case at issue. Hence, it could be said that the rule of reason is a license to engage in case-by-case adjudication.<sup>6</sup> In other words, whether a transaction unduly restrains trade is decided by the courts, on a case-by-case basis, using a rule of reason that judges all relevant elements in assessing a defendant's purpose in fulfilling the restraint and the restraint's upshot on competition.<sup>7</sup>

It has to be taken into account that courts cannot apply the rule of reason without a precise definition of the relevant market because without a definition of the market, there is no way to determine the party's capacity to diminish or abolish competition.<sup>8</sup> Consequently, the relevant market is defined as “the area of effective competition” and so identifying the ground within which noteworthy substitution in consumption or production happens which means that the relevant market corresponds to the commercial realities of the business.<sup>9</sup>

To that extent, the adoption of the rule of reason has led to the policy of diminished enforcement advocated by the Chicago School approach and so every time the Court judges some practice that would ordinarily violate the antitrust laws in itself, and rulings affecting consumers must be considered in every case before liability can attach which means that the Court has not advanced the correctness of

<sup>6</sup> Cal. Dental Ass'n v. FTC, 526 U.S. 756, 779 (1999) (describing rule of reason analysis as requiring “plenary market examination”).

Furthermore, after the Court added the recoupment requirement to predatory pricing claims demanding courts to take into consideration the long-term effects for consumers of below-cost pricing, enforcers all but stopped bringing cases. In addition, owing to the complexity of winning a case, the US government seldom brings predatory pricing claims.<sup>11</sup> It is worth noting that a criterion in holding a competitor liable under the antitrust laws for charging low prices is a manifestation that the competitor had a reasonable prospect, or, under § 2 of the Sherman Act, a critical probability, of recouping its investment in below-cost prices. In addition, the Supreme Court held that Brooke had failed to prove competitive injury as a matter of law and so stating that the evidence did not prove that Brown and Williamson had a reasonable possibility of recovering its losses from its alleged below-cost pricing scheme in decelerating the growth of the generic market.<sup>12</sup>

It is worth noting here that the per se rule states that an agreement is assumed to be illegal and anticompetitive if it falls within the broad parameters of the statute such as price-fixing agreements between the competitors which are regarded to be illegal<sup>13</sup> and so corporations and the market know from the beginning which acts are illegal leading to anticompetitive outcomes and consequently competition is preserved in advance in a way. On the other hand, rule of reason means investigating whether the said agreement is legal or not and so placing emphasis on the necessity for inquiry before regarding the said act to be illegal<sup>14</sup> and so corporations firstly act and afterward authorities are investigating the results of their activities which means having an impact on competition which afterward has to be corrected in case of anticompetitive results. It is distinctive that the per se Rule finds its roots in the Harvard school of thought and the Rule of Reason finds its roots in the Chicago School of thought.<sup>15</sup>

It could be said that the rule of reason presumption means that the Court will force a per se rule of illegality only when the conduct is so apparently harmful to

When conduct is explicitly harmful, the rule of reason necessitates that the conduct be rebuked without further inquiry, and so creating the notion that the conduct is subject to a per se rule of illegality. Correspondingly, when conduct is unequivocally good for consumers, the rule of reason necessitates that the Court abstain from condemning the conduct, without further inquiry, and so generating the notion that the conduct is per se legal.

Additionally, it could be argued that the rule of reason is the root of "antitrust's 40-year enforcement winter" and so the Court has to embrace burden-shifting frameworks compelling defendants to prove the absence of harm to consumers which means that enforcers have the burden of proving the presence of harm themselves.<sup>18</sup> In other words, the Court must either accept the Chicago view that competition is the enemy of growth, or reject it, and begin ruling conduct per se illegal again. To that extent, Chicago School assumes that situations of overwhelming dominance are no longer deemed a problem, and the implementation of antitrust rules must be based on efficiency, irrespective of any concerns linked to the competitive structure on the relevant market.

Judge Learned Hand<sup>19</sup> had stated that antitrust law seeks to "put an end to great aggregations of capital because of the hopelessness of the individual before them". Likewise, Robert Bork<sup>20</sup> recommends the maximization of consumer welfare as the only principle for competitive decision-making which is endorsed by the Schor v Abbott Labs judgment of the 7th Cir. in 2007<sup>21</sup>: "If a manufacturer cannot make itself better off by injuring consumers through lower output and higher prices, there is no role for antitrust law to play."

It has to be taken into consideration that the use of an economic approach is projected to augment legal certainty for the authority in charge of enforcing competition rules and so the effects-based approach was seen as the only way to enforce

competition laws efficiently.<sup>22</sup> Moreover, the consumer welfare test embraces issues of welfare distribution, while the total welfare<sup>23</sup> test concentrates only on efficiency, disregarding any consideration of the distribution of welfare. To that extent, the Chicago approach focuses on ‘consumer welfare’ supposing to promote “efficiency”, resulting in low prices for consumers.

Additionally, it has to be taken into account that while the Chicago School debates for the robustness of markets and the requirement for minimal regulatory interventions, the Harvard School focuses on the institutional limitations concerning adjusting even real market failures.<sup>24</sup> Thus, the two schools cultivate comparable noninterventionist results.

It is characteristic that applying the ‘consumer welfare’ standard denotes that a merger is anticompetitive if it upsets the competitive procedure harming free trading which means that the consumer welfare standard lets regulators and courts to concentrate on long-term transformations requiring economic analysis in order to prove the likelihood of market power at some later date.

## 5.4 Cartels and Competition

Is it acceptable a degree of diminishing of “competition”? It has to be taken into account that the antitrust laws speak of the conduct they prohibit in unmistakably economic terms, such as “restraint of trade,” “monopoly,” and diminishing of “competition.” To that extent, Hovenkamp<sup>34</sup> considers that the Chicago School movement attractiveness was not the belief of less enforcement notwithstanding of the facts, but rather the idea of handling economics to analyze business conduct in an effort to capitalize on social welfare which in fact might nullify the rationale of competition in many occasions in favor of fulfilling the interests of capital.

US antitrust law rests on a central distinction between restraints that are ancillary to legitimate productive business ventures or transactions, and those that are the result of a naked,<sup>35</sup> cartelistic restraint on competition that generates, allocates, and/or manipulates market power. It has to be taken into consideration that most cartels are per se illegal, but courts have refused to condemn some. Moreover, cartels are generally illegal regardless of their effect on consumer welfare, and this still dominates much of antitrust but this is resulting in a lack of consistency in the subsequent antitrust standards. Most of cases implicate a cartel that is subject to oversight by a public agency and so applying some form of preemption based on state or federal law or constitutional provisions.<sup>36</sup>

Are competition exceptions an innovation to bypass real competition and fulfilling the interest of some elite? The question to be answered is what factors explain why some cartels can be legal, but the vast majority is not. Most cases encompass express exemptions from antitrust law found in federal statutes,<sup>37</sup> constitutional protections, and state action immunities. ## 5.6 Platforms and Competition

A digital platform is a website, app, or other digital setting networking commercially with one or more groups of users.<sup>61</sup> Platforms that sell solely digital content do not characteristically have serious capacity constraints on their products. Regardless that a platform is digital, not all of its output is inevitably digital, but platforms such as Facebook, Google Search, Spotify, and Netflix produce digital content almost exclusively.

Antitrust law has proved to be an adaptive device and the great challenge for antitrust in the twenty-first century is to develop remedies to oversee digital platforms. Ross Levine et al.<sup>62</sup> argue that competition enforcement does indeed promote innovation. Platforms’ monopolies build on not on a single IP right but on a package of exclusive rights ranging from patents on software to network infrastructure, supply infrastructure, and from trade contractual relationship. Moreover, any monopoly must be restricted in scope and duration to safeguard competition.

The activities of big corporations in the digital economy today raise noteworthy competition concerns but it is not proven that they directly harm end-users or result

To that extent, if a platform is not a natural monopoly, competition should be both feasible and required.

It is worth noting that businesses classified as containing natural monopoly activities form 10% or more of economic activity embracing electricity and gas, public transport, ports, post, telecommunications, rail, water, and waste and are politically significant. Furthermore, markets generating a single winner are generally ones where economies of scale, network results, or the demand for interoperability back a single format managed by a single private company. Moreover, qualities that make the appearance or upholding of a single technology winner less likely to embrace interoperability or pooling of indispensable information or data. Hence, Androids, iPhones, and other cellular phones interconnect, facilitating users to engage in a full range of communications with one another.

The Supreme Court<sup>75</sup> states that only platforms compete against other platforms and so American Express did not compete with alternatives such as cash or debit cards for the reason that its anti-steering rule did not apply to these products. In fact, the court held that the two companies do not compete, as a matter of law, because two-sided platforms can only compete with other two-sided platforms.<sup>76</sup> Also, it is argued that normally only horizontal restraints qualify as unreasonable per se and so restraints that are not unreasonable per se are assessed under the rule of reason, which necessitates courts to conduct a fact-specific assessment of market power and market structure in judging the restraint’s actual impact on competition which means that the objective is to extricate between restraints with anticompetitive outcome that

Uber was prevented from charging a price significantly higher than its costs due to competition from taxicab companies. Will Uber and Lyf drive traditional taxis out of the market? It is not clear due to the fact that taxicab companies will adopt technologies that make them more competitive with multi-homing customers. Nonetheless, antitrust policy unavoidably looks at shorter or middle runs, so what counts is the extent of substitution now and whether a particular two-sided platform competes with a more traditional market is one of fact, not of law. Thus, DOJ has to prove that a proposed transaction would harm competition in a properly defined relevant antitrust market.<sup>77</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that even if costs drop constantly as output increases or network consequences are large, a digital platform is still not automatically a natural monopoly. Product differentiation is an element of competition and so even though a natural monopolist can eliminate a rival with an identical product merely by charging a competitive price, the differentiated entrant faces a different demand permitting new entry even against a much larger incumbent. Hence, railroads faced noteworthy competition from trucking, and AT&T's competition for its traditional landlines came from wireless technology providers. Moreover, concerning digital platforms, Facebook displaced MySpace, not by merely going head-to-head with a noticeably identical product, but rather by presenting a set of inter-member communication services that MySpace lacked. It could be said that the most substantial competitive pressures to Facebook Blue will come from differentiated products that offer users a distinctive way of interacting with friends and family for which Facebook Blue is not adjusted. Thus, Facebook is pushing the technology to do anything users want.

To that extent, the capacity of corporations to differentiate their goods or services at least partly rationalizes the dominant platform strategy of buying up nascent digital companies. Moreover, these acquisitions are not simply horizontal but rather fall into the category of “product extension” mergers, which are acquisitions expanding the variety of products or services that the acquiring company offers. Hence, there is an attempt either to gain product differentiation or to cut off efforts by others to develop differentiated alternatives. Therefore, antitrust policy regarding startup acquisitions becomes relevant.

Large platforms such as Facebook, Amazon, or Google preserve their positions by buying up all of the prospective challengers before they develop into more formidable rivals. Thus, the systematic platform acquisitions of tech startups prevent the eventual emergence of substantial rivals and not producing price increases or innovation reductions in the short run by facilitating collusion in the post-merger

There is a need of evidencing a probability of substantially lessened competition.<sup>79</sup> It is worth noting here that the court specified<sup>80</sup> that the competitor integration policy limits only how canvas apps on Facebook operate, and leaves app developers entirely free to develop applications for Facebook's competitors. Moreover, the States' exclusive dealing theory fails as a matter of law and an exclusive dealing claim to survive a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs must effectively assert that the exclusive contract "caused substantial market foreclosure."<sup>81</sup> Here, the States proclaimed only that the competitor integration policy "discouraged developers from creating apps that bridged" but not that this policy substantially foreclosed Facebook's competitors.

Competition problems in digital platforms present some novel encounters and antitrust law can handle them which means that courts and other antitrust policy makers should treat digital platforms as corporations that have unique qualities, but not so unique needing the abandonment of what we know about competition in high-technology and product-differentiated markets.

On the one hand, competition is being impaired by restricting consumers' freedom of choice. On the other, harm to competition takes the form of harm to innovation which means that access to technological channels can be closed off by the platform and so causing damage to dynamic effectiveness. To that extent, once a platform "controls" the innovation dynamics of its complementors, it can diminish the reasons and capacities to develop disruptive innovations which mean that the impairment to innovation damages the velocity of innovation and composition. Assumed the market power that platforms possess and their potentially irreversible character means that the criterion of consumer welfare concerning competition has to remain by affixing particular considerations regarding labor tradition. Consequently, it is no matter of talking merely damage to consumer welfare but tackling prospective harm to effective competition. Hence, the lawfulness of dominant corporations' practices must be evaluated not by their net influence on consumer welfare but upon the substance of fair competition which influences consumer affairs.

In fact, the scale of damages is considerably broader by reducing the prospective for the development of startups, amplified inequalities, privacy problems, growing fake news, among others. Therefore, it is more a matter of regulating the economic power of specific companies than an issue of defending competition. Furthermore, it

Again, the advancement of digital markets itself lawfully augments the scope of competitive concerns and so the growth of the platform economy amalgamates the competitive reasoning concerns under other branches of law such as consumer law since the users of the platforms are private individuals, which is also the case of contract law. Nowadays, digital platforms serve as indispensable facilities for the digital economy. Moreover, platforms leverage their exclusive control over search engines, e-commerce platforms, and app stores to bar rivals from markets for digital content, goods, and services by this means harming consumers and suppressing innovation. Also, forming and protecting monopolies, via exclusive rights or otherwise, can incentivize innovation. Conversely, any monopoly must be controlled in scope and duration to safeguard competition.

It is argued that platforms abuse their power by disregarding and discerning against third parties on their platforms. It has to be taken into account that barriers to entry for emerging competitors protect incumbent platforms from competitive forces that normally limit market power which means that freed from such restraints, incumbent platforms can participate in exclusionary behavior in the market for goods and services offered on the platform. There is a necessity to grant competitors equal and fair access to needed infrastructure for commerce. To that extent, digital platforms have become the leading force in digital commerce by allowing them to utilize their power to discriminate against third-party firms, foreclose markets and extract monopoly rents.

Do dominant technology platforms like Google, Amazon, Facebook, and Apple threaten innovation? Small companies’ businesses are more inventive and producing more patents per employee. On the other hand, instead of generating innovative products, corporations have counted on lax merger regulation to buy out competitors, or by employing anticompetitive practices to prevent them from entering markets in the first place.<sup>91</sup> It has to be taken into account that functioning in highly concentrated markets, these dominant corporations do not innovate in order to escape losing business to rivals but simply either grab others’ innovations or buy out the innovators at paltry prices.

Since corporations like Facebook and Google, which let consumers access their services for free, proving consumer harm poses a challenge. Do consumers pay for free services by offering corporations with valuable data? It has to be taken into account that dominant tech platforms utilize user data made available only to them by monitoring what their users do both on and off their platforms and so taking the best-performing ideas, functionality, and non-patentable products initiated by independent providers.

Platforms use tying strategies so as to deprive rival companies of appropriate economies of scope in the tied product market at an earlier stage, so preventing it from entering the primary tying market later.<sup>94</sup> To that extent, in digital platforms, if the tying product and the tied product markets are subject to fierce competition from prospective challengers with disruptive innovations, the anticompetitive outcomes of tying are less serious.<sup>95</sup> Tying has become a common practice in digital platforms causing both procompetitive consequences and anticompetitive results and so tying practices fall within competition law scrutiny because when a platform has already reached a decisive mass engenders anticompetitive concerns through tying during the process of platform expansion. Mandrescu<sup>96</sup> detects that platforms choose between “on platform expansion” or “cross platform expansion” through tying.

## 5.7 EU's Artificial Intelligence Act

The accelerating digitalization of society and the economy has shaped a situation where a few large platforms control imperative ecosystems in the digital economy. Digital services embrace a large category of online services, from simple websites to

internet infrastructure services and online platforms and so the rules stated in the DSA principally concern online intermediaries and platforms.<sup>97</sup>

The Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act generate a safer digital space where the fundamental rights of users are protected founding a level playing field for corporations. While the DMA safeguards a contestable and fair digital market by compelling a list of obligations on large platforms (gatekeepers), the DSA encompasses general rules on the liability of providers of online intermediary services and preserves their diligence by approving a layered approach and inflicting more extensive obligations on online platforms and large online platforms. Hence, the former is generally linked with competition law and market access, whereas the latter is commonly related to consumer protection and liability matters.

The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA)<sup>98</sup> initiative, which is set to introduce ex ante regulatory rules for "gatekeepers" in online platform markets, is one of the most important pieces of legislation to emanate from Brussels in recent decades. The DMA complements the EU and Member State competition rules facilitating the harmonization of rules at the EU level under Article 114 TFEU so as to circumvent fragmentation that could otherwise undermine the functioning of the Internal Market. Furthermore, DMA complements competition rules by tackling unfair practices by gatekeepers that either fall outside the existing EU competition rules or antitrust enforcement involving the situation in specific markets by intervening after the restrictive or abusive practice takes place engaging investigative procedures that take time. In addition, DMA diminishes the detrimental structural consequences of unfair practices ex ante by leaving open the prospect of further ex post intervention by EU or national competition law enforcement. It has to be taken into account that ex ante interventions prevent corporations from getting too much market power and ex post enforcement measures tackle abuses of dominance when they take place.

Also, DMA offers the Commission the power to impose fines and periodic penalty payments alike those available for violations of EU competition rules. According to the DMA,<sup>99</sup> the difference in market power could lead to an entrenchment of the powerful position of the gatekeepers and to unfavorable trading conditions for the non-gatekeepers.<sup>100</sup> Moreover, fairness in the DMA means that corporations receive different entitlements in line with their market power and so

<sup>97</sup> Regulation (EU) 2022/2065 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 October 2022 on a Single Market For Digital Services and amending Directive 2000/31/EC (Digital Services Act) *OL L 277*, 27.10.2022, p. 1–102.

<sup>98</sup> Regulation (EU) 2022/1925 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 September 2022 on contestable and fair markets in the digital sector and amending Directives (EU) 2019/1937 and (EU) 2020/1828 (Digital Markets Act) *OL L 265*, 12.10.2022, p. 1–66.

<sup>99</sup> Regulation (EU) 2022/1925 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 September 2022 on contestable and fair markets in the digital sector and amending Directives (EU) 2019/1937 and (EU) 2020/1828 (Digital Markets Act).

<sup>100</sup> Recital 33 Regulation 2022/1925 cit.

those with more market power receive fewer entitlements and see their economic freedom restricted, and those with less market power receive more entitlements.

The DMA is grounded on the understanding that unfair practices in the digital sector are predominantly common in core platform services as a result of certain features, embracing extreme scale economies, strong network consequences, data-driven advantages, and vertical integration. Moreover, the DMA presents a targeted set of harmonized rules that applies only to those undertakings that meet these criteria, which are illustrated in detailed quantitative thresholds in Article 3 of the DMA.

AI has become a resource of interactive, autonomous, and self-learning agencies performing tasks that would otherwise necessitate human intelligence and intervention to be successfully executed. The EU's Artificial Intelligence Act (AIA) has been drafted as a set of harmonized rules to aid organizations in designing trustworthy AI systems. Thus, delegating tasks to AI systems augments consistency, advances efficiency, and boosts access to a service or product. Moreover, AI is used to adjust the quality of community services through more accurate forecasting. To that extent, as a result of AI's ability to draw inferences from large and even less-structured data, AI is a valuable device for facilitating new solutions to complex problems. Furthermore, AI systems reduce human control and so remove human responsibility.

EU priority is to make certain that AI systems used in the EU are safe, transparent, traceable, and non-discriminatory which means that AI systems should be supervised by people in order to avoid destructive results<sup>101</sup> rather than encompassing autonomous compliance but, on the other hand, the forthcoming AAI technology will force EU to comply with the rules of dealing with AAI systems. Currently, the key objective of the AIA is to make certain that AI systems within the EU are safe, and comply with existing laws on fundamental rights, norms, and values. Moreover, the AIA describes AI systems mostly by including logic- or rule-based information processing, along with probabilistic algorithms. Like the GDPR, it applies to all corporations desiring to run AI systems within the EU, irrespective of whether they are based in the EU or not. The AIA embraces a *risk-based approach* to regulating AI systems demanding providers of high-risk AI systems to conduct conformity assessments before placing their product or service on the European market. Nevertheless, while the AIA specifies a wide range of procedural prerequisites for conformity assessments grounded on internal control, it does not offer any detailed guidance on how these rations should be implemented in practice. Basically, the AIA seeks to make certain that AI systems conform with existing EU laws, rights, and values to avert harm to its citizens. The AI rulebook bans the use of the technology for exploiting vulnerabilities.

<sup>101</sup> On 14 June 2023, MEPs adopted Parliaments negotiating position on the AI Act. The talks will now begin with EU countries in the Council on the final form of the law. Dragos Tudorache said: "The AI Act will set the tone worldwide in the development and governance of artificial intelligence, ensuring that this technology, set to radically transform our societies through the massive benefits it can offer, evolves and is used in accordance with the European values of democracy, fundamental rights, and the rule of law."

It is also imperative to say that the AIA has extra-territorial reach applying to any corporation running an AI system within the EU and corporations located outside the EU. The Artificially Intelligent Act<sup>102</sup> distinguishes the difference between “AI” and “AI systems” forbidding AIA practices, embracing subliminal manipulation under Article 5(1)(a) and (b), social scoring under Article 5(1)(c), remote biometric identification and classification under Article 5(1)(d), and mistreatment of vulnerabilities.<sup>103</sup> Moreover, AIA does not encompass any provision for liability to pay damages incurred by AI systems. Also, the AIA does not consider harmonizing itself with EU Data Protection Law. To that extent, the AIA has acknowledged a wide array of challenges, but the AIA has not referred to any individual rights but merely appreciated the fears posed by AI to fundamental rights without the provision of any legislative framework through which individuals can pursue their rights. The AIA draft does not foresee any robust machinery against AI-driven decision-making. Moreover, it does not confer any power on the European AI board to make certain strict compliance with the rules engrafted under AIA. Also, the AIA does not describe when, how, and at what stage human oversight is necessitated. It could be said that the law should adopt AI and robotics as a device wherever required to back the structural values of the legislative contribution delivering valuable, vibrant, constructive, and progressive administration of justice.

## 5.8 Digital Monopolies

It is characteristic that the FTC stimulates antitrust and regulatory efforts by tackling the power of big tech corporations.<sup>104</sup> As it is mentioned earlier, it is witnessed that principal Internet platforms exploit their power to prevent market entrants, to extract monopoly profits, and to gather intimate personal information that they can utilize for their own benefit. To that extent, there is a need to enforce the Clayton Act and in general the antitrust laws fairly and energetically.

Vertical restraints often pose no risk to competition unless the entity imposing them has market power, which cannot be evaluated.<sup>105</sup> The US Supreme Court supported that not all vertical restraints should be condemned.<sup>106</sup> The Advocate General argued that in order to ascertain whether an agreement restricted competition one had to carry out “a comprehensive examination of their economic

While the US Supreme Court has not accepted “margin squeeze” as a stand-alone offense, the EU recognizes margin squeeze as a discrete example of abuse of dominance. In TeliaSonera,<sup>109</sup> the Court approved the application of an equally efficient competitor test that takes into consideration the dominant operator’s costs and revenues holding that while an anticompetitive effect is “probable” where the wholesale product at issue is “indispensable” for the supply of the end product, still an anticompetitive effect can be generated when the wholesale product is not indispensable which means that indispensability is an issue for appraisal but not a necessary condition. Moreover, the Court held that it is required to ascertain the levels of “margin squeeze of competitors at least as efficient as the dominant undertaking.” The TeliaSonera case settled that margin squeeze must have an anticompetitive effect on the market. Unlike the EU which acknowledges a broad perception of margin squeeze, the USA does not acknowledge margin squeeze as a stand-alone abuse. The Supreme Court<sup>110</sup> ruled that “if there is no [antitrust] duty to deal at the wholesale level and no predatory pricing at the retail level, then a firm is not required to price both of these services in a manner that preserves its rival’s profit margin” and so recognizing that absent an antitrust duty to deal or predatory pricing, a “margin squeeze” cannot establish a valid antitrust claim on its own. Moreover, the linkLine judgment was similar to the TeliaSonera judgment as they both concerned ADSL services.

It is argued that a company with no antitrust duty to take care of its rivals at all is under no obligation to provide those rivals with a “sufficient” level of service.<sup>111</sup> Section 2 of the Sherman Act makes it illegal to “monopolize, or attempt to monopolize, or combine or conspire with any other person or persons, to monopolize any part of the trade or commerce among the several States, or with foreign nations.”<sup>112</sup> Hence, merely retaining monopoly power and charging monopoly prices does

not violate §2 which means that the statute aims at “the willful acquisition or maintenance of that power” as differentiated from growth or development by means of a superior product, etc. <sup>113</sup> Businesses are free to decide the parties with whom they will trade, as well as the prices, terms, and conditions of that trading. <sup>114</sup> Any duty to deal has to come from the statute alone and so the only way that the antitrust agencies and courts could not apply Section 2 in regulated sectors at all is if the US Congress specifically says in the statute regulating the sector that the statute supersedes the antitrust laws.

Taking into account that conduct that is “per se illegal,” encompassing violations of the antitrust laws, like outright price-fixing agreements and Section 2 allegations of monopolization, attempted monopolization, and conspiracy to monopolize were brought only civilly, DOJ obtained a guilty plea to a criminal violation of Section 2 for the first time in decades, launching an effort to revive criminal enforcement of monopolization law. <sup>115</sup> To that extent, Section 2 is applicable only when an attempt to collude would have resulted in a party securing or preserving monopoly power in a defined market and so the automatic per se condemnation reserved for specific categories of “manifestly anticompetitive” horizontal agreements, like price fixing, bid-rigging, and market allocation. <sup>116</sup> DOJ’s criminal enforcement endeavors have been restricted to the so-called “hardcore,” or per se, offenses under Section 1 of the Sherman Act such as price-fixing, bid-rigging, and market allocation schemes between competitors. <sup>117</sup>

The EU competition rules are horizontal in nature applying to all economic sectors. It is characteristic that excessive pricing has become a central category of EU competition law infringement cases concerning pharmaceuticals alongside pay for delay. <sup>118</sup> Excessive prices are considered unfair prices in Article 102a TFEU and are a form of abuse of dominance. <sup>119</sup>

It is worth noting that there is a distinctive application of competition rules in EU and US concerning the same pricing policy approved by an undertaking. In the USA, an antitrust claim can arise in a “price squeeze” situation only if some other antitrust violation is being performed. Again, there is no excessive pricing in the USA and so high pricing composes an infringement only if it amounts to a de facto refusal to deal and if refusing to deal would be an antitrust infringement in the occurrences of dominance, lack of business justification, etc. Besides, low pricing can be an infringement only if constituting below-cost predatory pricing. Thus, without the

occurrence of either of those independent infringements, there can be no margin squeeze and so it is not a “stand alone” infringement.

It has to be taken into account that a detailed regulatory scheme such as that generated by the 1996 Act normally induces the question of whether the regulated entities are not shielded from antitrust scrutiny altogether by the doctrine of implied immunity.<sup>120</sup> Thus, the Supreme Court assumes that it is less expected to find a refusal to deal infringement in a regulated commerce when the regulations enact various provisions designed at preventing anticompetitive behavior and so in those cases, the Court considers the regulation for the economic “context” in which the conduct is taking place to ascertain if it is expected to have an anticompetitive effect which means founding a legitimate justification for the refusal.

The Court of Justice<sup>121</sup> specified that the margin squeeze test is grounded on the costs and the strategy of the dominant undertaking itself, instead of on the specific condition of its actual or prospective competitors. Moreover, the “as-efficient-operator test” permits dominant corporations to evaluate the lawfulness of their activities and is consistent with the general principle of legal certainty.<sup>122</sup> Again, behavior resembling a price squeeze may be undertaken for efficiency or procompetitive reasons such as to abolish a double marginalization or to meet competition from another technology.<sup>123</sup> Furthermore, it is needed to establish that the practice generates an anticompetitive outcome on the retail market and that the practice is not in any way economically justified. Consequently, the Court approved that margin squeeze is not a per se abuse and so there is a need to prove the prospective for anticompetitive effects on the specific facts.<sup>124</sup>

The dominant undertakings’ pricing practices are abusive when they have possibly an exclusionary effect “capable of making market entry more difficult or impossible” and so in the lack of any consequence on the competitive situation of competitors, a pricing practice cannot be classified as exclusionary which means that actual exclusionary results must be shown so as to ascertain the abusive nature of a particular practice.<sup>125</sup>

The Directorate General for Competition at the European Commission enforces competition law in the areas of antitrust, merger control, and State aid. The Treaty of the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) does not define the core elements of Article 102 and the law under Article 102 protects competitors, but only if they are as efficient as the dominant undertaking. The Court of Justice found that a pricing practice constitutes and abuse under Article 102 if it has an exclusionary effect on

In the EU, there are still countries where you will find big firms, which used to be former state monopolies. Besides, it is problematic to ascertain whether any liability for margin squeeze remains in the USA under Section 2 of the Sherman Act following the case in Linkline.<sup>127</sup>

Again, the “*indispensability*” criterion is element of the legal test under Article 102 TFEU when a dominant company denies an input available because to order such a company to share its input interferes with central rights such as the right to property and the right to contract along with the reasons to invest. Where these rights and incentives are not at play, for the reason that the dominant company has already given access to the input but tries to limit competition by requiring unfair terms for such access, the *indispensability* criterion is not an element of the legal test.

First of all, in *Telia Sonera* and in *Telefónica* the CJEU had already explained that the *indispensability* criterion is not vital for price predation cases. Besides, in *Slovak Telekom*<sup>128</sup> the CJEU has explained that the *indispensability* criterion is not required in non-price predation cases and so after *Slovak Telekom* it will be easier to prove a breach of Article 102 TFEU in cases where a dominant corporation supplies an input to its competitors but degrades such supply by any means.

To that extent, the CJEU has refined that in cases of “constructive” or “implicit” refusal to supply to a competitor of an infrastructure, facility, or service, the prerequisite of the *indispensability* of such input is not needed for an abuse of dominance in breach of Article 102 TFEU to take place. Rather, the *indispensability* of the input is demanded for the application of Article 102 TFEU only in the narrow situation of outright refusal to supply an input to a competitor.

The Court of Justice confirmed that *Slovak Telekom* had abused its dominant position in the Slovak market for broadband internet services by limiting the access of alternative operators to its local circle. In addition, in *Slovak Telekom, the court* maintains the relevance of the essential facilities doctrine and of *Bronner* criteria explaining that they only apply to refusal to deal cases. Hence, if a dominant corporation decides to deal with rivals, it could violate Article 102 TFEU by deteriorating the terms offered to such rivals, even if the relevant input is not objectively required to compete in the downstream market. Moreover, denial to deal infringes Article 102 TFEU only if it is “*able to give rise to at least potentially anticompetitive effects, or exclusionary effects, on the markets concerned.*”<sup>129</sup>

There is no duty to aid competitors. It could be said that the regulatory framework that exists in Verizon<sup>131</sup> case reveals that regulation drastically reduces the possibility of major antitrust harm. Section 2 of the Sherman Act, being the symbol for free enterprise, prevents unlawful monopolization but it does not give judges “carte blanche” to uphold that a monopolist changes its manner of doing business whenever some other approach might yield greater competition.<sup>132</sup> In addition, Justice Antonin Scalia delivered the Court’s opinion that the alleging breach of Verizon’s Telecommunication Act duties to share its network with competitors did not state a claim under the Sherman Act due to the fact that the 1996 act did not modify antitrust law or add new claims and so Verizon did not violate preexisting antitrust standards.

Is there confusion due to retaining two antitrust enforcement agencies? It seems that by retaining two antitrust enforcement agencies generates contemporary confusion.<sup>133</sup> It has to be taken into account that certainty is central for investors, and possible and actual conflicts between DOJ and the FTC reduce certainty. To that extent, antitrust issues influencing technology are particularly complex generating concerns how best to apply antitrust law to emerging technologies and so in case the DOJ and the FTC will proceed on different theories augment uncertainty. Furthermore, the court finds that the FTC assumed that Qualcomm’s conduct violated antitrust laws, despite the DOJ’s approval of Qualcomm’s conduct.<sup>134</sup> It could be said that Congress will

Mergers between platforms and nascent technologies generate new enquiries. First of all, mergers and acquisitions will establish the monopoly power of the platform. ## 5.10 Antitrust Complexities

Antitrust policy is related to applications of market power, which is the power to profit by dropping output below the competitive level and moving up prices unreasonably above cost. Moreover, antitrust doctrine does not condemn companies merely for the reason that they are very large and so discarding imposing liability based on size since size and market power do not always go hand in hand.<sup>141</sup>

Section 2 of the Sherman Act expressly prohibits both monopolization and attempts. It is obvious that the presence and degree of any anticompetitive consequence vary and so anticompetitive complexities mean that the FTC must prove its case as in other rule-of-reason cases.<sup>142</sup> The Supreme Court<sup>143</sup> refused to force a per se rule of illegality for the reason that doing so would prevent a “significant amount of procompetitive conduct” and stating that per se rules of illegality “can be counterproductive. They can increase the total cost of the antitrust system by prohibiting procompetitive conduct the antitrust laws should encourage.” To that extent, the Chicago School regards erroneous over-enforcement of the antitrust laws as a key threat to the economy, and the post-Chicago School considers erroneous under-enforcement as a greater threat to the economy.

Decisions that are based on an in-depth economic assessment of the investigated conduct’s actual effects are highly case-specific and are consequently doubtful to result in administrative precedent and clear guidance for the wider business community. Besides, per se rules are generally applicable conduct rules that are not conditional on an analysis of consequences but ascertain legal presumptions of illegality for certain kinds of conduct that is expected to have detrimental results which means that such rules lessen the enforcement cost, diminish the length of proceedings, and so confirming clear boundaries for all undertakings that fall within their latitude.

It is worth mentioning here that Chicago School approach thinks that over-enforcement of the antitrust laws is risky since innovative behavior looks like anticompetitive behavior and erroneous condemnation of innovative behavior could damage economic growth.<sup>144</sup> According to Chicago, innovation can deceptively appear to be anticompetitive for the reason that innovation destroys competitors who fail to carry on. Furthermore, innovation is beneficial for consumers, delivering them better goods at lower prices which means that they should not be an object of the antitrust laws. On the other hand, the innovator who succeeds at diminishing costs, and drops prices as a result, to the advantage of consumers, looks like a predatory pricer.<sup>145</sup> In addition, for Chicago, the daunting thing about the apparent resemblance between innovation and anticompetitive behavior is that innovation is not just good for consumers, but is in fact the most essential driver of consumer welfare and economic growth. It is worth mentioning here that innovation is the driver of development and so an elastic implementation of antitrust law to a certain degree is a pro, but, on a higher scale of no implementation of antitrust law, the better innovation is prohibited to the detriment of society and environment. It has to be taken into account that antitrust enforcement stimulates innovation and so competitive markets generate greater motivations for innovation. Additionally, according to Chicago, letting a few bad players get away with monopolizing markets likely would instigate much less damage to consumers, for the reason that history has revealed that even the most entrenched monopoly<sup>146</sup> position ultimately erodes under the force of new technologies, such as AI, and shifting tastes. In other words, antitrust has to allow the market to do its work.

The Post-Chicago School has disputed that failing to convict a bad corporation takes an even greater toll on innovation, by initiating an economy of large corporations with little motivation to destabilize their market positions by innovating. There is need of comparing the resulting costs with the social benefits of antitrust enforcement.<sup>147</sup> Moreover, monopolies like Google and Facebook can hold back the competitive threat of new technologies by buying up nascent innovative competitors like Nest and WhatsApp which leads to excluding the incentive of these enterprises

The Supreme Court in the Marine Bancorporation case required an extravagant evidentiary burden for a violation of § 7 of the Clayton Act based on the elimination of prospective competition.<sup>148</sup> According to the Court, two preconditions must exist before an actual potential competition theory “establishes a violation of § 7. Facebook operated in a rapidly changing competitive environment where the basic technological undergirding of the social network was advancing, embracing the growing significance of mobile technology to connect users online. It has to be taken into account that if a market is not a natural monopoly, then the appearance of a dominant company involves exclusionary practices, and superior management. The Supreme Court<sup>151</sup> stated that “monopoly would be inevitably prevented if no extraneous or sovereign power imposed it and no right to make unlawful contracts having a monopolistic tendency were permitted.” Thus, US antitrust law refuses to condemn a dominant company apart from proof of one or more anticompetitive practices which means that a dominant company ought to do

Also, it has to be taken into consideration that the natural-monopoly question for networks is distinctive for the reason that it implicates two specific questions such as if the network is a natural monopoly and if the network is controlled by a single company. For instance, the global telephone system is a natural-monopoly network for the reason that the extent of network externalities is global and a larger network always has advantages over a smaller one. Nonetheless, the telephone system is competitively structured for the reason that it is controlled by many corporations, denoting that no single company dominates it. It is worth noting that the high degree of interoperability is an important factor cutting against natural monopolies facilitating competition inside the network. However, Section 1 of the Sherman Act outlaws only “unreasonable restraints.” <sup>153</sup> Moreover, restraints are unreasonable per se for the reason that they always or almost always restrict competition and decrease output. <sup>154</sup> To that extent, only “horizontal” restraints being restraints imposed by agreement between competitors qualify as unreasonable per se which means that restraints that are not unreasonable per se are assessed under the “rule of reason” demanding courts to perform a fact-specific evaluation of “market power and market structure” in order to evaluate the restraint’s actual outcome on competition. <sup>155</sup> In other words, there is a need of distinguishing between restraints with anticompetitive result that are damaging to the consumer and restraints inspiring competition that are in the consumer’s best concern. <sup>156</sup>

It has to be taken into account that the concentration of economic power in the USA and its after-effects on competition have led to a re-examination of the place of consumer welfare as the single benchmark for evaluating competitive practices. Hence, there is a need of determining between a competition policy securing the result of competition such as allocative efficiency and a competition policy protecting the competition process for its own sake. Competition law has to achieve both elements.

## 5.11 Mergers and Competition

Clayton Act prevents mergers and acquisitions which significantly lessen competition or tend to create monopolies and so under the Clayton Act, as modernized by the HSR Act, if a deal meets certain criteria linked to transaction size, and size of the parties to the transaction, premerger notification is needed and the FTC or the Department of Justice will review the merger.<sup>157</sup> The current approach to antitrust review of mergers fails to avert “killer acquisitions,” in which dominant companies acquire nascent competitors with the principal goal of lessening competition.<sup>158</sup> Facebook’s acquisition of Instagram can be viewed as one example of a monopolistic practice.<sup>159</sup>

To that extent, killer acquisitions aim toward terminating the development of the target’s innovative product to obstruct future competition which means that killer acquisitions will result in a reduction in the development of substitutes. Motta and Peitz<sup>160</sup> dispute that such acquisitions harm consumer welfare because of anticompetitive amalgamations of data, increased prices, and reduced opportunities for entrants. It seems that killer acquisitions assemble in certain activities like pharmaceuticals<sup>161</sup> and their competitive suppression consequences necessitate specific norms.<sup>162</sup> Lemley and McCready<sup>163</sup> contemplate that adverse consequences on competition arise from venture capitalists’ and startups’ obsession with “exit strategy” as being purchased by a dominant competitor. Hence, the appreciation that large technology corporations acquire startups to suppress competitive threats generates changes in merger policy. Are the existing legal instruments appropriate to sanction the competitively negative outcomes of vertical integration, both by way of new downstream online platform acquisitions and by way of so-called “killer” acquisitions? Article 101(1) TFEU forbids any form of coordination that deliberately substitutes practical cooperation between enterprises for the risks of competition.

It is worth noting that courts are able to afford a presumption of legality or illegality to most competitive conduct and so the structure of most transactions discloses whether it is right to apply a presumption of legality or illegality.<sup>165</sup> On the one hand, courts and antitrust enforcement agencies have determined that vertical mergers and joint ventures between non-competitors and vertical resale restraints imposed by suppliers on their distributors almost always have a net positive result on consumers and so courts categorize such vertical transactions at the end of the antitrust analysis as legal. On the other hand, horizontal agreements among competitors to fix prices, restrict competition, or assign territories almost always restrict competition without any offsetting efficiency advantage for consumers and so such horizontal agreements are categorized at the end of the antitrust analysis as illegal. Also, motive and intent play leading roles in anticompetitive conduct, specific competitive behavior reveals its impact and so courts should distinguish good from bad intention.<sup>166</sup>

On the one hand, inter-brand competition refers to the competition that exists among corporations at a given level of the value chain. On the other hand, intra-brand competition is the rivalry that exists among the distributors or retailers of a specific brand of a given product/service.

Vertical resale restraints only involve “intra-brand competition,” but they do not negatively affect inter-brand competition and so their only impact on inter-brand competition is beneficial.<sup>167</sup> Thus, vertical resale restraints given that have the beneficial effect of encouraging dealers to provide quality-related services that make a manufacturer’s products more competitive against other brands should be

It is worth noting that the US Supreme Court established strict rules against price fixing and limited the power of the government to challenge corporate mergers.<sup>175</sup> However, the antitrust laws accelerated the rise of monopolies and oligopolies due to the fact that states proved economically ineffective against the new, giant corporations operating in national markets and global ones.

Mergers evaluation is based on their impact on customers and the depth of market shares and market concentration is not an end in itself, but is constructive by illustrating the merger's competitive consequences.<sup>176</sup> Horizontal mergers in highly concentrated markets are questioned in an effort to remedy the foreseen harms of horizontal mergers in concentrated markets and so both the FTC and the DOJ often allow these consolidations to proceed on the condition that the merging parties agree to divest assets in the market in which they compete head-to-head or agree to behavioral duties and restrictions.<sup>177</sup>

Big Tech dominates the technology sector in many economies and technology corporations such as Google, Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Microsoft get the top five spots on the NASDAQ by market capitalization. To this extent, startup companies stipulate competitive pressure since they are able to siphon off or "cream skim" customers and collect valuable data. Thus, Big Tech buys other firms in order to solidify and protect their dominance. Also, Big Tech acquisition of startup firms gains the incumbent by diminishing competitive pressure of prospective entrants on the periphery of the market or by averting future entry and expansion by such firms that could destabilize the incumbent's dominance. As long as new startups can emerge competition is still alive. Competition is a constant mobility of efforts for new development in order to achieve better earnings.

It has to be taken into consideration that the acquisition of startup firms aids the dominant firm by dropping the disciplining competitive pressure of prospective entrants on the periphery of the market or by precluding future entry and expansion by such firms undermining the incumbent's dominance. Mergers encompass economies of scale making likely the elimination of the duplicate efforts in comparable research projects. Mergers augment the suitability of inventions by dropping technological spillovers to competitors. Furthermore, an augment in market power by

The laissez-faire was considered the best approach in terms of economic policy but the inter-war period was characterized by the defense of the cartel as an efficient way of organizing the economy and escaping destructive competition. It is worth mentioning here that a merger would bring noteworthy efficiency gains in businesses distinguished by high levels of fixed costs.

The EU expanded the reach of its competition laws<sup>184</sup> and extra-territorial jurisdiction arises when a violator makes another party change its course of conduct with a view to foreclosing competition triggering harm in the EU. European competition authorities have gradually adopted consumer welfare as the sole criterion for competition rules enforcement. Additionally, in EU competition law, the consumer welfare criterion is being contested at the very moment when it seems to be gaining ground. It is worth noting that the EU seeks to review mergers ex ante that is before they are concluded, so as to prevent creation or strengthening of dominant positions in the EU market.

As Jan Kregl<sup>185</sup> refers, competition law regulation is having a largely ex post character, meaning that regulatory steps are taken and restrictive measures are implemented as a reaction to the assumed anticompetitive conduct. On the other hand, the EU merger control procedure is built on the opposite principle, having an ex ante effect, and so while it is relatively feasible to undo the damage instigated by cartel agreements or by abuse of dominance, restoring the premerger market

It seems that the most fundamental root of European competition law lies in judging its failure to overcome the market power of large corporations. The goal of EU merger control is to prevent concentrations from causing lasting harm to competition<sup>186</sup> in the EU and remedies are by far the most common device by which the European Commission seeks to accomplish this and so constituting the Commission's most commonly used form of intervention. Are remedies valuable in averting price increases from mergers? Kwoka<sup>187</sup> argues that "many challenged mergers are subject to remedies that fail to prevent post-merger price increases." Moreover, the Commission in order to avert harm to competition is to prohibit a concentration. Apart from formal interventions, merger control also blocks harm to competition by deterring anticompetitive mergers from being planned and some mergers are discarded by the parties for the reason that competition authorities raise competition concerns. Besides, in the USA, most problematic mergers are not blocked by the courts but cleared with remedies, through "consent orders" (FTC) and "consent decrees" entered by a court at the request of the Department of Justice. Nonetheless, apart from the deterrent outcome of prohibitions, effective remedies are central in guaranteeing that merger control fulfils its undertaking of keeping markets competitive. Furthermore, the prevalence of structural remedies in EU merger control leads to the risk of forcing European actors to abandon activities or discard strategic assets in favor of competitors from outside Europe.

It is worth noting here that under the EU merger control regime, the term "gun-jumping" stands for an early implementation of a concentration in advance of its notification or before receiving an approval of the transaction which amounts to infringements of Articles 4 (1) and 7(1) of the Council Regulation No 139/2004 of 20 January 2004 (EUMR).<sup>188</sup>

It seems that the Commission's line to merger remedies is not essentially different from the one of the Department of Justice and the FTC due to the fact that all these authorities use remedies, not prohibitions, as the principal device to tackle anticompetitive consequences from mergers. The European Commission has approved, under the EU Merger Regulation, the acquisition of Fitbit by Google and the approval is conditional on full compliance with a commitments package offered by Google. <sup>200</sup> On the other hand, the European Commission's decision to fine Google for its self-preferencing maneuvers in Google Search is restricted to specific vertical shopping services. <sup>201</sup>

It seems that the existing law of mergers is ill-equipped to tackle the tech firms' acquisition of startups as a consequence of a rule called the "potential competition" doctrine addressing the consequences of an acquisition where one firm is in the market and the other is "waiting in the wings" or on the periphery of the market.

## 5.12 Deficiencies of Modern Antitrust Enforcement

It has to be taken into consideration that antitrust law is advanced entirely through adjudication facilitating fact-specific analysis of liability and remedies. First of all, competitive markets are a foundation of economic liberty and so absence of competition empowers dominant corporations to exercise their market power with harmful tactics. Thus, in uncompetitive markets, corporations with market power raise prices for consumers, reduce salaries for workers, and choke off new entrants and other upstarts and so undercutting innovation and business vitality. Taking into account that antitrust law is matured entirely through adjudication means that antitrust adjudication bears shortcomings because courts analyze most forms of conduct under the "rule of reason" standard. Rohit Chopra & Lina Khan <sup>202</sup> argue that a rule of reason approach is nothing more than "a broad and open-ended inquiry into the overall competitive effects of particular conduct [which] asks judges to weigh the circumstances to decide whether the practice at issue violates the antitrust laws." It could be said that the FTC has to step into the competition breach by promulgating ex ante rules to enforce better the prohibition against "unfair methods

of competition” outlined in Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. <sup>203</sup> Also, taking into consideration that the “rule of reason” entangles a broad and open-ended inquiry into the overall competitive consequences of certain conduct demanding judges to weigh the surroundings in investigating whether the practice at issue infringes antitrust laws implicates judges in a struggle to categorize anticompetitive behavior and to apply complex economic criteria in consistent manners which is unaffordable instigating uncertainty. To that extent, judges themselves have appraised antitrust standards as being highly difficult to manage which means that if a standard is not administrable, it won’t generate predictable outcomes. Thus, the absence of clear standards and rules in antitrust denotes that market players face uncertainty in not adopting legal norms into their business decisions. Likewise, uncertainty deprives market members and the public of notice concerning what the law is, undercutting due process being a central norm in legal systems.

## 5.13 AI and Market Self-Correcting

It is worth noting that antitrust has been vital for structuring the economy now and in the past, either in favor of concentrating economic power or against it. Additionally, strong antitrust enforcement is central to preserving a competitive market structure. The Chicago School thought that markets are self-correcting and that free entry is a “natural” condition that erodes incumbent market power and so there was no necessity for robust antitrust enforcement to generate or uphold the settings required to make competition effective. In other words, contemporary antitrust consensus stems from the belief that market forces could naturally correct the occasional occurrences of market power and could do to this point better and quicker than government intervention.

On the one hand, which is the need for the occurrence of antitrust given that the market naturally hinders the emergence of any market power. On the other hand, antitrust plays a decisive role in stimulating open and competitive markets. Hence, antitrust policy is a required device to restore the market power problem, but in practice has been ascertained not sufficient due to political matters and in fact the overruling of politics above antitrust law.

Will scarcity of e-energy generate problems in AAI market requiring competition rules as well? ## 5.14 Predatory Pricing

Taking into consideration the principle of Sherman Act, Section 2 assertion is that a corporation is not competing on the merits and so pursuing conduct is not permissible such as pricing intended to hamper or suppress legitimate competition. Thus, monopolists do not attempt to suppress competition on the merits and so Sherman violations arise from the view that “[a] business rival has priced its products in an unfair manner with an object to eliminate or retard competition and thereby gain and exercise control over prices in the relevant market.” <sup>211</sup> The US Supreme Court upheld a finding of harm to competition when Continental Baking entered a market and underpriced Utah Pie, a smaller but locally dominant rival. <sup>212</sup> Thus, when a company uses unreasonably exclusionary conduct driving its rivals from the market or somehow raises their costs in order to make them fewer challenging competitors, its market power grows. On the other hand, the US Supreme Court considers that the simple possession of monopoly power, and the concurrent charging of monopoly

prices, is not illegal<sup>213</sup> which means that solely possessing monopoly power and charging monopoly prices does not violate § 2 of the Sherman Act.<sup>214</sup>

The absence of competition stems from systemic failures in the market and so corporations' triumph by brute force, using questionable methods to prevent the formation of any competition and so antitrust law was invented to address situations like these. Moreover, antitrust laws seek to discipline anticompetitive behavior resulting in higher prices and reduced output.<sup>215</sup> Also, corporations take advantage of their market power and so distort competition and trigger long-term consumer harm.

Predatory pricing transpires when a company charges less for its product or service than it costs to produce. Below-cost pricing<sup>216</sup> is performed by corporations with monopoly power in order to drive rival competitors, principally more efficient competitors, from the market and so once the company eliminates its rivals, it raises prices and takes up again receiving monopoly profits. It could be said that the rationale of predatory pricing is to exclude competition so a corporation afterward recoup its short-term losses by charging supra-competitive prices.<sup>217</sup> Hence, predatory pricing harms consumers by restraining competition, increasing prices over the long term, reducing choices between providers, and dropping enticements to innovate and advance efficiency.

It is worth noting that predatory pricing claims necessitate a probability analysis since the plaintiff must prove that when the defendant was charging a price below cost, it possessed a likelihood of later recouping that investment in below-cost pricing by charging a monopoly price. Moreover, predatory pricing is one form of anticompetitive conduct offering the basis for either a monopolization or attempted monopolization claim, nonetheless, the latter is more common.<sup>218</sup> Courts generate

## 6.1 Introduction

Antitrust laws in the USA, and competition rules in the EU, are set out in statutes of general applicability, written in broad, almost constitutional form. US antitrust is economically founded, evolutionary, and limited to a set of achievable social welfare purposes. It has to be taken into account that transparency of antitrust law's central function should lead to transparency in performing it.

The US and the EU antitrust agencies have concluded several bilateral cooperation agreements with their foreign counterparts enabling greater diffusion of basic economic theories triggering antitrust enforcement in the USA and the EU. The OECD and the International Competition Network have offered central settings for voluntary cooperation and diffusion of best practices, involving economic analysis of antitrust law. Nonetheless, these networks have not fully adopted the Chicago School's approach to antitrust law by endorsing a more expansive notion of antitrust enforcement while stressing the benefits of economic principles as a basis of antitrust policy.

## 6.2 Chicago Versus Harvard

The “Chicago School of Antitrust Analysis” utilized rigorous microeconomic analysis to transform antitrust enforcers’ focus from economic power to economic incentives such as market power, entry, and efficiency.<sup>1</sup> Thus, the Chicago School’s

<sup>1</sup>Herbert J. Hovenkamp & Fiona Scott Morton, Framing the Chicago School of Antitrust Analysis, 168 U. PA. L. REV. 1843 (2020). Andrew I. Gavil, William E. Kovacic, and Jonathan B. Baker, Antitrust Law in Perspective: Cases, Concepts, and Problems in Competition Policy 66–67 (West 2d ed 2008).

ideas are comprehended as a commitment to a certain method of antitrust enforcement rather than an agreement on specific policy outcomes. In addition, the Chicago School supported to focus on the incentives of economic agents and not on the structure of the market to ascertain the competitive effects of mergers and corporation conduct altering the Harvard School approach which was concerned with market concentration. Therefore, the Chicago School advanced a less antitrust intervention grounded on a belief that markets would largely self-correct while governmental intervention could entrench monopolies. Hence, according to the Chicago School,<sup>2</sup> the key aim of antitrust was the promotion of consumer welfare and total welfare<sup>3</sup> and so considering that vertical mergers are generally efficient and rarely lead to foreclosure concerns. Equally, conglomerate mergers were seen as typically efficient, demanding little antitrust intervention.

It is worth noting that the Chicago School formed law of vertical restraints renounced an older precedent that had rejected coordination comparatively on the basis that it concerned a “kind of feudal dominion” that should not survive beyond company boundaries. The Supreme Court in Simpson<sup>4</sup> specified that vertically imposed price fixing by an oil company on gas station resellers is illegal and in State Oil<sup>5</sup> decided that maximum price restraints by powerful corporations upon small resellers are legal. To that extent, precedents are rationalized on the basis of economic arguments that vertical restraints generate efficiencies that eventually redound to the benefit of consumers, paralleling the economic reasons that were employed to validate corporate mergers allowing powerful corporations to dominate markets.<sup>6</sup>

While the USA has promoted the “development of sound antitrust laws” abroad, the EU system has had a more direct impact on states implementing competition policies for the first time.<sup>7</sup> It is worth noting that antitrust enforcement gradually
