began to rely on economic experts and econometrics that are now all but mandatory in antitrust litigation. US antitrust enforcement changed considerably, echoing many of the teachings of the Chicago School.

It is worth mentioning here that courts, particularly those adhering to the then-Chicago and Harvard School economic theories, imposed their economic ideologies into the law and the Supreme Court began quoting them. It is expressed by the court the view that “federal courts are not economists, and we should avoid an unnecessary ‘ramble through the wilds of economic theory.’”<sup>8</sup> There is a need to apply legal principles which will incorporate an economic substance but not entire economic theories to be taken as legal principles. To that extent, Maurice E. Stucke and Ariel Ezrachi<sup>9</sup> argue that “Economics, of course, can inform antitrust law and serve to ensure its measured application. But it should not be used to displace the law. An economics-based rule of reason, as it is implemented by the courts, offers little certainty once theory and modeling are stretched and manipulated to suit one’s agenda.”

## 6.3 EU Versus USA

It seems that EU and US antitrust policies differ in a number of vital matters. First of all, the structure of and approach to antitrust law in the EU assigns the Commission much greater discretion to deviate from established economic principles and procedural best practices in its antitrust enforcement and decision-making. Thus, antitrust enforcement at the EU level is driven almost entirely by the European Commission and unreviewed and unchecked by EU courts which means that EU antitrust is distinctly less economically founded, and unavoidably more politicized, than in the USA.

In actual fact, Article 102 TFEU more closely aligns with the original, pre-Chicago School understanding of Section 2 of the Sherman Act due to the fact that Article 102 TFEU rests on a perception of special responsibility for competition as a function of market power. Also, the EU statute goes beyond forwarding further monopolization and directly limits monopoly rent extraction. To that extent, a dominant firm has “a special responsibility not to allow its conduct to impair genuine undistorted competition” and so it is notable, as it compels a positive duty upon the dominant company to uphold competition, instead of a purely negative prohibition

<sup>8</sup>Host Int'l, Inc. v. MarketPlace, PHL, LLC, 32 F.4th 242, 253 (3d Cir. 2022).

<sup>9</sup>Maurice E. Stucke & Ariel Ezrachi, Innovation Misunderstood, <https://ssrn.com/abstract=4547201> p 13. Ariel Ezrachi and Maurice E. Stucke, The Darker Sides of Digital Platform Innovation, Network Law Rev., Aug. 11, 2022.

of anticompetitive conduct.<sup>10</sup> Finally, Article 102 TFEU directly restricts the extraction of monopoly rents.

While the US centers on protecting the process of competition for the economic welfare of consumers, the EU upholds its competition laws to affect a wider range of political/economic/social objectives. Undeniably, the Commission has specified that European competition law chases multiple purposes. Concerning competition itself, the EU tracks objectives that are far more ambiguous than those chased under US antitrust law. While it is comparatively uncontroversial that antitrust law in the USA presently pursues a single goal, such as the maximization of consumer welfare, the issue is less settled in the EU. Moreover, the European Union has been reluctant to commit to a well-defined competition objective for its antitrust law.

Additionally, the US and European antitrust regimes diverge considerably with regard to the objectives they engage in, and the extent to which these are, or are not, based on mainstream economics. Although the USA is guided by the consumer welfare standard, the objectives of European competition enforcers are both diverse and often unchained from economic thinking. Furthermore, the EU courts have eventually exposed EU competition law to augmented politicization.

In many matters, EU merger law is fairly similar to US merger law, being guided by something resembling a consumer welfare model.<sup>11</sup> The Commission is compelled to set out clearly and concisely the decisive facts and legal and economic considerations, and the pleas in law and evidence having decisive value in the context of a merger decision.<sup>12</sup> The General Court of the European Union annulled the European Commission's 2016 decision to block the proposed merger between Hutchison 3G UK with its brand "Three" and Telefónica UK with its brand "O2" by clarifying the legal test for non-coordinated effects in oligopoly cases. The Court noted that the new merger regulation has to achieve an extension of the scope of the review, but also to preserve and strengthen the concept of a dominant position and to increase legal certainty. The new regulation should permit the Commission to catch mergers in oligopolistic markets that, without generating or strengthening an individual or collective dominant position, have led to a condition where firms could establish the parameters of competition by becoming a price maker rather than remaining a price taker post-merger. The Court decides that while the revised regulation now permits the Commission to catch cases without finding dominance,

<sup>10</sup> Case C-552/03, Unilever Bestfoods v. Comm'n, 2006 E.C.R. I-9091 §22. See Case C52/09, Konkurrensverket v. TeliaSonera Sverige AB, 2011 E.C.R. I-527 §82, 3, 8, 24; Case C-202/07, Fr. Télécom SA v Comm'n, 2009 E.C.R. I-2369 §105.

<sup>11</sup> CK Telecoms ruling offers a fitting example. See Case T-399/16 CK Telecoms UK Investments Ltd v European Commission <https://curia.europa.eu/juris/liste.jst?num=T-399/16> Judgment of the General Court (First Chamber, Extended Composition) 28 May 2020 ECLI:EU:T:2020:217 Annuls Commission Decision C(2016) 2796 final of 11 May 2016 declaring incompatible with the internal market the concentration resulting from the acquisition of Telefónica Europe Plc by Hutchison 3G UK Investments Ltd.

<sup>12</sup> Bertelsmann and Sony Corporation of America v Impala, C-413/06 P, EU:C:2008:392, paragraph 169. Evropaiki Dynamiiki v EMSA, C-252/10 P.

the circumstance that a merger takes place in a tight oligopoly situation is not enough for a prohibition decision which means that the test for non-coordinated consequences in oligopolistic markets unavoidably necessitates the elimination of vital competitive constraints that the merging parties had exerted upon each other. Hence, the reduction of competitive pressure on the market was not enough to demonstrate a prohibition of a merger which means that such an interpretation would lead to the Commission being able to outlaw any merger in an oligopoly at its own discretion. The Court sets the standard for the Commission to establish with a "strong probability" the existence of noteworthy impediment following the concentration.

The Commission found that the merger would have a negative effect on prices and the quality of services for consumers. According to the Commission's horizontal merger guidelines, a merger generates negative competitive outcomes if it excludes an "important competitive force." Again, some companies have more of an impact on the competitive process than their market shares and so a merger encompassing such a company alters the competitive dynamics in a noteworthy anticompetitive manner, predominantly when the market is already concentrated. In addition, the Commission has relied on this concept to rationalize competitive concerns in oligopoly situations. Nonetheless, according to the Court the general approach pursued by the Commission regarding the concept of the important competitive force was inaccurate and pointing out that the Commission confined itself to finding that the undertaking in question had attributed to competition on the market and so de facto giving power to the Commission to disallow any horizontal merger in an oligopolistic market infringing the principle of legal certainty. To that extent, the perception of an important competitive force must be interpreted in such a manner that the removal of such a firm from the market eliminates an imperative competitive constraint and so fulfilling the significant impediment to the effective competition test. Thus, in order to qualify as an important competitive force, the firm in question needs to stand out from its competitors in terms of influence on competition.

The Commission's horizontal guidelines clarify that products may be differentiated within a relevant market such that some products are closer substitutes than others and so rivalry between the parties has been an imperative source of competition on the market being a key factor in the analysis of the competitive effects of a merger. Furthermore, analogous to the "important competitive force" concept, "closeness of competition" is an argument that the Commission employs to raise competition points in oligopoly markets. The Court sets out that the horizontal merger guidelines must be read in light of recital 25 of the merger control regulation, which demands the removal of key competitive constraints the merging parties had exerted upon each other. While in oligopolistic markets everyone is close to some degree, closeness is relevant if it causes a competitive constraint and so the parties must be "particularly close" competitors. The Court found that the Commission had failed to provide evidence that the merging parties met this requirement by disputing whether the products on the mobile telephone market are sufficiently differentiated to generate relevant effects through "closeness of competition." If firms on the market are somehow "close" is not enough since any four-to-three mergers could be outlawed.

The Commission further supported its decision with a quantitative economic analysis reminding that “the transaction is likely to generate an incentive for the merged entity to significantly increase prices.” The Commission had applied a GUPPI (Gross Upward Pricing Pressure Index) analysis assessing the upward pricing pressure following a merger based on diversion ratios and margins of the parties, taking into account (unlike the basic UPP-test) the likely reactions of competitors. The Court specified that the analysis applied by the Commission was sophisticated and generally a suitable tool for the analysis but it identified that the Commission did not consider the quantitative analysis as decisive evidence not illustrating that a quantified price increase would be substantial which means that the Commission must prove any increase with a high degree of probability. Consequently, when the Commission uses quantitative analyses, it must take into consideration all the relevant factors influencing the price level, involving standard efficiencies that could arise from the merger. Hence, the Court explained that these standard efficiencies as a part of a quantitative model must be separated from specific efficiencies, which are taken into consideration in the overall competitive evaluation of the concentration, so as to determine whether they are expected to counteract the restrictive consequences of the concentration. To that extent, the Commission did not stipulate whether the non-coordinated consequences identified would be “significant” or would result in a significant impediment to effective competition in the present case.

The Court made clear that the reasoning of the Commission was too speculative not assessing the influence on competition and competitors by re-stating that EU competition rules are principally intended to protect the competitive process as such, and not competitors. Moreover, the Court states that the EU Merger Regulation permits the Commission to catch anticompetitive mergers in non-dominant cases, but that in such cases the Commission must deliver convincing evidence that the merger will lead to the removal of vital competitive constraints resulting in a noteworthy impediment to effective competition. Furthermore, the Court refined that the Commission must produce convincing evidence to demonstrate with a strong possibility the existence of noteworthy impediments to competition following the concentration.

Also, the Court found that the Commission failed to show that the consequences of the merger on the UK's network-sharing agreements and on the mobile network infrastructure in the UK would establish a noteworthy impediment to effective competition. The Commission had failed to ascertain that the acquisition would have harmed competition or that prices would have increased.<sup>13</sup>

<sup>13</sup>Judgment of the General Court (First Chamber, Extended Composition) 28 May 2020 ECLI:EU:T:2020:217, Council Regulation (EC) No. 139/2004 of 20 January 2004 on the control of concentration between undertakings, OJ L 24, 29.1.2004.

Finally, the ECJ<sup>14</sup> recently decided that in order to block a merger or require remedies, the European Commission needs to show based on a “cogent and consistent body of evidence” that a merger “more likely than not” will result in a significant impediment to effective competition (SIEC).

The EUMR enables an efficient allocation of resources and a consistent merger review.<sup>15</sup> It is worth noting that the Court explained that Article 2(3) EUMR must be interpreted narrowly permitting the Commission to outlaw mergers in oligopolistic markets only in situations where the merger is influencing competitive conditions to an extent identical to the effect of individual or collective dominance. Thus, a significant impediment to effective competition must have a noteworthy influence on competition, similar to the impact that would take place if a dominant position were to arise which means that a prohibition as a result of a significant impediment to effective competition is only possible if the concentration would result in the elimination of a firm which extensively impedes the scope of action of the other participants in the market. Because of the higher requirements for proof involved, complex concentration proceedings in such markets will lead to even greater procedural expense and so the Commission has to collect and assess even more data than it already does now.

Undoubtedly, like US law, there is discretion in enforcement, and even within sensible constraints the EU is more suspicious of large mergers. Obviously, the political objectives of competition enforcement embrace concerns for unifying the single market, involving the consequences that markets have on labor broadly speaking. Besides, US competition law depends on demanding economic analysis. Moreover, the US Supreme Court has distinguished the limitations that courts face in differentiating between pro- and anticompetitive conduct in antitrust cases, and predominantly the risk this generates of reaching false positive decisions in monopolization cases.<sup>16</sup>

The EU’s more “precautionary” approach to antitrust policy is embedded in a belief that markets do not or are unlikely to function well in general, and definitely not appropriate to self-correct in the face of monopolization. The precautionary principle comes at the expense of short-term growth which means that by approving a precautionary approach, a costly public policy in those instances is not clearly warranted by underlying risk and uncertainty.<sup>17</sup> The precautionary principles denote

that policymakers should exclude certain mutually advantageous transactions on account of the social costs that they might inflict further down the line. Additionally, the precautionary principle has been correlated with anti-growth positions.<sup>18</sup> The Google Shopping decision reveals evidence that removing existing barriers to competition enforcement in the digital economy leads to harm to consumers.<sup>19</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that the nonexistence of consumer harm so as to find antitrust injury is not incidental, but signifies a central alteration of antitrust enforcement, mainly when it comes to big tech firms and so together with the lack of clear knowledge, a modification in the burden of proof, and the lack of a consumer harm requirement with the intention of finding abuse of dominance all reveal the precautionary approach that the European Commission has now accepted.<sup>20</sup> European competition law is much more reliant on structural presumptions and precautionary reasoning. To that extent, the German competition authority attempted to use its antitrust authority to impose on consumers its distinctive political preferences.<sup>21</sup>

Of course, no one believes that markets are perfect, or that antitrust enforcement can never be appropriate. What is the function of the market in the modern economy, and particularly in high-growth, emerging economies? While US antitrust law involves a full-blown, effects-based analysis of challenged behavior in the context of monopolization or abuse of dominance and vertical restraints, the EU relies heavily upon presumptions of harm or extremely shortened analysis. Also, while US monopolization law bans only predatory or exclusionary conduct resulting in both the unlawful acquisition or maintenance of monopoly power and the making of net harm to consumers, the EU punishes the simple exercise of monopoly power such as the charging of “excessive” prices by dominant corporations or the use of “exploitative” business terms which means that the EU is punishing the simple

Coupled with the lack of clear knowledge, a shift in the burden of proof, and the lack of a consumer harm requirement in order to find abuse of dominance all reveal the precautionary approach that the European Commission has now embraced.”).

extraction of rents by a lawfully obtained dominant firm, while the US punishes only the unlawful extension of market power. Even the EU's highest court has acknowledged the paucity of the Commission's analysis in this area in its Intel decision.<sup>22</sup>

The GC in Michelin II (Case T-203/01) dealt with the anticompetitive effect of loyalty rebates considered sufficient to show that the abusive conduct of the dominant company “tends to” restrict competition or the conduct “is capable of” having that effect. Thus, for the purposes of applying Article 102, “establishing the anticompetitive object and the anticompetitive effect are one and the same thing.” On January 26, 2022, the European General Court (GC) partially annulled a 2009 European Commission (Commission) decision, in which the Commission noticed that Intel had abused its dominant position by implementing a strategy of eliminating its competitors from the market. Thus, the Commission should have analyzed the consequences of Intel's conduct when evaluating whether it had infringed Article 102 of the Treaty on the TFEU.<sup>23</sup> Moreover, the GC noticed that the Commission's decision concerning the exclusivity rebates at issue was based on an error of law since it had considered Intel's rebates as automatically anticompetitive, and so had concluded that no effects analysis was needed to establish an abuse. In addition, the GC noticed that the Commission had failed to take into account all the relevant criteria required for an effects analysis such as the criterion relating to the share of the market covered by the rebates.<sup>24</sup> Hence, the European Courts will not uphold Commission decisions where the needed legal and evidentiary analysis is lacking.

The judgment demonstrates that the European Courts look in detail at evidence and economic analysis in antitrust cases, and will annul EC decisions if they do not undertake an effects-based analysis or if their economic analysis has errors. Thus, the analysis must establish legal standards concerning anticompetitive effects which means that the EC must support its infringement decisions with rigorous effects-based assessment, and not count on a formalistic approach grounded on “presumptions” of competitive harm. In other words, exclusivity rebates cannot be assumed to be an abuse of dominance once evidence is put to the EC of the absence of anticompetitive foreclosure. Furthermore, firms can count on economic analysis to evaluate the antitrust compliance of their rebate schemes, while the EC must endorse rigorous and careful analysis of anticompetitive foreclosure consequences. It could be said that there is a massive financial risk for European Union regulators when they lose challenges to antitrust fines.

It is characteristic that there is pressure in competition law between the wish for legal certainty as to the categories of behavior that will give rise to infringements,

and the demand to evaluate the influence of such behavior in context to settle whether it has anticompetitive effects.

Is there a difference between the USA and the EU with regard to antitrust? As mentioned earlier, the difference between the USA and the EU with regard to the reliance on presumptions in antitrust cases is the relative adherence of the US regime to economic principles and their relative disregard for the EU.<sup>25</sup> There is a divergence concerning the quantification of anticompetitive harm, where European competition law compels a much less vigorous burden on authorities than does US law and so it seems that there is a failure of the EU's "competitive process" standard to separate competitive from anticompetitive exclusionary conduct in line with established economic principles. Moreover, compared to the USA, European competition law has recognized a wider set of per se prohibitions and sets a lower bar for plaintiffs to establish the existence of anticompetitive conduct.

Where US case law is steered by maximizing consumer welfare, EU competition law favors structural presumptions and places a much heavier weight on distributional considerations. Hence, US antitrust is undisturbed with firms that charge what some might consider "excessive" prices and so the plain possession of monopoly power, and the simultaneous charging of monopoly prices, is not only not unlawful; it is an imperative part of the free market system.<sup>26</sup> To that extent, charging monopoly prices is what magnetizes "business acumen" in the first place, encouraging risk taking generating innovation and economic growth. Besides, companies infringe EU competition law for the reason that they charge "excessive" prices<sup>27</sup> and so the ECJ held that charging a price which is excessive since it has no reasonable relation to the economic value of the product supplied is an abuse.

US antitrust law instructs allegations of predatory pricing to two strict conditions: (a) Monopolists must charge prices that are below some measure of their incremental costs and (b) there must be a realistic possibility that they will able to regain these first-period losses.<sup>28</sup> In the EU, the competition rules are in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Merger Regulation offering a broad framework of general applicability, binding on the member states, their citizens through the doctrine of direct effect, the member states of the EEA, and other preferred trading partners of the EU. The EU has crafted block exemptions, de minimis limitations to the normal competition rules.<sup>29</sup> It has to be taken into account that European competition enforcement is accountable to political forces pursuing to

preserve the overall political legitimacy of the European Union. Moreover, competition policy is one of the topics where the Commission has exclusive competence and action in this field is crucial to the success of the growth agenda steering innovation and delivering clear benefits to consumers, businesses, and society as a whole.<sup>30</sup> The EU enforcement agencies are not constrained because of their clearly political function and the EU courts have eventually exposed EU competition law to amplified politicization.

The US structure, although molded by the political process through the election of Congress and the president confirmed the senior-most antitrust enforcement officials, is nonetheless largely insulated from direct political concerns. Moreover, the roles of the Department of Justice and the FTC are to impartially manage the laws written by Congress, as interpreted over time and a great number of cases by the courts. Undeniably there is policy-oriented decision-making taking place by US enforcement officials and the US administration's evident politicization of antitrust enforcement is brought to light by the testimony of a whistle blower.<sup>31</sup> Also, politicization of antitrust enforcement in the United States is limited in the first instance by the structure of the US system via the judiciary's strong check on political influences.

As mentioned earlier, Congress designed the antitrust laws to favor enforcement by catching certain anticompetitive practices. The Sherman Act involves a delegation of lawmaking power by Congress to the courts covering the field of antitrust. Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act prohibit broad but definable categories of anticompetitive agreements and monopolization. In contrast, Sections 3 and 7 of the Clayton Act and Section 5 of the FTC Act are more elastic. Section 7 of the Clayton Act broadly forbids mergers and acquisitions where the outcome “may” tend to significantly lessen competition. Likewise, Section 3 of the Clayton Act disallows tying and exclusive dealing agreements where their effect also “may” tend to significantly lessen competition. Section 5 of the FTC Act takes a different line, outlawing unfair methods of competition and filling certain gaps in those statutes. Congress also has customized antitrust through statutory exemptions and immunities, granted for a variety of industries, from medical schools to soft drink bottlers to newspaper publishers.<sup>32</sup>

It has to be taken into account that the Sherman Act is taking affirmative steps to contain domination, to accommodate and promote democratic coordination, and to set rules of fair competition. Thus, the Sherman Act authorizes courts to generate

new lines of law<sup>33</sup> and so the Sherman Act invites the federal courts to articulate a set of rules that will make them work in socially resourceful manners. Sanjukta Paul<sup>34</sup> states that “judges have arrogated to themselves the power to invent the criteria by which antitrust law will govern the economy, claiming all the while that Congress delegated this power of reinvention to them through the Sherman Act itself.” It could be said that the Sherman Act is planned to stop unfair business methods so as to promote competitive markets.

The content of competition law concerning competition itself in the EU encompasses objectives that are far more ambiguous than those pursued under US antitrust law. While antitrust law in the US currently pursues the maximization of consumer welfare, the European Union has been reluctant to commit to a well-defined competition objective for its antitrust law. Furthermore, whereas the USA is steered by the consumer welfare standard, the objectives of European competition enforcers are both diverse and often freed from economic thinking. To that extent, the US Supreme Court has developed jurisprudence limiting provisions to certain practices that restrict consumer welfare.<sup>35</sup> Moreover, the courts have allowed defendants to argue that the competitive outcomes of a specific arrangement are not harmful to competition for the reason that the special characteristics of the product, the industry, or the corporations in question.<sup>36</sup> In Microsoft’s decision, the court adopted a rule of reason for tying, but only for the software industry.<sup>37</sup>

Recently, FTC has communicated its wish to move toward some custom tailoring to deal with problems that might lie beyond the bounds of the Sherman and Clayton Acts. litigation, such as unfair data collection and “unfair competition in major Internet marketplaces.”<sup>41</sup> While public attention in the USA has focused on increased market concentration, lessening competition, and rising economic inequality, the US Congress and enforcement agencies are facing escalating calls to strengthen the antitrust laws and their enforcement and so need to reconsider its approach to antitrust policy.<sup>42</sup>

It seems that EU competition law has been focused on “an increased role of economics in competition law,” with emphasis placed on the promotion of economic efficiency and consumer welfare and so the goal of EU antitrust law has concentrated on consumer welfare emphasizing the effects-based analysis and the central role of the efficiency defense but market integration stays important.<sup>43</sup> On mergers, the European Commission’s approach is similar to the USA’s favoring of a more effects-based analysis of anticompetitive behavior but considering per se illegal certain types of conduct that are per se legal in the USA. Moreover, UNCTAD documents the shift in EU antitrust policy from a form-based to a more effects-based approach relying on economic analysis.<sup>44</sup>

Digital conglomerates are shaped owing to market power formed via predatory pricing and high levels of diversification.<sup>45</sup> Anyway, the EU disputes vertical and conglomerate mergers contrary to the Chicago School’s principles that emphasize these types of mergers’ pro-competitive effects and so vertical agreements that contain territorial restrictions or restrict the resale price of goods or services often lead to per se antitrust liability in the EU. Also, the EU treats exclusionary conduct by dominant corporations with suspicion of pursuing these companies’ tying, discounting, exclusive dealing, along with predatory, discriminatory, or unfair pricing practices. Anu Bradford<sup>46</sup> et al. argue that “the EU shows it has not relinquished its rather ‘maximalist’ approach to antitrust, which is antithetical to the Chicago School’s antitrust minimalism.”

There are high-level differences between the EU and US approaches to competition policy. To that extent, the whole structure of an approach to antitrust law in the EU vests the Commission with much greater discretion to diverge from established economic principles and procedural best practices in its antitrust enforcement and

Thus, antitrust enforcement at the EU level is driven almost entirely by the European Commission, a political body, and largely unreviewed and unchecked by EU courts<sup>47</sup> and so EU antitrust is less economically grounded, and unavoidably more politicized, than in the USA. Even though the EU's approach to competition policy appears close to that of the USA, it is diverging in the economic reasoning that underpins US antitrust law and divergences between EU and US law point to a number of key matters where the EU approach undermines consumers and constrain the region's economic growth. While the US concentrates on protecting the process of competition for the economic welfare of consumers, the EU has built and maintains its competition laws to affect a wider range of political/economic/social objectives. Undeniably, the Commission has usually stated that European competition law pursues multiple objectives. To that extent, the European Commission<sup>48</sup> found that Google's online search services favor its own shopping service over competing shopping services and so Google had infringed Article 102 TFEU in relation to the national markets for specialized search services in 13 countries.

Which is the approach concerning Hub-and-Spoke Arrangements under EU Competition Rules and the USA? Online gig platforms are data-driven business models that utilize and develop algorithms and AI tools that learn from user behavior and adapt to make interactions more and more efficient enabling users to sell their labor or services to other users via the platforms.<sup>49</sup> The pricing algorithms play an imperative role in generating the efficiencies that platforms offer but competition issues occur once the platform steps in and coordinate prices, either by suggesting prices or by fixing prices centrally. Article 101 (1) TFEU distinguishes between by-object and by-effect restrictions of competition. Under EU competition law, hub-and-spoke arrangements facilitating price fixing between competitors are as illegal as entirely horizontal cartels.<sup>50</sup> Moreover, the coordination of transaction parameters by the platform is likely to have procompetitive effects.<sup>51</sup>

Algorithms examine pricing and quantities of products and services in a given market through data analysis and so by scrutinizing data identify patterns designating anticompetitive conduct such as market segmentation or price fixing.

EU competition law still considers certain vertical restraints with suspicion and apart from the general rule of Article 101 (1) TFEU, the Vertical Block Exemption Regulation (VBER) specifies which categories of vertical restraints are expected to be found contrary to Article 101 (1) TFEU, and which categories of vertical

Under the present state of US law, such a vertical price fix is illegal only if it leads to harm to consumers, signalled in price increases or quality reduction.<sup>54</sup> Also, a horizontal conspiracy among book publishers, orchestrated by Apple in fixing the price of e-books distributed through e-readers implicates competition law due to pricing influences.<sup>55</sup>

It is worth noting that e-commerce together with AI systems instantly and continuously identifies the behavior of other market participants, mainly the alteration in their supply, depriving competitive uncertainty. Wherever data on competitors' behavior and their prices is available for processing by AI in competitor's service, market transparency and familiarity with how competitors are acting in the market will be the normal state of affairs. It is worth noting that transparency of online markets, the availability of data on the behavior of competitors in them, and at the same time the capabilities of algorithms in the service of enterprises are elements contributing to the influence of AI on competition. It is worth mentioning here that the non-negotiated price collusion via algorithmic price parallelism generates the ability of a company to rapidly follow every move of its competitors and so non-contact behavior is not covered by the prohibitions of Section 1 of the Sherman Act and Article 101(1) TFEU.<sup>56</sup> Also, algorithms are used to monitor prices agreed

AI makes such a non-negotiated collusion achievable between numbers of corporations instantaneously and sustainable over a longer period of time than under “classical” conditions of competitive uncertainty.<sup>57</sup> Furthermore, AI technology is assessing whether differences in bidders’ bids show standardized differences in parameters, structural and wording similarities in descriptions that would indicate collusion.<sup>58</sup>

It is worth mentioning here that the Australian Competition and Consumer Act of 2010 in Section 46 makes enterprises profiting from collusion punishable for harm to competition even without having to deliver evidence of their collusive behavior which means that a corporation benefiting from having used a specific algorithm leading to price coordination with competitors is liable without its people having involved in any exchange of signals, information, offers, and acceptances.<sup>59</sup> Consequently, companies utilizing and employing an anticompetitive algorithm would be liable for the algorithm acting independently in the same way as if their employee had acted against rules of competition. Enforcement of competition law encompasses trade-offs between the risk that pro-competitive conduct will mistakenly be found anticompetitive and the risk that anticompetitive behavior will mistakenly be found not to be so. Moreover, the scope of Section 46 is limited to those markets in which the corporation’s conduct is most likely to have a purpose, effect, or likely effect of competition concern.<sup>60</sup> Likewise, vertical restrictions will not significantly diminish competition unless they are imposed by a company with substantial market power.<sup>61</sup>

## 6.4 Developments on Competition Law

Section 2 of the Sherman Act prohibits “monopolization,” involving a higher level of power than EU “abuse of dominance” (Article 102 TFEU). Also, EU Article 102 covers exploitative conduct such as charging excessive prices along with exclusionary acts, while Section 2 covers only exclusionary acts. Furthermore, Article 102 disallows exclusionary acts distorting competition on the merits, such as leveraging by gatekeeping platforms to secure advantages, while Section 2 disallows only exclusionary acts augmenting market power and harming consumers, classically evidenced by higher prices and lower output.<sup>62</sup> There are market competitors bigger than nations having significant power, which may not count as monopoly power under Sherman Act precedents, and documented abuses are either exploitative or distortive of competition on the merits without lessening output which means that the Sherman Act has “blind spots,” and many dominant firm abuses fall within them.

US Supreme Court case law specified that business, when it is performed individually and not in combination with competitors, almost always operates in the interests of consumers. Moreover, the Supreme Court has re-made Section 2 jurisprudence in the libertarian image, and the stance of the Court is not anticipated to adjust unless and until Congress changes it<sup>63</sup> which means that Section 2 of the Sherman Act makes it very hard for a plaintiff to evidence that a violator has adequate power to pass the first screen of the monopolization violation and so the US Section 2 jurisprudence makes it hard to prove conduct that violates the Sherman Act.<sup>64</sup> It has to be taken into consideration that US antitrust law considers that large size alone cannot be an antitrust offense and so according to Section 2 plain possession of monopoly power, or the pursuit of it, is not in itself illegal.<sup>65</sup>

In the USA, the dominant formulation of goals of antitrust is narrow due to consumer welfare in the interests of efficiency.<sup>66</sup> EU competition law values undistorted market processes allowing markets to work better, dealing with consumers but not exclusively which means flexibility in controlling abuses.<sup>67</sup> Antitrust

Taking into account that behaviors such as excessive pricing and refusal to supply generate prospective concerns if a firm is dominant, in Germany ARC-Digitization Act<sup>69</sup> has expanded the range of review involving abuse of relative market power and economic dependence and so the new law has diminished the likelihood of a merger control filing in Germany by raising the turnover thresholds to EUR 50 and 17.5 million. Moreover, an abuse of economic dependence is an anticompetitive practice prohibited under French law as well<sup>70</sup> and so it seems that the FCA fined Apple due to the fact of abusing economic dependence by discriminating against premium resellers in terms of supply in comparison to Apple-owned stores and bigger retailers.

It has to be taken into account that competition law is oriented in protecting the competitive process in markets but it seems that EU competition law more narrowly counts on economic evidence focused on welfare effects.<sup>71</sup> Additionally, in many jurisdictions, competition law is essentially tied to economics in a way of comprehending them as the main reasoning for competition law.<sup>72</sup>

Resembling the gradual transition to rule of reason in the USA, the Commission employs a soft reform of its approach to competition law enforcement, rather than amending the competition law articles of the EU treaties and triggering conflict with established CJEU case law. Hence, the Commission suggested its enforcement priorities departing from blanket prohibitions to a case-by-case, effects-based approach.<sup>73</sup>

Accordingly, the Commission's guidelines on cartel enforcement declare its rationale is to protect competition on the market as a way of boosting consumer welfare with an effective allocation of resources. Also, the Commission averts mergers that will deprive customers of low prices, high-quality products, and innovation by considerably increasing the market power of corporations.

It has to be taken into account that acquiring a corporation with better access to data creates comparative advantages by allowing a company to benefit from synergies, not mentioning that applying more efficient algorithms developed by one

Concerning abuse of dominance by corporations, the Commission points out that dominant undertakings should not impair effective competition by excluding their competitors in an anticompetitive manner and so imposing unfavorable consequences on consumer welfare via higher prices, limiting quality, or slashing consumer choice.<sup>77</sup> Thus, it seems that the Commission concentrates on the economic effects of anticompetitive conduct and so anticompetitive behavior is sanctioned when finding negative consequences on consumer welfare. It has to be taken into account that the legal foundation of the VBER lies in Article 101 TFEU banning agreements between companies that avert, restrict, or distort competition. While Article 101 TFEU applies to horizontal cartel agreements between direct competitors, fixing prices and/or output to the detriment of consumers, CJEU defines that Article 101 TFEU also applies to agreements between companies in a vertical relation. Moreover, While the European Commission defines that vertical restraints are less destructive than horizontal restraints, the prohibition of anticompetitive agreements in the TFEU is subject to an accumulative set of exemptions in Article 101(3) that are hard to meet for defendant companies which means that the Commission has advanced a system of block exemptions for vertical agreements.<sup>81</sup> The Commission demands economic evidence in assessing the effectiveness of the VBER.<sup>82</sup> It is worth mentioning that many of the consequences attached to platforms are similar to what takes place via vertical integration or control.<sup>83</sup>

As an answer to the rise of dominant online platforms, National Competition Authorities and legislatures developed differentiated approaches toward MFN clauses of platforms like Amazon and Booking.com, negatively influencing legal certainty.<sup>84</sup> Most Favored Nation clauses (MFN—“price parity clauses”) compel retailers to operate brick and mortar stores, banning sales through online platforms and executing “recommended” resale prices and so MFN clauses are agreements between a supplier and a retailer whereby the supplier assures the retailer equally favorable conditions as related to all other retailers the supplier embraces.<sup>85</sup> In 2021, the EU decided that Google abused its dominant position in the market for specialized product search services by demonstrating a preference for its own comparison shopping service in general search results over third-party content.<sup>86</sup>

It has to be taken into account that anticompetitive behavior of digital platforms is caught by general competition rules and so price discrimination grounded on data

It is worth mentioning here that the Chinese Anti-Monopoly Guidelines<sup>87</sup> specify the principles of market definition in the platform economy by encompassing a list of practices that are expected to raise competition-related concerns and so advocating a proper competition law response to those concerns. The Guidelines specify what is regarded an abuse of dominance in platform markets and so abuse of dominance is constituted by using a platform of the data collected on users or merchants to engage in price discrimination or differential treatment (Articles 15, 17). Moreover, the comparison of the Chinese Guidelines and the EU law reveals that the EU presently lacks a comprehensive device encapsulating what its competition law's position to digital platforms is. To that extent, the EU still largely counts on the case law of the CJEU and the decision-making practice of the Commission to refine how the traditional competition rules apply to digital platforms. On the other hand, Chinese Guidelines stipulate a thorough framework on what comprises an appropriate approach to the novel conduct.

The rule of reason context involves a three-step process and so firstly anticompetitive harm, secondly evidence of pro-competitive efficiencies and thirdly the benefits are achieved through less restrictive means.<sup>88</sup> Amex specified that the welfare of both the merchants and cardholders must be considered before anticompetitive harm can be ascertained.<sup>89</sup> It is worth noting that competition rules are evolving and there is an approach to the rule of reason matching it with per se analysis.<sup>90</sup>

## 7.1 Introduction

Initially, the founders of the US antitrust law chose between two institutional models of antitrust. In the corporate regulatory model, the capital-concentrating effects of general incorporation statutes would have been considered the subject of antitrust regulation and so the target of antitrust enforcement would have been to optimize market performance by specifying fitting corporate structure and behavior. The competing crime-tort model focuses on the corporation as the subject of antitrust regulation and the crime-tort model conceived of antitrust as a freestanding standard of industrial competition. The crime-tort model focused on discouraging and compensating for forbidden behavior. By breaking up antitrust law from corporate law, the crime-tort model sets free antitrust law on non-corporate subjects, embracing labor and professional associations that would not have been antitrust subjects in the corporate regulatory model. The crime-tort model produced vagueness as to the hierarchy between the state and the federal regulation of competition.

It is argued that competition is a process in the real world for business rivalry and so the concept of “competition,” supported by pre-Chicago judicial precedent and legislative history, expresses moment-to-moment business rivalry and not economic efficiency.<sup>1</sup>

<sup>1</sup>Harry S. Gerla, *Restoring Rivalry as a Central Concept in Antitrust Law*, 75 Neb. L. Rev. 209, 211–22 (1996)

## 7.2 Chicago School Versus Harvard School

To start with, the Chicago School project was justified in advancing the intention of a certain political-economic order, rather than simply an abstract commitment to an analytical framework. Hence, Chicago School thrived in persuading the federal courts to adopt a far narrower view of antitrust that has as its single objective the avoidance of economically incompetent transactions, mentioned by economists as “allocative efficiency.”<sup>2</sup>

Furthermore, the Chicago School view considers that monopolists should not be penalized for obtaining their market power owing to a superior product but in cases involving monopolists’ duty to deal, tying, and exclusive dealing, the more lenient Chicago School view confuses the standards of conduct for dominant companies. Post-Chicago School scholars have realized that monopolists such as Microsoft have an exclusive capacity to leverage the appeal of their networks to expand their market power into other markets or to preclude new companies from entering the market they have already monopolized. The Microsoft case did not present a structure for antitrust regulation that can be rigidly or realistically utilized for antitrust analyses of all high-technology companies. Thus, courts and regulators must recognize without losing sight of the ultimate purpose that technology not only influences antitrust analyses but also fosters competition. Concerning the Chicago School approach Sanjukta Paul<sup>3</sup> argues that “the relaxation of enforcement when it came to corporate mergers, monopolization, and vertical restraints, was the priority. And if one of the underlying political priorities of the Chicago School was to secure the power of concentrated capital, then price-fixing was the most obvious concession.”

It has to be taken into consideration that the spirit of the Harvard school’s view was that allowing a lot of small companies to exist adds to competition rather than a small number of companies. Under the “Harvard School” view, the courts and agencies accepted the illegality of any mergers, joint ventures, or agreements that allowed corporations to get, enhance, or exercise market power, notwithstanding whether the conduct had the prospective to benefit consumers by lowering prices or increasing output.<sup>4</sup> Under the “Chicago School” view, the courts and agencies became much less willing to prohibit competitive conduct on its face but they are involved in a wide factual inquiry to substantiate the consequences of specific conduct on consumers before finding it illegal. It has to be taken into account that it is difficult to prove the adverse economic consequences of specific types of

It could be said that a merger is basically a plain transaction including a sale or exchange. In *Northern Securities*<sup>10</sup> decision, in 1904, the Supreme Court held that the exchange violated the Sherman Act because the merger would eliminate competition between the railroads. Four judges dissented because they thought that *property rights* should be protected and that the merger should be permitted. Owners should have the right to sell or exchange their property. The four dissenters insisted that the antitrust law violated the constitutional protection of private property from government taking away.

Furthermore, the property logic that has shaped vertical restraints doctrine for the past 40 years awards various statuses to price restraints and non-price restraints, granting more moderate treatment to most non-price restraints providing the actual foundation for the dominant approach to vertical restraints. Until 1963, the Supreme Court treated competition as a unitary process and restraints as an undifferentiated notion. It was in the *White Motor Company*<sup>11</sup> case that the Supreme Court first held that manufacturers' non-price restraints on dealers would be treated more moderately than price restraints. The Court's differentiation between price and non-price restraints was the product of a change from viewing competition as a unitary process to seeing it as a bi-level process. White Motor developed a marketing strategy to compete on product quality and service encouraging its dealers to join it in non-price competition against the Big Three (General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler) by investing in brand development—better service and more inventory. White eliminated dealer competition, classically price competition, by limiting their geographic and customer markets. Besides, a vertical restraint between levels, one imposed by a manufacturer on its dealers below, was seen as potentially enhancing competition. It was the property logic of ownership of a brand and the images and ideas contained in it that led the Court to adopt this bi-level view of competition.

After *White Motor*, antitrust courts handled competition among dealers, characteristically price competition, as less critical than competition among manufacturers, often non-price competition. At the bottom was the determination that manufacturers

The number of corporations in the market and their relative sizes determine how efficiently corporations will function in that market. Oligopolists assess their output so that, together, they would be able to accomplish a profit-maximizing price approaching the monopoly level.<sup>45</sup> When markets are concentrated, companies are more expected to engage in anticompetitive conduct. There is a strong relationship between structure and performance.<sup>46</sup>

When Congress enacted the Sherman and Clayton Acts, it was concerned with the increasing economic and political power of trusts and a need to protect individual competitors from the market power wielded by large companies. Harvard scholars were contrary to market concentration, even when it might lower costs and prices, in so doing benefiting consumers. Any conduct by companies with market power is presumed illegal regardless of its effect on consumers. For instance, in *United States v. Aluminum Co. of America*,<sup>47</sup> the court held Alcoa liable for monopolizing the aluminum manufacturing market merely because taking advantage of economies of scale by expanding its manufacturing size to meet increasing demand, Alcoa was able to provide quality products to customers at low prices. Under the Harvard School approach, courts do not engage in a complicated analysis of the economic circumstances in the relevant market and so corporations in concentrated industries were successfully deterred from transactions that enlarged concentration levels in the relevant market. Thus, large corporations were precluded from engaging in a competitive manner that could have benefited consumers and would have been totally permissible for corporations with lower market shares. According to Chicago scholars, the antitrust laws were to protect individual competitors against large corporations' exercise of market power. Robert Bork<sup>49</sup> argued that the antitrust laws were designed only to augment the effectiveness of the American economy equating wealth improvement with "consumer welfare," meaning lower costs, reduced prices, and increased output of products and services desired by consumers. It has to be taken into consideration that the preservation of competition leads to consumer benefit as long as lets the market to work appropriately in a global sense favoring a global competitive market and not merely the consumers of a specific product or service against the interests of other groups of consumers/people. Exclusively "consumer welfare" cannot be the scope of competition without at the same time to preserve competition. Global dynamics such as environmental protection, freedom of choice, and innovation should be taken into consideration when we investigate the task of antitrust/competition law that of preserving/safeguarding antitrust/competition.

It is distinctive that Chicago School scholars argued that the Harvard School misapprehended the techniques in which corporations carry on to compete, even when they have fairly few rivals. In reality in concentrated markets, corporations try to find ways of competing with each other. Also, the Chicago School scholars<sup>53</sup> assumed that markets should be given a free rein in order for corporations to be more efficient. Furthermore, the courts should only interfere in the competitive route when it was understandable that anticompetitive conduct was threatening consumer welfare.<sup>54</sup> To that extent, courts have been inspired by the Chicago school view and insisted on proof of explicit anticompetitive effects before finding defendants’ conduct illegal notwithstanding the fact that a particular corporation or a group of competitors possessed striking market power and so plaintiffs would have to display, through empirical evidence, that the conduct at question harmed consumers by increasing prices or decreasing output.<sup>55</sup> Consequently, courts become more moderate in allowing corporations to obtain and exercise market power. This approach let the Supreme Court to refuse to presume the illegality of a price-fixing agreement among a group of musical composers and Microsoft was allowed to carry on to force its monopoly in the computer operating system market into related markets for word processing, Internet access, video and audio services, and instant messaging.<sup>56</sup>

It could be argued that a rule of reason, rather than a per se, method was fitting in light of the prospective economic benefits of the location clause imposed by Sylvania. Hence, *Sylvania* established the basis for modern antitrust dependence on empirical economic evidence.

It is characteristic that fewer competitors in a market stipulate an easier way of coordinating their pricing without committing detectable violations of Section 1 of the Sherman Act.<sup>75</sup>

It could be said that the Chicago School view regarding economic efficiencies as a mitigating factor in merger cases is not a panacea in spite of the fact that mergers may achieve economies of scale, synergies, or cost savings that will enable the parties to offer lower prices to consumers because in fact competition among corporations might not exist. Under the Harvard School approach, the courts precluded conduct by corporations that were only attempting to gain or preserve a monopoly position in the relevant market. Nonetheless, the courts following the approach of the Chicago School recognized that corporations should not be punished purely for obtaining monopoly power. Enterprises often obtain power because they are the most successful in delivering the products and services desired by consumers and so courts do not find monopolists liable under the Sherman Act unless they had engaged in some type of offensive competitive conduct. Farrell, Katz, & Martin<sup>82</sup> argue that in search of boosting consumer welfare is the best way to amplify total welfare in practice.

It has to be taken into account that Section 2 of the Sherman Act bars monopolization, or attempts to monopolize, by individual businesses. Poor economic performance is predictable in monopoly markets and, until the late 1960s, courts became willing to find monopolists liable, even if they had not engaged in any exclusionary conduct. According to the workable competition model, antitrust law should not interdict the employment of monopoly or market power attained via legitimate competition to compel high prices, other than forbidding the utilization of such power to exclude rivals. Meese*,<sup>89</sup> “the “market power” model is a manifestation of neoclassical price theory and its workable competition model, economic frameworks that dominated industrial organization for much of the twentieth century.” Also, Chicago School & Harvard School theorists coincide in the view that corporations employed market power to impose exclusionary agreements and in fact offered a more precise account of what such imposition compelled. It could be argued that price theory, and not Legal Realism, is the basis of the market power model of contract formation and derived antitrust doctrines. On the other hand, recognition that voluntary exclusionary rights agreements engender anticompetitive damage challenges the Chicago School embracing that the possession of preexisting market power is an essential condition for antitrust liability under § 1 of the Sherman Act. In addition, courts rely upon a “market power” account of exclusionary contracts when condemning a monopolist for, say, “willful maintenance” of its power.<sup>90</sup> The Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice<sup>91</sup> alleges that a defendant “abused its monopoly power . . . through its exclusionary contracts” and that “[e]ach exclusionary contract” entailed willful exploitation of that power.

It is worth noting that Chicago School scholars think that monopolists should not be liable purely for engaging in conduct that is a natural end result of their market power assuming that corporations customarily acquire monopoly power because of their capacity to provide consumers with superior products at low prices. It is worth noting that under an exclusive dealing arrangement, a corporation compels a customer or supplier to deal only with it and not to deal with its competitors and regardless of the anticompetitive effects of monopolists' exclusive dealing arrangements, the courts allowed a permissive approach to such conduct.<sup>98</sup> An exclusive dealing arrangement constitutes a predominantly effective means of excluding its competitors from the relevant market. It is obvious that buyers or sellers are frozen out of a market by exclusive deals. Buyers will not take on exclusive deals that preclude competition since by construction, such contracts will lower the entire surplus accessible to buyers. Industry profit under monopoly is superior under competition and downstream companies sign exclusive contracts to limit competition by preventing efficient entry raising the joint profit of the present and downstream competitors, and so the "surplus" that is offered to the companies for signing contracts.<sup>99</sup> When downstream competition is limited, gains under monopoly are limited by double marginalization so that downstream companies do better not signing contracts and buying from a competitive upstream market. The demand of a single downstream company is enough to cover the entrant's fixed costs since final consumers will switch to the cheaper downstream company and intense downstream competition eradicates the incumbent's capacity to keep out even if it offers discriminatory or sequential contracts. Monopolists prevent actual or potential competitors from accessing the resources required to compete in the monopolized market or in a related market to which it is attempting to extend its monopoly power. It is characteristic that when less than thirty to forty percent of the suppliers or customers in an individual market have been subject to an exclusive dealing arrangement, the courts have been hesitant to find an antitrust violation which means in fact alteration of the meaning of competition.<sup>100</sup> Monopolists escape liability for an exclusive dealing arrangement merely by demonstrating that they did not exclude a rival from a substantial percentage of accessible suppliers or customers.

Even though tying and exclusive dealing arrangements have analogous competitive effects, the federal courts have applied a per se approach to tying arrangements and monopolists frequently have been found to hold in illegal tying arrangements

The Harvard School's view of illegality discourages beneficial competitive conduct and makes no economic sense for the courts to suppose the illegality of certain agreements among competitors that are designed to improve their effectiveness, in this manner, benefiting consumers. In merger and joint venture cases brought under Section 7 of the Clayton Act, the Harvard School was preoccupied with the parties' market influence, and it caused courts to neglect the prospective efficiencies resulting from the integration of rivals' resources. In monopoly cases under Section 2 of the Sherman Act, the Harvard School view excluded large businesses from engaging in antagonistic competitive conduct that could have benefited consumers.

When the *rule of reason* succeeded the per se rule as the prevailing method in restraint of trade litigation, antitrust cases became more complicated and their result became more difficult to forecast and so antitrust enforcement under Section 1 of the Sherman Act lost much of its restraint outcome. The Chicago School view considers that monopolists should not be penalized for obtaining their market power owing to a superior product but in cases involving monopolists' duty to deal, tying, and exclusive dealing, the more lenient Chicago School view confuses the standards of conduct for dominant companies.

On the one hand, in *California Dental*,<sup>108</sup> the court held that the restrictions should be analyzed under the quick look because they made it “more difficult for consumers to find a lower price and for dentists to compete on the basis of price.” On the other hand, the Supreme Court held that a quick look analysis was not suitable, since it was not spontaneously clear that the advertising restrictions were possible to have anticompetitive effects because the restrictions might have promoted competition by eliminating misleading and unverifiable discount advertising. ## 7.3 Post-Chicago School

It is worth mentioning here that the post-Chicago School relied on more complex forms of analysis, embracing game theoretic models of firm behavior enabling the identification of anticompetitive behavior. Hence, while the use of game theory and the study of strategic interaction are not new and have been used in Chicago School antitrust analyses, the post-Chicago School certainly emphasizes game theory generating specific testable hypotheses and empirical testing of these models. “Neo-Chicagoans” demonstrate the economy as an equilibrium system in which corporations have equal initial access to technology, capital, and information, and compete for advantage through product and cost-efficiency.

It has to be taken into consideration that “Neo-Chicagoans” count on studies of rising output in the digital zone to illustrate economic efficiency so as to rationalize a blanket laissez-faire approach. To that extent, issues like privacy loss or excessive ad load are ignored comprehending that rational users freely trade their privacy in exchange for free goods and services and so targeted advertisement made available by large digital corporations is considered as an informational advancement.

It could be said that the post-Chicago School does not condemn monopoly power per se, but only monopoly power that is obtained or maintained by anticompetitive means but promoting the consumer welfare standard.

## 7.4 Populists and Competition

It has to be taken into account that markets are imperfectly competitive in some way, whether it be as a result of economies of scale, imperfect information, or impediments to entry. Moreover, markets diverge in their information flows and transparency and the difficulty of detecting defections diverges accordingly.

It is worth mentioning here that populists are troubled about the political power of large corporations suggesting the deconcentrating of the economy in order to diminish their power and so opening up opportunities for small companies, helping

It seems that “Chicago Economics” does not display any coherent set of principles or techniques. Hovenkamp and Morton<sup>125</sup> provide that “Antitrust enforcement turns monopoly markets into competitive ones, corporate profit into consumer surplus, and is therefore a public good. As with any public good, it tends to be underprovided.” It is argued that there is a need of generating a number of rebuttable presumptions permitting antitrust plaintiffs to shift the burden of proof to defendants.<sup>126</sup>

While the Chicago School focused on overall efficiency and total welfare embracing the aggregate welfare of consumers and producers, modern antitrust law has focused specifically on consumer welfare. Under the modern consumer welfare standard, antitrust law has advanced principally high output and low prices.<sup>127</sup>

## 7.5 New Brandeis Movement

Justice Louis Brandeis was a strong proponent of a democratic distribution of power and opportunity in the political economy.<sup>128</sup> Thus, concentrated private power can destabilize democracy itself, when left unrestricted.

It has to be taken into account that an open and competitive market has prevailed in the United States. It has to be taken into account that the framers of the antitrust laws sought to prevent large unjust wealth transfers from producers and consumers to large corporations by safeguarding open markets and augmenting freedom of opportunity for new and small companies.<sup>129</sup>

It seems that Neo Brandeisians based on all “big is bad” visualize all large digital corporations.<sup>135</sup>

Economics and the consumer welfare standard were a direct response utilized by courts and regulators to settle the “conflicting and incoherent results” of then-antitrust enforcement and so courts are placing a greater emphasis on economic tools and credible evidence of anticompetitive effects, rather than bright-line rules and presumptions. Jonathan Baker Et Al<sup>136</sup> argue that “Courts have contributed to increased monopoly power through decisions that have weakened the prohibitions against anticompetitive exclusionary conduct and anticompetitive mergers.” It is characteristic that Neo-Brandeisians regard the consumer welfare standard as “fundamentally flawed” discarding economics and evidence-based policy as a foundation for antitrust enforcement.<sup>137</sup> New Brandeisians back “bright-line rules” to demarcate anticompetitive conduct without concern to whether that conduct harms consumers. It could be said that the Neo-Brandeisian school gives too little regard to markets and consumer-serving qualities of business strategies.

The New Brandeisians argue that the US antitrust laws had their origins in broader concerns about economic power and inequality, and do not identify the promotion of consumer welfare or any kind of solely economic welfare as their objective. To that extent, the New Brandeis movement rejects the understanding that

## 8.1 Introduction

Formalism illustrates what it means to apply a rule, the vagueness of the most important statutory competition law provisions makes non-formalistic, purpose-based reasoning indispensable in forming more specific substantive legal tests turning into rule-like and applied formalistically. For instance, the ECJ formed a rule that describes an “undertaking” for the purpose of Articles 101 and 102 TFEU as “every entity engaged in an economic activity, regardless of the legal status of the entity and the way in which it is financed.”<sup>1</sup> A legal formalism prescribes courts to apply that legal formalism rather than deciding on the basis of all relevant considerations. Courts have always found ways to avert the formalistic application of rules. In US antitrust law, the per se prohibition of certain types of business conduct appears to be a typical example of a legal formalism. Per se rules are formalistic for the reason that assigning the conduct to the relevant class is done on the basis of the straightforward meaning of the class, without investigating whether it is justified to do so. Per se rules reveal that legal formalism is both constraining and liberating.

It has to be taken into account the degree to which per se rules and the rule of reason in US antitrust law and the category of “by object” restrictions in EU competition law encompass formalistic reasoning. Moreover, the link between “legal form” and “anticompetitive effects” and the debate on “form-based” versus “effects-based” approaches to competition law denotes that “effects-based” approaches to competition law entangle formalistic legal rules.

It is argued that rules are means mediating between certain purposes and certain decisions furthering these purposes.<sup>2</sup> To that extent, formalism simplifies decision-making by only counting on the rule itself rather than the rationales underlying the

The original version of this chapter was retracted. The retraction note to this chapter is available at [https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-48083-6\\_14](https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-48083-6_14)

<sup>1</sup>Klaus Höfner and Fritz Elser v Macrotron GmbH, C-41/90, EU:C:1991:161, para. 21.

<sup>2</sup>Frederick Schauer, Formalism, 97 YALE L. J. 509 (1988).

rule. Nonetheless, decision-makers still distinguish the content of the rule encompassing some evaluative choices, if only relating to the literal meaning of the words contained in the rule.<sup>3</sup> Also, any rule application necessitates taking into consideration the legal context of the rule. A rule simplifies the decision-making process by demanding the decision-maker to abstract from excluded considerations. Hence, rules are “generalizations” entailing the decision-maker to abstract from some of the precise circumstances of each case, and they are “entrenched” for the reason that they ought to be followed in spite of whether the outcome in a particular case is desirable or undesirable.

It is also essential to underline in a competition law context that formalism is not only about statutory rules. Most competition law provisions are vague, “standard-like” norms that appear to eliminate very few considerations from their application to concrete cases. Hence, Section 1 of the Sherman Act 1890 is so abstract that it only be applied to concrete cases by taking into consideration its principles. Thus, if formalism is applicable to legal reasoning grounded on statutory rules, it is relevant hardly to any competition law system. To that extent, both US antitrust law and EU competition law, along with various other competition law systems, largely comprise case law and that case law may or may not embrace rules that function as legal formalisms.

Judicially shaped rules incorporate substantive legal tests such as the rule that a naked horizontal price-fixing agreement is an unreasonable restraint of trade in US antitrust law, and the rule that restrictions of competition by object are by definition significant in EU competition law.<sup>4</sup> Hence, applying a per se prohibition against naked horizontal price-fixing advances the rationales supporting the prohibition and so courts applying that rule recognize that the rule was shaped for the reason that virtually all naked horizontal price-fixing agreements are detrimental to competition. Nonetheless, there is a central difference between taking into consideration rationale in forming the rule and taking into consideration rationale in applying the rule. Hereafter, no substantive legal test in competition law has been formed without taking into consideration one or more rationales. In the EU competition law, the substantive legal test applicable to price discrimination by dominant undertakings explicitly embraces “all the circumstances” of the case having a low “rule-like” quality and is not formalistic.

The US antitrust case law after Trenton Potteries disclosed the difficulties of formally applying even a straightforward per se rule, such as the one against horizontal price-fixing. In Broadcast Music,<sup>5</sup> the Supreme Court held that applying the per se rule against horizontal price-fixing “is not a question simply of
