Perhaps, in US antitrust law, naked horizontal price-fixing and naked market division agreements have remained subject to a fully formalistic analysis. For other types of conduct, case-specific analysis is indispensable to analyze whether the conduct falls under the scope of a per se prohibition, which explicitly or implicitly entangles engaging with the rationale(s) of the relevant provision.

It is characteristic that the per se rule is a typical example of a legal formalism because it requires decision-makers to apply the rule without enquiring into the purpose(s) of the rule. Section 1 of the Sherman Act 1890 prohibits agreements that fall within the class of “agreements in restraints of trade,” just as Article 101 (1) TFEU concerns the class of agreements that have as their object or effect the restriction of competition.

## 8.2 Formalism and the Rule of Reason

The rule of reason is regarded as a structured, three-step test encompassing a burden-shifting process and the plaintiff must prove that the restraint has a significant anticompetitive effect harming consumers in the relevant market.<sup>6</sup>

First of all, while the per se rule in US antitrust law is a proxy for a legal formalistic approach to competition law, the rule of reason is deemed to be the doctrinal equivalent of a standard-based and/or effects-based approach. Although the rule of reason is a doctrine of US antitrust law, the term is also used concerning competition law systems throughout the world. In EU competition law, the category of restrictions of competitions ‘by effect’ is related to the rule of reason. Moreover, the “rule of reason” is a focal point in competition law illustrating the relevance of formalism and formalistic reasoning in the application of the rule of reason in US antitrust law.

In GTE Sylvania, the Supreme Court overruled the per se illegality rule for vertical non-price restraints by demanding a thorough case-specific inquiry in which “the factfinder weighs all of the circumstances of a case in deciding whether a restrictive practice should be prohibited as imposing an unreasonable restraint on competition.”<sup>7</sup> Additionally, in Leegin, the Supreme Court overruled the per se illegality rule for vertical resale price maintenance. In respect of the needed analysis under the rule of reason, the Supreme Court held that “[i]f the rule of reason were to apply to vertical price restraints, courts would have to be diligent in eliminating their

<sup>6</sup> Ohio et al. v. American Express Co. et al., 585 U.S. 1, 9–10 (2018); National Collegiate Athletic Association v. Alston et al., 594 U.S. \_\_ (2021), 24–25.

<sup>7</sup> Continental T.V., Inc. v. GTE Sylvania, Inc., 433 U.S. 36, 50 (1977)

anticompetitive uses from the market” elaborating a number of pro-competitive and anticompetitive indicators.<sup>8</sup>

If the rationale of competition law is to protect “competition,” and anticompetitive effects, pro-competitive principles, and efficiencies are all relevant concerns in view of this reason, then the structure of the rule of reason averts an unconstrained, all-things-considered analysis of all these considerations in light of the principle of protecting competition. Thus, the constraints imposed by the rule of reason are sequential and procedural.<sup>9</sup>

The allocation of the legal and evidential burden of proof is a tactic to formalize the administrative and judicial process and so within the formal structure of administrative and judicial procedures, the rule of reason in general is categorized by a low degree of formalism. To that extent, “formalization” of the rule of reason is demonstrated by two recent Supreme Court judgments, *Actavis* and *Ohio v. AMEX*. In *Ohio v. AMEX*,<sup>10</sup> the US Supreme Court compels the plaintiff, in cases entangling two-sided markets, to embrace both sides of a platform in the market definition demonstrating market power on that single market. Additionally, the Court held that such market definition is needed even if the plaintiff relies in his case on direct proof of anticompetitive effects. Legal rules on market definition liberate decision-makers by permitting them to quantify market power by proxy, on the basis of specific legal constructions as to what counts as “the relevant market.” By the way, market definition requirements display the more general point that legal formalisms can both constrain and liberate and can have both positive and negative effects on the quality of the decision-making course.<sup>11</sup>

Likewise, in *Actavis*, the Court formalized the first stage of the rule of reason by restricting the evidential obligations that are needed to prove considerable anticompetitive effects. Furthermore, the Court declared that courts need not take into consideration all the circumstances of the case in establishing substantial anticompetitive effect.<sup>12</sup> Thus, it could be said that the rule of reason in practice easily works as a quasi-per se legality rule.<sup>13</sup>

Consequently, in US antitrust law, the increased application of the rule of reason rather than the per se rule has not led to less constrained decision-making on the basis of the characteristics of each case in light of the principles of antitrust. Moreover, to the extent that the rule of reason is verbalized as a genuine all-things-considered analysis, it is so approximate that it can hardly be used for a consistent and predictable analysis but additional interpretive guidance on its application has turned

<sup>9</sup> M.A. Carrier, The Four-Step Rule of Reason, 33 Antitrust 50 (2019).

<sup>10</sup> Ohio et al. v. American Express Co. et al., 585 U.S. 1, 9–10 (2018);

<sup>11</sup> M. Eben, The Antitrust Market Does Not Exist: Pursuit of Objectivity in a Purposive Process, 17 J. COMP. L. & ECON. 586 (2021).

<sup>12</sup> FTC v. Actavis, Inc., 570 U.S. \_\_ (2013), at 20.

<sup>13</sup> H. Hovenkamp, A Miser’s Rule of Reason: The Alston Antitrust Case, FACULTY SCHOLARSHIP AT PENN LAW 2533 (2022).

While the rule of reason in US antitrust law and the analysis of anticompetitive effects are typified by a low degree of formalism, in practice both involve a relatively high degree of legal formalism. Hence, the rule of reason hardly operates as an unconstrained and has developed into a collection of conduct-specific rules that either advance establishing anticompetitive effects or rather make it virtually impossible to establish them.<sup>14</sup>

## 8.3 Formalism and Anticompetitive Effects

The rule of reason in US antitrust law integrates conduct-specific rules that formalize the decision-making process and so the substitution of “effects-based analysis” for “formalistic distinctions” has been a positive development. Also, it is stated that legal presumptions that rest on formalistic distinctions rather than actual market realities are disfavored in antitrust law.<sup>15</sup>

In Europe, the form-effects distinction has not been accepted by the EU courts, but nonetheless plays a noteworthy role in EU competition law scholarship, signifying “form-based” or “formalistic” and “effects-based” approaches to EU competition law. To that extent, the formalistic approach is connected with a per se prohibition of certain types of business conduct, or a qualified per se prohibition, amalgamating a prima facie per se prohibition with the prospect for the defendant (s) to justify the conduct. On the other hand, an effects-based approach necessitates the plaintiff to display actual or probable anticompetitive consequences on the market so as to find even a prima facie infringement which is subject to objective justification, for instance by Article 101 (3) TFEU or the likelihood for objective justification in Article 102 TFEU. Correspondingly, the use of “presumptions” applies once “certain conditions” are accomplished, while the “effects-based” approach necessitates evidence of anticompetitive effects in an individual case.

## 8.4 The Effects-Based Approach and Legal Formalism

It has to be taken into account that an effects-based approach to competition law requires a case-by-case analysis of whether anticompetitive effects have occurred or are expected to take place implying that a finding of antitrust liability must be based on empirical evidence of actual or probable anticompetitive effects.

<sup>14</sup>T. Wu, The American Express Opinion, the Rule of Reason, and Tech Platforms, 7 J. Antitrust Enforcement 104, 122 (2019): “Their mirror-image counterpart [of per se rules] in American Express takes the less-appealing approach of using complex economic theory to create near-impossible burdens of proof—burdens particularly hard to meet when they emerge on appeal. At worst, they offer a highly jazzed-up way of getting around some awfully damaging facts”

<sup>15</sup>Eastman Kodak Co. v. Image Technical Services, Inc., 504 U.S. 451, 466–467 (1992)

To that extent, conceptions of effects-based approaches to competition law draw heavily on economic theories of harm and usually relying on a number of assumptions and a restricted set of intuitions concerning rational behavior in particular conditions to derive conclusions as to whether a certain type of business conduct or the individual settings of a case are anticompetitive and so leading to actual or expected anticompetitive effects.<sup>16</sup> Furthermore, empirical data offer information supporting multiple economic narratives concentrating on either pro-competitive or anticompetitive effects.

Competition law functions with general presumptions about the performance of markets. Moreover, in monopolization and abuse of dominance cases, where, at the bottom, fierce competition against competitors cannot be discerned categorically from attempts to exclude those competitors from the market. Hence, the legal rules of an economics-informed competition law are expected to be equally, if not more formalistic than the “form-based approach.”

In addition, the rule in EU competition law is that a dominant undertaking has a “special responsibility” not to harm the competitive process.<sup>17</sup> While the special responsibility rule does not by itself denote what types of conduct are abusive, it forms more specific theories of harm and forms of abuse by compelling a general obligation onto dominant undertakings. Accordingly, the contemporary, “effects-based” approach is an equally, if not more formalistic approach that utilizes assumptions, categories, and inferences based on formal economic methods, which are turned into formalistic legal tests combining economic knowledge. It could be said that an agreement has a restrictive object even if it does not have the restriction of competition as its single aim but also chases other legitimate objectives which is a formalistic approach to Article 101 (1) TFEU.<sup>18</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that interaction between economic formalism, legal formalism, and all-things-considered analysis is signaled in several parts of the US and EU competition case laws. The Supreme Court substantially restricted the scope of Section 2 of the Sherman Act 1890 through a number of formalistic presumptions of legality, which were informed by certain assumptions from

In Brooke Group,<sup>19</sup> the Supreme Court ruled that the above incremental cost pricing is per se legal under Section 2, contrary to scholarship that had emphasized possible exclusionary effects of above-cost pricing. Again, in Trinko,<sup>20</sup> the Supreme Court correspondingly limited the scope of Section 2 of the Sherman Act 1890 by following a rule-based laissez-faire approach, stating that charging monopoly prices is not a violation of Section 2 for the reason that “it is an important element of the free market system” and “[t]he opportunity to charge monopoly prices—least for a short period—is what attracts ‘business acumen’ in the first place.”

In EU law, the approach towards price-based conduct by dominant undertakings is less formalistic than under Section 2 Sherman Act 1890. Concerning price discrimination, in Post Danmark I,<sup>21</sup> the Court stipulated an all-things-considered test to evaluate whether price-setting strategies should be considered anticompetitive. Again, in AKZO,<sup>22</sup> the Court held that prices below average variable costs are abusive, and prices between average variable costs and average total costs are abusive if they are ascertained as part of a plan for destroying a competitor. Consequently, for prices above average variable costs, the Court presented a specific rule as opposed to necessitating an all-things-considered analysis embracing more elements than simply the fact that prices are below average total costs and the existence of a plan to destroy a competitor.

Even though the effects category in Article 101 (1) TFEU, like the rule of reason analysis in US antitrust law, is regarded as an all-things-considered analysis based on the specific facts of each case and as a matter of legal principle, in practice specific types of agreements are subject to specific effects-based but formalistic tests. The anticompetitive nature of the effects of an agreement is evaluated in light of the competition that would have occurred in the absence of the agreement. In other words, the Court has provided formulaic criteria to structure the way in which anticompetitive and pro-competitive effects are taken into account.<sup>23</sup>

broader agreement that is, overall, pro-competitive.<sup>24</sup> A single exclusive purchasing agreement has considerable anticompetitive effects even if it is not part of a “bundle” of similar agreements which have the amassed consequence of foreclosing market access. Likewise, the identification of an overall, pro-competitive rationale and the necessity of the anticompetitive clause for the agreement as a whole is implicated which does amount to neither an unconstrained, all-things-considered analysis of the agreement, nor the balancing of pro-competitive and anticompetitive effects in general. To that extent, the analysis of ancillary restraints is rule-like and formalistic.<sup>25</sup>

It is worth noting that formalization through rules is needed to prevent a situation in which all circumstances are relevant, and so nothing is dispositive. By contrast, the dangers of broadening the scope of the by object category too much are also clear and the case law on “by object” restrictions has moved towards a decrease in formalism, while the case law on “by effect” restrictions has moved towards increased formalization through fact-specific rules and criteria.<sup>26</sup> Hence, rules become more standard-like over time and so predictability and formalism are related for the reason that the degree of formalism touches both the number of norm applications that are appropriate along with the norm itself and the possibility that the decision-maker reaches an erroneous outcome.

Although the ECJ de facto applies a system of precedent, there is no doctrine of stare decisis in EU law. Hence, in EU law, there is no obligation for the Court to stick to past decisions if they are considered incorrect or otherwise undesirable. Thus, the selection between following the rule and deciding on the basis of the specific settings of the case becomes particularly prominent if pre-existing rules from case law do have normative weight but there is no absolute doctrine of stare decisis. Examples from EU competition law reveal how the jurisprudential selection for formalistic or non-formalistic reasoning has direct repercussions for decisional jurisdiction, both horizontally and vertically.<sup>27</sup> Likewise, selective distribution systems comprise a characteristic of competition and are corresponding with Article 101 (1) TFEU, given that resellers are chosen on the basis of objective criteria of a qualitative nature, and these criteria are applied consistently for all prospective resellers and do not go further than needed.<sup>28</sup>

In Brohner, the ECJ determined that a dominant undertaking is only entitled to grant access to a physical infrastructure if such access is indispensable for opening the market and this indispensability test constrains the discretion of subsequent

administrative and judicial decision-makers to apply Article 102.<sup>29</sup> Nonetheless, it remained unclear exactly to which types of situations the Bronner doctrine extended, because most types of abuse are constructed as “implicit” or “constructive” refusals to deal.<sup>30</sup> Thus, the ECJ in Slovak Telekom and the GC in Google Shopping restrained the scope of the refusal to deal doctrine to “explicit” refusals to deal that follow an explicit request for access.<sup>31</sup>

Also, in practice, Slovak Telekom and Google Shopping augment the discretion of the Commission by restricting the room of applicability of the indispensability test. In other words, by narrowing down the scale of legal formalism, the administrative and judicial decision-makers gain more discretion. Nevertheless, just as formalism in general can be both liberating and limiting, a broader grant of decisional jurisdiction can also restrain decision-makers more than it liberates them. Thus, in the absence of the formalistic rule, the decision-maker is permitted to decide whether the conduct is anticompetitive or not, centered on the specific circumstances of the case.<sup>32</sup>

In Hoffmann La Roche,<sup>33</sup> the Court decided that a dominant undertaking which applies discounts conditional on the fact that the customer gets all or most of its supplies from that undertaking abuses its dominant position. The legal formalism concerning the abusive nature of loyalty rebates was revised in Intel<sup>34</sup> and the Court did not deny the presumption that loyalty rebates as defined in Hoffmann La Roche are abusive. Since the Commission’s decisional discretion is limited by law and judicial review, the result of Intel<sup>35</sup> is that the Commission is expected to be more constrained by rules after Intel than it had been by the substantive rule from Hoffmann La Roche.

It is argued that one of the key points of Intel is that dominant undertakings should have the chance to reveal that the presumed anticompetitive effects of the relevant conduct are implausible.<sup>36</sup> Moreover, in competition law, a highly abstract

rule necessitating decision-makers to ban “anticompetitive conduct” without offering any further guidance brings complexity. Hence, formalism to competition law leads to per se rules and “by object” prohibitions.

It is worth noting that per se rules are formalistic for the reason that they strongly reduce the number of considerations that are relevant in deciding whether some conduct is a restraint of trade in the sense of Section 1 of the Sherman Act 1890. To that extent, US federal courts have appealed to the rationales of US antitrust law assuming that the “fixing” of a “price” between competitors does not always constitute “horizontal price-fixing.” In addition, even the most straightforward per se rule is not always applied wholly formalistically and so the same applies to the “by object” category in EU competition law functioning formalistically in particular cases such as naked horizontal price-fixing or naked output restrictions, but as a matter of legal principle necessitates an analysis of the legal and economic context of an agreement which takes place by looking at the rationale of EU competition law.<sup>37</sup> Thus, both per se rules and the by object category are formalistic to a degree.

## 9.1 Introduction

Digital technology embeds politics by shaping social outcomes which means that AI brings forward social and political transformation. Moreover, technocracy has a political device in place for delivering the direction for society, while the technocrats have the power to determine and effectuate the policies considered indispensable to proceed in the desired direction.

It has to be taken into account that the AI state due to the lack of technical capability deploys digital tools so as to identify and survey. Moreover, the digitization and algorithmicizing of identities offer the competence to link all pertinent information in a central register or to generate protocols facilitating information-sharing between administrative units.<sup>1</sup> Thus, AI technology prepares the arrival of AAI systems, AAI humanoids, and AAI society.

It is worth noting that authoritarian governments equipped with robust surveillance technologies raise the prospect of a drift toward totalitarianism. Thus, the convergence of digital surveillance and the police state raises such a possibility. Digital systems can be trained not only to monitor forbidden behavior but also to identify, categorize, isolate, and manage entire populations deemed politically dangerous.

Due to globally standardized measures, digital organizations can collect data on a global scale. Taking into account, digital platforms are sovereigns in their own right, platforms become totalizing institutions from which users have no realistic option of escaping. Will the AAI state be an electronic platform where AAI entities will function electronically with no material life?

<sup>1</sup>Britton-Purdy, Jedediah S., David Grewal, Amy Kapczynski, and K. Sabeel Rahman. 2020. "Building a Law and Political Economy Framework: Beyond the Twentieth-Century Synthesis." 129 Yale Law Journal 1784

## 9.2 EU Materialization

*Federalism* amalgamates separate states within an overarching political system in a way that permits each to uphold its own integrity. The constitution is the supreme law in the federal nation describing specific powers which belong to the federal government. The national government and state governments share powers. The body of law of the common central government is the federal law applying to everyone in the United States. The Supreme Court makes final decisions concerning federal laws about specific cases brought before them. Moreover, the US Supreme Court serves as the legal arbiter of the federal system in regard to conflicting claims of state and national governments. The superior relationship that federal laws have with regard to conflicting State laws is established.<sup>2</sup>

A federal union is a political system of shared sovereignty with momentous central government powers and others that the states implement. The United States is a federal union. Federations gave imperative functions, embracing foreign affairs, defense, and management of the economy and taxation, among others, to a federal government that implemented the powers conferred it directly upon the “citizensry of the federation.”

The sui generis and complex character of the European Union makes it challenging to evaluate the strength and transmission channels of its global influence. To that extent, Bradford pinpointed the single market as the fundament of the EU’s global regulatory power.<sup>3</sup>

It has to be taken into account that the vision to unite Europe from a fragmented to a conflict-ridden continent remains an “uphill task.” In 1949, the United States worked with the Europeans to produce the Marshall Plan and urged the Europeans to abolish national trade barriers like tariffs. Moreover, Americans indicated the forming of a common market and adopting a federal union but this suggestion was radical for the highly nationalistic Europeans. It is characteristic that the European Coal and Steel Community began in 1952 and Schuman pronounced that this cooperative economic effort would be “a first step in the federation of Europe.” On the other hand, the stoppage of the “United States of Europe” movement and its replacement by a functionalist tactic, expressed by the current EU model, was the outcome of the still intense sense of nationalism of the states of Europe.

In 1957, six European countries founded the European Economic Community, and, in 1993, the European Union came into force, generating a new level of integration among its member countries in order to avert wars. The Treaty of Rome was signed expressing the objectives of “the four freedoms”: the movement of people, goods, services, and capital. Thus, instead of forming a federation, the EEC set up a structure of political bodies, appointed by the member states, to

<sup>2</sup> McCulloch v. Maryland, 17 U.S. (4 Wheat.) 316 (1819), Dodson, Scott (2016). “The Gravitational Force Of Federal Law”. University of Pennsylvania Law Review. 164 (3): 703–753.

<sup>3</sup> Anu Bradford, The Brussels Effect – How the European Union rules the world Oxford University Press, 2020.

propose, approve, and rule on laws but most of the political power stayed firmly in the hands of the national governments.

In 1992, the Maastricht Treaty created the European Union but for the first time, the French, who had led the European unification process, expressed doubts about granting more sovereignty to a stronger European organization. The European Union began as a common market that gradually enlarged in size and original economic arrangements are enhanced by numerous political and regulatory institutions for the continent as a whole. Anyway, the EU is stronger and more democratic than it was when six nations founded the European Economic Community in 1957 but so far, the EU is still not a federalized "United States of Europe." To that extent, EU member states have principally given up only some economic authority to have the advantages of a common market and so the EU still has no elected president, no military force, no foreign policy, and no real power to enforce its laws.

Is there extensive disagreement today on the future of the European Union? Which is the place of the EU in a world of increasing geopolitical rivalry? Should Europe be developed into a federation or remain just a financial or economic exercise? Has Russia's war in Ukraine initiated a new era for European unity? Does the AI era dictate the transformation of the EU model into the USE?

Brussels-based technocrats have been spotted to impose policy solutions that have often been unwanted and/or thought to be unsuitable. It has to be taken into account that diverse political, economic, and diplomatic urgencies have been re-arranged to manage the multiple crises that have hit EU and so EU member states' relations have been comprehended and appreciated principally via the lens of economic strategies and priorities, heading for averting the largest EU economies from being battered by the infectivity of the weakest member states. Additionally, the intergovernmental management of the EU economic downturn ultimately harmonized with the national interests of the biggest EU countries to prevail on those of the most fragile ones.

It is characteristic that Europeans who dispute a more federalized EU argue against abandoning their sovereignty. It is worth mentioning here that the United States is a federal system and the EU is a unique economic and political union between 27 European countries and so the EU is not a federation. Unlike the United States, the EU lacks a formal constitution but it is supposed that the EU Treaties function in practice as a constitution since they outline the allocation of powers.

## 9.3 EU Functioning

The EU was set up in order to end the frequent wars between neighbors, which was an outcome of World War II. Thus, the European Coal and Steel Community united European countries politically and economically with the purpose of promoting and securing peace.

Since the 1992 Maastricht Treaty, defending member states' specific welfare, chiefly circumscribed to the realm of economic and foreign policy issues, has

become a trademark of how EU politics and objectives have been practiced both inside and outside its borders. Also, it is argued that Europe is not “building a federal state similar to the United States”<sup>4</sup> due to deficient institutions and incompatible objectives constraining the course of European unification.

The Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe was an unratified international treaty intended to found a consolidated constitution for EU replacing the existing European Union treaties with a single text.<sup>5</sup> The Treaty was signed on 29 October 2004 by representatives of the then 25-member states of the European Union but the rejection of the document by French and Dutch voters in May and June 2005 brought the ratification process to an end and so the process for EU becoming a federation was blocked. To that extent, the Treaty of Lisbon was created to replace the Constitutional Treaty.<sup>6</sup> In other words, when the Treaty of Lisbon entered into force in December 2009, the EU finally appeared to have achieved institutional consolidation after the failure of the Constitutional Treaty. To that extent, governments stick to their original bargain concerning the integration process and so they are reluctant to give up autonomy and enter into new commitments.

The EU has developed into a unique arrangement of multilevel governance but lacks a government in the strict or conventional sense. Moreover, the EU treaties refrain from referring to federalism per se, nor do they embrace specific references to sovereignty. Furthermore, the treaties assign various political and institutional responsibilities by policy area.

It is argued that the EU vertical division-of-powers dimension embraces multiple elements of federalism<sup>7</sup> but in reality, the EU is not a federation and G.I. Zekos argues that any effort to find bits of the federation in the current model of EU is not helpful in promoting the effectiveness of EU as a political entity. The EU model encompasses a multilevel system via patchy vertical separation and sharing of powers.

The EU is a unique political and economic partnership formed by a series of binding treaties and member states agreed to share sovereignty. The key objective of the European Union was to “preserve peace and liberty and to lay the foundations of an ever-closer union among the people of Europe” and so calling for economic growth which was to be achieved through the establishment of a custom union with a common external tariff, common policies for agriculture, transport and trade, and enlargement of the EU to the rest of the Europe. Thus, the EU has long viewed the enlargement route as an extraordinary opportunity to further stability and prosperity

The EU is grounded on the rule of law, which is instituted by treaties that have been accepted voluntarily and democratically by all member countries and so if a policy area is not mentioned in a treaty, the Commission cannot propose a law in that area. Accordingly, institutions of the EU adopt legislation which the member countries then implement. It is characteristic that decision-making processes and the role of the EU institutions differ depending on the subject under consideration which makes the running of the EU peculiar and full of many disadvantages instead of functioning under a federal government. The European Union has seven institutions as its governance: The European Parliament, the Council of the European Union, The European Commission, the European Council, the European Central Bank, the Court of Justice of the European Union, and the European Court of Auditors. EU members have taken steps toward political integration, with decisions to develop a Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and efforts to advance collaboration in the area of Justice and Home Affairs (JHA). It is worth mentioning here that EU efforts to standardize policies in the JHA field were obstructed by member countries' fears that such measures could infringe on their legal systems and national sovereignty.

British voters decided on Brexit due to supposed economic difficulties grounded on the European integration and globalization but at the end of the day, British voters lost free access to the European market.<sup>10</sup> EU member countries have to make certain that national policies are in line with agreed EU strategies and positions but CFSP does not prevent individual member countries tracking their own national foreign policies or conducting their own national diplomacy which shows the character of the current EU model. CSDP seeks to improve the EU's capability to respond to security crises and to increase European military capabilities.<sup>11</sup>

## 9.4 Federalism in EU Via ECJ

The EU is an entity of limited powers and is founded upon the principle of conferral which means that the EU institutions act within the bounds of the competences conferred upon them by the member states in the Treaties and so the exercise of EU legislative powers is restricted by the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It seems that the principle of proportionality was formally preserved in the EU Treaties as a structural constitutional principle of the EU legal order.<sup>14</sup> Kolowski<sup>15</sup> believes that the EU has moved beyond federation, but will never become a federation akin to the United States. According to Brugess,<sup>16</sup> federalism, in the EU context, is appreciated as the “application of federal principles to the process of European integration.” On the other hand, federalism leads to the establishment of a federation.<sup>17</sup>

There is a reference to the “sui generis” nature of EU law<sup>18</sup> and so the European Court of Justice (ECJ) defined the system of the Treaties as “a new legal order of international law for the benefit of which the states have limited their sovereign rights.” On the other hand, the Court of Justice is not the most significant organ in the

It has to be taken into account that *de jure*, Supreme Court constitutional adjudications do not have *erga omnes* results while, in most cases, de facto they do.

On the one hand, the US Supreme court<sup>20</sup> adds to the constitutionalizing of politics via law interpretation which advances the development of the United States. It has to be taken into account that the concept of national constitutional identity in Article 4(2) TEU means that the member states can identify their own national identity, but the decision about the compatibility of the national identity with EU obligations since the Treaty of Lisbon is always conferred in the European Court of Justice, which makes the ultimate decision on Kompetenz-Kompetenz.<sup>21</sup> Moreover, EU law always takes precedence over national constitutional law.<sup>22</sup> Kelemen<sup>23</sup> concludes that the supremacy of EU law and deference to the ECJ on questions of Kompetenz-Kompetenz does not jeopardize the constitutional identity of the member states.

## 9.5 AI Advancement and Competition

Artificial intelligence systems will be able to solve problems whose scale and complexity are beyond human capabilities. Moreover, via advanced artificial intelligence (AAI) techniques,<sup>35</sup> machines will think as brains, and brains can be thought of as machines. Human intervention in the decision-making will be completely out of the loop in entirely automated systems.<sup>36</sup> Also, AI is developing very rapidly and human societies are becoming more “information mature” by relying increasingly on AI technologies which means that the impact of AI technologies on human shared values increases. Likewise, AI has become an integral part of public governance and so AI systems have to implement and comply with the rule of law. While AI enriches neutrality and accuracy in decision-making, it raises fears about the status of public values and democratic principles.

Does AI contribute to legitimate political processes? Does AI pose threats to democracy? Do AI applications disrupt democracy via information manipulation? Do AI applications necessitate a central government for EU in order to have an effective central control of governance?

It is worth noting that the resources of big data are utilized by AI systems and so controlling the future through the power of inference which means that AI governmentality is based upon governable subjects who are seen as aggregates of intra-personal data assembled and exploitable on an indescribable scale and detail.<sup>37</sup> Also, the extending accessibility of data and the escalating power of AI

Zekos, Artificial Intelligence And E-Bills Of Lading Contracts, Journal of Internet Law April 2021 Vol. 24 N8 p3–10 Wolters Kluwer <https://irus.wolterskluwer.com/store/product/journal-of-internet-law/>

decision-making alter the future of political institutions. To that extent, AI decisions in public governance must be transparent and explainable to gain legitimacy.

The utilization of AI systems by public decision-makers augments concern to develop legal and policy frameworks for the trustworthy sharing and processing of data to support democratic processes.<sup>38</sup> To that extent, data-sharing allows citizens to connect with public decision-making processes in a manner supplementing the more traditional role of the news media to build and inform political agendas.<sup>39</sup> Additionally, AI implementation could bring equal treatment for all citizens via AI fairness rather than human bias which is the distinctive part of liberal democracies.<sup>40</sup> Which is the factor of allowing AI to function objectively and achieving the best outcome? The answer is a good algorithm formulated in a non-bias way and not influenced by any political intervention in favoring a particular solution except an objective outcome coming out of valuable big data.

As mentioned earlier, AI is superior to human intelligence for the analysis of large and complex problems encompassing the need for strategy, prediction of long-term consequences, and analysis of vast amounts of data. To that extent, algorithmic governance is utilized both in ordering human action, and in the use of AI in the domain of government, and predominantly in a situation in which AI is given the authority to govern by mandates. Additionally, technical standardization facilitates systems and network compatibility, enabling interoperability and so the EU Commission utilizes AI as a functional instrument to boost equality of opportunity, socioeconomic welfare, and democracy. Likewise, interoperability generates economies of scale and market competition, stipulating international cooperation and coordination in standards development. Thus, AAI technology will implement all of them by offering an unbiased functioning in order to function globally. In other words, a single government for the EU is essential in order to have a standardized implementation of AI systems which means the need of transforming the current EU model of governance into a federal governance model.

## 9.6 Political Integration of EU

Can the steps of the European Community integration process be described as part of the traditional federalizing process? Hay<sup>41</sup> wrote about certain “federalizing features” of the common market Treaty system and federalism is ascertained as the process of federalizing a political community.<sup>42</sup> To that extent, Weiler<sup>43</sup> argues that “The Community is not destined to become another America or indeed a federal state.”

Joschka Fischer has said that he considers that in the end, the EU must become a single federation, with its political leader chosen by direct elections among all of its citizens.<sup>44</sup> Moreover, Matteo Renzi<sup>45</sup> has called for a “United States of Europe,” and political theorist Glyn Morgan has made an extended argument for a super state as a desirable geopolitical rival to the United States.<sup>46</sup> Furthermore, Mario Draghi urged the EU to adopt a “pragmatic federalism” involving treaty change.<sup>47</sup>

Eurosceptics argue that the EU acts as an imperialist power towards its own member states but the EU lacks much international power, at least in comparison to China and the United States. It is worth mentioning here that Eurosceptics consider that European Integration constitutes a form of imperialism.<sup>48</sup> Do Hungary and Poland argue against the European Union’s attempts to enforce the rule of law? It is obvious that all countries have joined EU voluntarily and so they have to follow the rule of law. Polish and Hungarians as individuals and Poland and Hungary as member states have the same rights and responsibilities as other European citizens and member states.

It is argued that the EU is a political and economic entity committed, both at its federal level and at the member state level, to a formula of liberal democratic market capitalism which is marked by the “Four Freedoms” enforced by the European Court

To that extent, an EU defense has to be at the service of an EU foreign and security policy demanding a political union with a single representation of the EU in the international institutions and arena. ## 9.7 Digitizing EU

The European Union is a project in constant making since the founding of the European Coal and Steel Community reaching great levels of integration, but progress has not been made unwaveringly in all fields. At the political level, integration has encountered noteworthy impediments slowing down the process in comparison to other common areas, such as economics.

It is obvious that the European Union is a unique political route and the process of integration responds to the requirements of the organization to adjust to the social, political, and economic reality and solve the problems arising from the process. To that extent, digitalization is a process necessitated to acclimate the European Union to the reality by offering a common frame to an existing digital world. Thus, the EU needs to respond to the necessities of the society for the accomplishment of European standards in a new, but already significant, area. The European Union digitization course built up great prospects in terms of economic growth and to that extent, the private sector is not the only one influenced by the digitization process, but the public sector will profit from a wider use of new digital devices.<sup>64</sup>

It is worth noting that the digitalization process of society influences competition and AI systems assist regulators to enforce competition law more effectively in modern data-driven economies in which market structures are becoming more complicated and different ways of infringing antitrust rules have appeared and so competition law enforcement relies on sophisticated ADM tools.<sup>65</sup> Hence, administrative bodies incorporate technologies in their decision-making processes.<sup>66</sup> Moreover, ADM systems offer capacity for improving internal efficiency by accessing greater amounts of data from more diverse sources and so competition authorities have a better understanding of the dynamics of markets and the elements affecting competition therein.<sup>67</sup>

EU prioritizes integration at the digital level within a broader social framework due to the fact that the citizens of modern societies continuously communicate digitally. Furthermore, the relationship of European firms with design, production, marketing, and generation of added value from products and services is anticipated to be redefined because the digital economy is already a reality, with relevant prospective advancement and significant progress.

Information and communication technologies (ICTs) permit the sector to function in a transparent and efficient way causing the reduction of corruption through clear control of public activities. Moreover, participation derived from the formation of a common political digital space is vital for deepening the integration at the European level. Hence, digital advancement will cultivate the formation of a more integrated European space at a political level for the reason that it diminishes distances by facilitating the participation of all European citizens in the political development of the EU.<sup>68</sup> Thus, the political future of Europe implicates removing barriers to create a common political frame.

Furthermore, digital development merges the optimization of resources and the reduction of costs at a private and public level. As a result, the European Union accelerates a process to enhance economic competitiveness and public spending. Once again, the formation of the digital market meets the opposition of nationalism supporting State autonomy against the unifying thrusts.

It is worth noting that the perception of national sovereignty plays a pertinent role in the process of European construction from its beginnings to the present day generating a game of balance between cooperation and integration and so a wrongful

It is worth mentioning here that the digital dominion revises and, at the same time, challenges the traditional notion of sovereignty and so AI technologies are deeply remodeling both societies and individuals, involving how we act, communicate, and think. Smuha<sup>73</sup> argues that “European digital sovereignty can thus be understood as the ability of the European Union—including its citizens and businesses—to autonomously decide on their relationship with (providers of) digital technology. This implies the exercise of control over two entwined elements, namely (a) the direction or ‘destiny’ of digital technology within the EU, and (b) the concrete digital infrastructure that enables the technology.” On the other hand, Larsen<sup>74</sup> argues that digital sovereignty “refers to a nation’s ability to control its digital destiny,” while adding that this “may include control over the entire AI supply chain, from data to hardware and software” which means that the state has this power by being a state but in the case of EU, everything depends on the authority given to EU by the Members States which does not denote real-state sovereignty in its classical essence.

Also, it is argued that European sovereignty implies a vision of the EU as an autonomous agent seeing the EU as legislating by having the capacity to adopt legislation and adjudicating by having the capacity to take part in judicial decision-making, through the CJEU together with national courts, as regulating by having the capability to regulate, through the European Commission and regulatory agencies and as enforcing by having the capability to enforce EU law. Instead, the EU legal order co-exists with the legal orders of its member states indicating that its competence and jurisdiction are not equal to the traditional autonomous concept of sovereignty and jurisdiction are conventionally intellectualized at the level of nation-states. Thus, while sovereignty is conventionally intellectualized at the level of nation-states, it has been liberally employed in the European context to the extent and scale that particular competences have been assigned to the EU by its member states. Consequently, taking into account the reasonable context of sovereignty means that the European sovereignty should infer a vision of the EU as an autonomous agent denoting that the EU has to become an autonomous single political entity and so not be dependent on the wishes of the member states.

Furthermore, it is argued that states must ensure to “protect their citizens and businesses from the manifold challenges to self-determination in the digital sphere”<sup>75</sup> denoting single-state sovereignty which does not infer to the current EU because its model is grounded on the interests of the member states and the authority given to EU by them and so AI technology demands the transformation of EU into the USE in order as a single digital sovereignty to comply with the demands of AI digitalization.

## 9.8 AI Networking

It has to be taken into consideration that technological collaborations empower organizations and regions to share, transfer, and integrate new knowledge, reinforcing processes of knowledge making and recombination, and extending the depth and breadth of the local knowledge basis. Hence, by enabling access to diversified knowledge, collaboration diminishes the costs of innovation by advancing externalities and knowledge spillover.<sup>76</sup>

A global innovation network is a globally organized web of collaborative interactions between different organizations involved in knowledge production that is linked to and resulting in innovation which means that via global networks, global players are able to access external differentiated knowledge boosting the opportunities of knowledge recombination taking on global dimensions. So far, in a global and digitalized context where knowledge exchange crosses regional and national boundaries, investing in global linkages is central to be innovative.<sup>77</sup> It has to be taken into account that global R&D collaborations offer developed countries with the opening to quickly access foreign market information and knowledge and so enabling them to harmonize and integrate the complementary resources and capabilities which means coproducing products due to the fact that the complementarity of resources and competences furthers additional collaborative innovations.<sup>78</sup>

To that extent, it is characteristic that EU innovation policies have been encouraging technological cooperation and boosting the share of knowledge between member states. Moreover, innovation networks play an imperative role in organizing the collective production of scientific and technological knowledge which means that collaboration through innovation networks permits the overcoming of the absence of financial resources in R&D investment, the sharing of risks and uncertainty, the access to external partners' competences, and better management of innovation intricacy. Thus, the management and advancement of innovation access by a single source is vital not mentioning in the case of AI technology where standardization is essential which means that the advancement of innovation by a single source in a politically united USE is central in order to gain leadership in a global market rather than having 27 or more jurisdictions to struggle an access to innovation networks having to deal with colossal networks of China, the United States, etc.

The online hotel Booking and Amazon cases show that the ECN fails to accomplish its purpose of ensuring a common approach in enforcing European competition law.<sup>81</sup>

## 9.11 Conclusions

It is stressed that Europeans are wealthy and well-equipped with the means to handle their own challenges, if they show leadership and political will which means that Europe's struggles are its own fault and concern, and it must find its own way out.<sup>92</sup> Where are all the European academics to speak loudly for the promotion of EU as a political entity for the good of Europeans in order to avoid a future global war on European soil once again? Will other superpowers transfer any future conflict on European Soil essentially by holding EU leadership in an official silence?

Taking into account that Europe is facing unprecedented geopolitical encounters and political transition, will the EU act together, as a federation in the making, or fall back on divergent national positions? First of all, inflation, energy price rises, climate change, supply chain shortages, and the digital revolution make it essential for the EU to act as one. On the other hand, the EU is absent from Europe's most dangerous geopolitical crisis since the Cold War, with national tactics prevailing on foreign, security and defense policy, economics, trade, climate change, and public health. Nevertheless, the incapacity and often unwillingness to implement coherent and cohesive policy guidelines to deal with the consequences of the global uprisings have profoundly marked the aptitude of the EU to function as a credible global diplomatic player. Thus, the EU should act as a single body, in a more supranational, rather than intergovernmental, manner. To that extent, the EU in order to stay at

## 10.1 Introduction

Corporations accumulate global technology and advancing technological capabilities that enable them to catch up with industry leaders in the global market. In the digital economy, central network outcomes initiate a “winner-takes-most” competition, with only one platform controlling a market, or being the big actor in a relevant market by impeding horizontal competition, or dominating a value chain by limiting vertical competition. Hence, markets typified by platform competition are horizontally concentrated and so other players in the online market do not present a workable competitive alternative to the established platform.

The digital economy brings forward a range of strategies to get a competitive advantage and transforms this to surplus value accumulated in the product. Digital economic players count on cost-cutting technology to break into online markets by unsettling the existing competitive structure, and ultimately gaining economic power. Also, new players making a more effective use of technology or relying on a better technological alternative overtake the well-known players.

As the digital economy has grown and data has become a more valuable and significant resource, the data practices of companies are being scrutinized by governments.<sup>1</sup> It seems that countries are balancing the commercial interests of the companies that are collecting and handling data, the privacy interests of the individuals who offer data, and their own interests in data due to national security, public security, and economic and social development objectives and interests.<sup>2</sup> Because of

## 10.2 AI and HRM

It has to be taken into account that with the accelerating application of AI, the interplay among companies, employees, and customers is profoundly altering and so the automation of the administrative parts of HRM activities and tasks is escalating. Moreover, contemporary developments are offering alternatives to human resources in functions traditionally demanding human interaction and communication. Currently, AI humanoid robots and AI bots are increasingly utilized which means that traditional human resource functions have been transformed, stipulating growing strengths and potentialities for HRM but also challenging job-specific obsolescence. Correspondingly, the introduction of AI human resource information systems presents openings to advance and diminish the cost of HRM functions embracing, among others, the evaluation of job applicants and employee performance appraisals.

Also, AI applications in HRM decision-making underline the capability to process large amounts of data at high speeds, the likelihood to assist salespeople gaining new customers more resourcefully and realistically assess and manage employee turnover risk. Nonetheless, even when AI advances task performance causing no immediate threat, its widespread use in HRM decision-making is sensed as a threat to human employees' autonomy and job security for the reason that it offers more choices to them perplexing them due to escalating perceived complexity. Explicitly, the introduction of AI applications in HRM permits HR employees to conduct background checks of job applications and AI-enabled recruitment platforms infer possible behaviors in terms of job fit and performance while being less biased and more objective than humans.<sup>4</sup> Algorithms assist HR practitioners and corporations by altering the selection process into a more systematic process by excluding the incidence of recruiters' biases and so AI offers to HRM recruiting constitute a positive development for HRM.<sup>5</sup> It has to be taken into account that algorithmic decision-making has enabled corporations to sort and rank people more effectively.

## 10.3 Legal Personality of Corporations

Laws and regulations are struggling to keep pace with the rapid introduction and diffusion of technological changes.<sup>7</sup>

It is worth noting that AI falling short of key moral qualities of personhood is considered as an apparatus of the actual persons to whom it belongs.<sup>8</sup> While the European Parliament formed a class of “electronic persons,” the more autonomous an AI entity becomes means that it cannot be treated as property by an owner for the owner’s chosen ends.<sup>9</sup>

Also, it is worth mentioning here that all of antitrust law’s violation provisions except one necessitate an agreement between two or more persons. The exception, § 2 of the Sherman Act, condemns monopolization and attempts to monopolize by one person acting unilaterally. Moreover, antitrust personhood is not restricted to biological individuals and so corporations are persons too, revealing a long history of considering them that way under state corporate law. It has to be taken into account that the Supreme Court held that a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary must be considered as a single person, incapable of conspiring with one another.<sup>10</sup> Thus, only persons, which embrace corporations, can violate the antitrust laws unilaterally and so electronic persons and electronic corporations will be treated accordingly.

Hence, AAI systems function as conduit for human activity.<sup>12</sup>

Corporations are creatures of the law and so AAI entities have a status akin to humans, they can own property and contracts, sue, and be sued in their own name. Additionally, AAI humanoids can be shareholders to a conventional corporation in a human-running world because corporation’s functionality will be run by AAI entities rather than humans but it is possible for a human’s elite to run an AAI system behind the curtains as long as they can survive as humans in an AAI world.

It has to be taken into account that law first recognized corporations as artificial persons via the idea of “legal personality” for private law convenience. Taking into consideration that only people can contract, sue, and be sued, own property, and enter into contracts, legally recognizing companies as “people” simplified commercial transactions, questions of liability, and the application of regulations to corporate activity. ## 10.5 Competition in China

Monopolies and unfair and disorderly competition are considered as destructive to markets, consumers, and economic development.<sup>29</sup> China has laws handling different aspects of competition. The Anti-Monopoly Law prohibits horizontal and vertical monopoly agreements, abuses of market power, and anticompetitive mergers, and is fundamentally quite similar to the antitrust/competition laws of many other jurisdictions outlawing anticompetitive abuses of administrative power. Moreover, the AML prevents and forbids monopoly conduct, protects fair competition in the market, and advances economic efficiency by preserving the interests of consumers and the public.

Also, the Anti-Unfair Competition Law encompasses a series of unfair competition practices, with a focus on the fairness of business transactions and business ethics.<sup>30</sup> Supplementary, in October 2021, the SAMR published draft guidelines to catalog digital platforms setting out their responsibilities and so outlining the obligations of digital platforms concerning cyber security, data security, privacy and personal information protection, workers' rights, environmental protection, and tax which mean that the SAMR will enforce laws against digital platforms.<sup>31</sup>

## 10.6 Digital Providers

Business management represents one context in which machine-learning algorithms are used.<sup>32</sup> Algorithms offer predictions and other data to other board members and some business models regularly count on AI to take vital action on an automated, high-speed basis such as broker-dealers regularly use algorithms for advice and execution of stock market trades.<sup>33</sup>

There is an expanding capability to automate business coordination via blockchain technology and blockchain-based smart contracts. AI can retain and manage wealth independently from human interfaces and the Uniform Limited Liability Company Act (ULLCA) already clearly offers the option that an LLC may function without any members flowing from the law's generation of fictional entities and treating them like people for certain purposes.<sup>34</sup> To that extent, AI induces all corporations from a hierarchical and formalized governance structure to more open governance structure grounded on a platform model.<sup>35</sup>

The digital/platform economy is a system portrayed mainly by platforms, driven by AI technologies and so generating value by assisting exchanges between two different but interdependent groups which means that AI-networked digital technologies stimulate economic exchange and transfer of information connecting people. It could be said that platform corporations are selling access to the software, the matching algorithms, and a digital system of reputation and trust between their users. Anyway, the digital/platform era necessitates new methods of collaboration and governance encompassing new corporate decision-making.

It seems that platform companies, currently ruled by humans via AI tools, replicate the centralized power structures and platform technology merely becomes the new medium through which to concentrate power, centralize resources, and more resourcefully serve market demands.<sup>36</sup> For instance, Uber and Airbnb remain conventional companies with old-style agency cost concerns born of customary centralized management hierarchies at the director and c-suite level.

## 10.7 E-Commerce and Competition

The objective of digital policy is to initiate outstanding framework conditions in Europe for innovative corporations and for the transformation of the European economy triggering investments in digital infrastructure. A large majority of e-commerce operators are platforms which intermediate and aggregate two-sided markets: one side comprising suppliers and the other side comprising consumers.<sup>47</sup>

It has to be taken into account that digital platforms facilitate efficient interactions between a supply side of producer users and a demand side of consumer users that create value in online and offline trades. On the other hand, Bertin Martens et al.<sup>48</sup> argue “that price regulation over information sharing like the one applied in the EU jurisdiction reduces the incentives of platforms to share information limiting the benefits for consumers.”

The harmonization of rules in the European single market facilitates the generation of competitiveness, since corporations find uniform rules across Europe which means that the EU can show its strength as an economic area via European rules. Diverging approaches of national competition authorities to practices by digital platforms within the EU are detrimental to the running of the internal, single market obstructing innovative homegrown digital businesses.

The EU Digital Markets Act applies the same *ex ante* fixed standard to all the “gatekeeper” platforms, presumed by quantitative metrics such as sales volume. On the other hand, competition law has the advantage of flexibility, since it embraces a case-by-case analysis tailored to the specifics of each digital sector. It seems that

## 10.8 Market Concentration in the Platform Economy

It is worth noting that horizontal deals in concentrated businesses with high product similarity are linked with anticompetitive effects.<sup>56</sup> Moreover, vertical mergers are principally stimulated by an efficiency-enhancing rational. To that extent, in horizontal mergers, companies acquire industry peers to expand businesses and, by doing so, managers could express anticompetitive pressure in the market by scheduling monopolistic prices and quantities. Moreover, horizontal mergers enhance market share, but cannot prevent the risk of new entrants. On the other hand, vertical mergers give rise to foreclosure and the locking out of prospective new market entrants and so competing businesses struggle to access supplies in a cost-effective manner, if at all, and new entrants may face inexplicably high costs. As mentioned earlier, the rise of Big Tech corporations, such as Google, Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Facebook, that act both as intermediary platforms and as providers of services and goods in several markets, has amplified worries concerning economic harms brought by the concentrated structure of the digital economy. Therefore, the advances in data processing and storage technologies have generated new business openings for big digital corporations and so digital corporations have employed such information purposefully to advance their own services and starting new products and services. To that extent, big digital platforms differentiate from other corporations due to direct and indirect network effects stemmed by their size and multimarket presence, accompanied by economies of scope and scale caused by the rigorous use of digital technologies.

Also, advertisers and publishers appraise the size of platform’s user base than users appreciate the number of ad-suppliers reaching them via the social media platform. Consequently, the platform subsidizes the service to end-users, at the expense of suppliers which means that where platforms present subsidized digital services to end-users backed by suppliers keen on reaching those users to present their products and services and so generating a concentrated structure of many digital markets. Thus, platform intermediaries like Amazon, Google, and Facebook gained, in a few years, high levels of market share among users in many digital markets.

It is argued that while Amazon revolutionized e-commerce and brought several consumer benefits, such as convenience, time savings, and lower prices, simultaneously it possesses significant market power and makes use of anticompetitive business practices such as predatory or below-cost pricing and aggressively expanded into multiple business areas via mergers and acquisitions (M&As).<sup>59</sup> On the other hand, Amazon along with other tech firms have not (yet) been challenged as a result of focusing mainly on consumer prices as the dominant metric for assessing competition.

Furthermore, the platforms’ dominance in digital ad markets leads to an increase in the prices of ads harming competition and innovation in retail markets, provided that only incumbents in these markets are able to pay the higher prices of advertisements. To that extent, the higher prices of digital ads stimulated by the concentration in digital ads market produce an entry barrier to new and small innovators in retail

Also, the accumulation of capital, technology, and data in the hands of a few Big Techs has advanced the rise of innovative digital solutions and so the upsurge in the demand for digital products and services that the COVID-19 pandemic brought has underlined the significance of AI technology infrastructure offered by the big digital platforms. Hence, the strong network results and economies of scale of many digital markets marked their concentration which does not result in inefficiencies because consumer's surplus would be well protected in the presence of enough contestability.<sup>60</sup> Thus, competition authorities should concentrate on managing the outcomes of market concentration in order to avert abusive misconduct of dominant platforms.

Likewise, the effectiveness of regulatory regimes planned to handle concentration and prospective anticompetitive misconduct in digital markets has been explored and so precautionary antitrust policy and ex post regulation have received strong interest. In addition, there is a need of defining that the objective of a prospective intervention is advancing competition in the digital platforms and not fostering competition for the digital platforms.<sup>61</sup>

## 10.9 Competition in Digital Platforms

Does the concentration generate abuse of position? First of all, digital platforms act as regulators of marketplaces formed by themselves and utilized by billions of people and corporations globally. Thus, due to reduced costs of communication, it is becoming possible for new entrepreneurs to investigate platform features and capabilities in distributing services and reaching new clients which means that digital platforms have augmented competition and innovation in several online and off-line markets. On the other hand, platforms gain access to privileged information linked to the demand and supply of many different businesses employing their platforms to trade and so the absence of clear boundaries to the strategy of digital platforms produces a danger of exploiting their users of both sides of the intermediation business with comparatively weak adverse consequences. Consequently, there is a need of generating measures to guarantee that the rules and conducts compelled by platforms on their own marketplaces do not distort free and vigorous competition and the enticements to innovation in markets of both sides of the intermediation platform. To that extent, *ex post* and *ex ante* regulatory interventions

It is argued that “competition to obtain a monopoly is an important form of competition”<sup>63</sup> and so competing to monopolize unavoidably means that competition is the exclusion of certain competitors except as long as the antagonism of companies under a certain pro-competitive process is a matter of progress and development regardless if many companies cannot follow the rhythm due to bad management and wrong investment along with unbalanced inputs because monopolies are possibly efficiency augmenting due to improved efficiency by stimulating innovation than a highly fragmented market. Hence, per se rules on ex ante covering allow the advancement of competition by presenting the rightful competition process with open access markets for all potential competitors. Thus, the effort to become a monopolist and dominant firm via equal opportunities of competition process is rightful, since competition law does not concern itself with every practice simply for the reason that it prevents competitors. Xingyu Yan and Hans Vedder<sup>64</sup> propose a test centered on the concept of minimum efficient scale by clarifying competition on the merits in a virtuously efficiency-based manner and showing “potential in enhancing the robustness of ex post antitrust when ex ante regulation has become the more popular recourse.”

It has to be taken into account that competition’s objective is to protect the competitive qualities via management excellences, not to schedule who should win and who should lose. Promoting competition for the intermediation platforms entails the introduction of a set of competition policy and/or regulatory measures with the objective of stimulating the entry of new players into the intermediation business.

The adoption of measures to increase the contestability of intermediation markets should start with the definition of which markets are to be addressed, followed by the definition of clear criteria for identifying which incumbent intermediation platforms have market power in those markets. Digital platforms via their market power across markets in the digital economy avert end users to switch to smaller competitors, even when newcomers present better services. It seems that concentration is welfare diminishing by permitting platforms to utilize users’ and consumers’ surplus unfairly. Due to welfare-enhancing characteristics of the current concentrated

Taking into account that the digital economy is in constant evolution, any ex ante measure is outdated very quickly and so new technology platforms remain without competition policy or regulatory interventions. Thus, precautionary competition policy measures considered the imposition of restrictions for incumbent interdiction platforms to acquire nascent, technology businesses<sup>66</sup> grounded on an understanding that that the start-up acquisition strategies of incumbent platforms intended to eliminate prospective competitors and so impairing venture capital investment and the innovation ecosystem.<sup>67</sup> It has to be taken into account that platform acquisitions of startups can lead to monopoly. Zekos considers that an AAI system will deal with the competition of digital platforms since all data will pass through the nodes of the system and the self-advancement of the system will block all illegal movements and so directly will enforce technical measures of the circulation of data and so the AAI law will be imposed immediately.

Likewise, the competition policy against the Big Techs in the United States and in the EU reveals the limitations of purely ex post, anti-trust remedies to foster competition in the platform economy.<sup>68</sup> It seems that ex post antitrust remedies are not effective enough to safeguard competition in digital markets and so ex ante remedies seem to successfully discourage competitive misconduct in the short term from platforms detected with market power. As discussed earlier, Big Tech start-up acquisitions fuel venture capital investment in the short term and are a vital exit strategy for venture capitalists which means that banning tech start-up acquisitions multiplies the risk and lower profit predictions of venture investment because of banning the selling of a start-up for a profit. In addition, lack of VC investment hinders entrepreneurship and start-up creation, with negative influences on consumer welfare. Hence, *ex post*, competition policy remedies fulfill the objective of advancing competition for the incumbent digital platforms. To that extent, competition policy enforcers should cope with cases of abusive misconduct commenced by incumbent platforms with market power and so not concentrating only on analyzing short-term impacts of mergers and acquisitions on consumer welfare such as the impacts on price and total output. It is argued that business conduct that enhances integration or concentration does not automatically violate antitrust law because there is a need of consumers to be harmed via higher prices, reduced supply, or diminished innovation or rivalry which means that a transaction is pro-competitive under the antitrust laws as long as consumer welfare rises.<sup>72</sup>

## 10.10 Standardization and Competition

Most technical standards development organizations (SDOs) have embraced internal policies exemplifying “due process” criteria such as openness, balance of interests, consensus decision-making, and appeals. Moreover, courts and enforcement agencies have taken into account SDOs as a procompetitive feature because standard development procedures by following certain due process principles are expected not to produce anticompetitive effects.<sup>76</sup>

## 10.11 Digital Providers and Competition

Blockchain technology generates a decentralized and principally autonomous model of the organization of the digital economy.<sup>81</sup> Moreover, the supposed transparency of the blockchain, which is in doubt lately, gives noteworthy advantages to platforms when organizing a network of transactions because transparency produces institutions-based trust.

Digital platforms are online corporations intermediating and aggregating suppliers and customers in two-sided markets. Each platform sector has its own exclusive characteristics and so Facebook, Alibaba, and Uber are very different in their scale economies and network externalities, developing differing trends toward concentration. Furthermore, digital platforms seem to constitute a hybrid between models of “retain and reinvest” and “downsize and distribute.” Online intermediaries and digital platforms offer the infrastructure and means on which other platform businesses are built. Also, digital platforms are typified by conglomerate kind of expansion, denoted by high diversification. It is argued that the existence of many

Democratic governments around the globe utilize a platform governance agenda requiring global platform governance, as no single country can change the formation of the platform economy alone. Taking into account that the platform firms in the consumer marketplace generate special liabilities owing to the control they exercise over data, advertising, and the duration of information, governments explore new ways to curb the power of digital giants in order to reduce the threats to public safety and democratic integrity.<sup>83</sup>

It has to be taken into account that platform governance will overtake corporate governance because there will be a movement from corporate competition to AI autonomous corporations managed by AI entities. Also, it has to be taken into consideration that digital platforms, as a new organizational form, highlight emerging patterns of internationalization in the digital economy.<sup>84</sup> Platforms denote a stable set of common technological resources, standards, and capabilities for organizing the production of complementary products, and presenting a cyberspace intermediary for the exchange between customers and suppliers of complementary products. Could digital platforms have the legal form of e-MNEs? Contrasting conventional MNEs and e-MNEs platforms gain advantages from both their proprietary resources and complementary resources. It is worth noting that deficiencies in IPR protection are in favor of inter-firm collaboration between platform owners and complementors while upgrading IPR regimes leads to internalization in a host market. On the other hand, in strong IPR regimes, legal protection of copyrights increases the platform's aptitude to utilize proprietary resources and the extent of internalization. It has to be taken into account that digital platform organization empowers corporations to get and reallocate decision and payoff rights to externally owned resources and so coordinating a value-creating ecosystem crossing national borders.<sup>85</sup>

The concept of “dominance” has been comprehended as “a position of economic strength” possessed by an undertaking to restrict competition “by affording it the power to behave to an appreciable extent independently of its competitors, its customers and ultimately of its consumers.”<sup>86</sup> Also, economic strength empowers the undertaking having a noticeable impact on the conditions under which competition will advance.
