Economic power encompasses the various aspects of power that are traditionally taken into consideration in competition law enforcement. Even though Section 2 of Sherman Act denotes monopoly power, and the European systems of competition law utilize the concept of “dominant position,” the concept of “market power” has grown to a unified conceptual framework and has outlined the competition law enforcement.

Market power endorses the capacity of an undertaking to initiate a deviation from the price or quantity obtained from the competitive situation in the market in which the transaction takes place. Also, market power is evaluated in the context of a relevant market of substitutable products, and a high market share signifies a higher influence on the economy.

Competition is the main tool used in the economy to promote consumer welfare.<sup>87</sup> G.I. Zekos argues that under the notion of consumer welfare hides a tendency to allow monopolies to play the central role in an economy which prohibits the evolution of other competitors on the market. Moreover, perfect competition arises whenever a large number of corporations selling similar products or services function in markets distinguished by price transparency and low entry barriers.

Competition law has developed advanced quantitative tools to measure market power. To that extent, competition authorities concentrate on the market structure and concentration and so defining monopoly power by reference to the capability of excluding rivals by using strategic barriers to entry so as to keep out or marginalize rivals.

Financial markets play a central part in determining the market value of corporations. Competitive strategy centers on competition, taking into consideration the corporate strategy to maximize the corporation's performance, in terms of surplus value and economic profit. Moreover, corporations pursue a competitive advantage, either by copying successful competitors while lowering their costs or by distinguishing themselves from their competitors, by advancing internal resources and competencies which means conceiving strategies to utilize these differences.

It is worth noting that online marketplaces bring benefits to consumers along with being powerful engines for growth and innovation. Moreover, acting as intermediaries between merchants and consumers, they tolerate a host of producers and retailers to reach consumers facilitating the development of new business models and possessing a superior bargaining position concerning their business users. Hence, power inequalities between platforms and business users result in sellers becoming dependent on those platforms to reach buyers.

It could be said that economic dependence is exemplified by the absence of reasonably equivalent alternatives available within a reasonable period of time permitting the imposition of services or conditions not to be gained under normal market conditions. Moreover, the perception of economic dependence is found in the

Court of Justice case law in British Leyland<sup>88</sup> closely linked to legal monopoly rights granted to a trade partner. Hence, the notion of dependency distinguishes a scale of relationships triggering public intervention and embracing relationships grounded on product ranges or strong brands, the strength of the buyer, and technical standards.<sup>89</sup>

EU member states have adopted specific rules on the abuse of economic dependence and relative market power. The German ARC acknowledges that undertakings can have market power even without a high market share, in circumstances where small companies as suppliers or purchasers of a particular form of goods or commercial services denote that reasonable possibilities of switching to other undertakings do not exist.

It has to be taken into consideration that platforms impose unfair trading practices against business users with the purpose of maximizing profits and earning costs of competition on the seller's part. Accordingly, online intermediary marketplaces gain a superior bargaining position and market power enabling them to extract excessive value from captive business users. To that extent, contemporary EU competition enforcement against online platforms and marketplaces has concentrated on exclusionary abuses, such as self-preferencing, as one manifestation of power imbalances and has not adopted other devices successfully complementing EU competition law in the quest of suppressing the platforms' superior bargaining position.<sup>90</sup> It has to be taken into account that the employment of competition law in the digital economy has concentrated on matters of access to data, interoperability of technologies, and protection of consumers from mistreatment in product markets.<sup>91</sup>

It seems that competition authorities in Europe and elsewhere have been rather slow to react to the development of digital capitalism by trying to handle the problem by applying industrial capitalism era competition law to the post-industrial informational capitalism. There is a need of the transformation of competition by focusing on its technological dimension and its influence on business models.

In essence, evaluating the effects of possibly competitive conduct in complex digital markets necessitates paying attention to how consumers actually behave rather than focusing narrowly on what would be rational for them to do. Consumers as buyers are induced both by specific recommendations and by the modes in which options are filtered.

First of all, as discussed earlier, large digital providers have materialized as gatekeepers serving as gateways for their business users and consumers and exercising control over whole platform ecosystems. These platform ecosystems are

Digital platforms count on their base of users for offering inputs for free and so collecting large-scale data used to train the algorithms of a search engine managed by the platform, which are then utilized in different modes. Also, digital platforms take advantage of their vertical power to lower their input prices by suppressing the wages of their employees or by taking advantage of amplified competition among suppliers and the existence of excess capacity upstream which means that by lowering the barriers of entry in upstream markets triggers the entry by new companies into the production of goods and services serving as inputs to the outputs of the digital platform. Hence, this amplified competition between their suppliers raises their markups.

Also, it has to be taken into consideration that corporations in the digital economy capture an uneven amount of the surplus value generated by innovation resulting from the materialization of the new industry due to new AI technological developments. Moreover, the effective strategy is opting for an “open architecture” via an open ecosystem and so producing higher value. In a digital economy marked by network effects, the position of incumbents is confronted by companies vertically stationed in complementary markets benefiting from network effects, rather than competitors established on the same relevant market.

It is worth mentioning here that competition takes part in several dimensions, beyond product and service markets, above all entrepreneurial assets but more drastically “non-consumption.” Hence, in the digital economy context, one needs to take a more dynamic perspective than product market competition. The Supreme Court underlined the significance of evaluating both sides of a two-sided transaction platform so as to accurately assess competition.<sup>95</sup>

It has to be taken into account that the status of dominance and the status of gatekeeper are distinct justifying the introduction of a new regulatory alternative. The Commission addresses the identified problems in a broader set of circumstances, since present EU competition rules are applied only when certain preconditions are met: such as the existence of an anticompetitive agreement in the case of Article 101 of the Treaty of the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or of a dominant position in the case of Article 102 TFEU. Also, current EU competition rules prevent or address a market failure, but not in the most effective way because they are of a systemic nature. Further, the EU competition rules do not capture all unfair business practices by digital gatekeepers. Jacques Crémer et al.<sup>96</sup> argue “that the basic framework of competition law, as embedded in Articles 101 and 102 of the TFEU, continues to provide a sound and sufficiently flexible basis for protecting competition in the digital era.”

The case-by-case assessment of the influence of a practice is the rule in the EU competition law system. It is worth noting that the determination of the entity which is compelled to offer compensation for damage instigated by an infringement of

Article 101 TFEU is directly governed by EU law and so claiming damages triggered by anticompetitive conduct certifies the full effectiveness of the EU competition provisions which means that there is an advancement of the working of the EU competition rules.<sup>97</sup> The Court ruled that subsidiary liability is available as a matter of law in the private enforcement of EU competition law, so long as appropriate economic, organizational and legal links exist between the parent company and the subsidiary and so the private enforcement of EU competition law deters anticompetitive behavior and the meaning of 'undertaking' does not vary depending on whether public or private enforcement is at issue.<sup>98</sup>

Article 101(1) TFEU is applied formalistically to very specific and clearly anticompetitive arrangements such as naked horizontal price-fixing, output restrictions, and market division and the court<sup>99</sup> has made clear that, for instance, "agreements which aim to share markets have, in themselves, an object restrictive of competition and fall within a category of agreements expressly prohibited by Article 101(1) TFEU, and that such an object cannot be justified by an analysis of the economic context of the anticompetitive conduct concerned." Also, the Court assesses the conduct at hand against the benchmark of a rule preferring to investigate each case in light of a broad range of considerations that appeal to the rationales of Article 101(1) TFEU.<sup>100</sup> Hence, there are resemblances between the development of the by object category and the per se rule in US antitrust law.

It is characteristic that the CJEU<sup>101</sup> mentioned that in a growing market, Article 102 TFEU necessitates action to avert the formation and consolidation of a competitive structure falsified by the abusive strategy of an undertaking which has a dominant position in that market which means demanding action before the anticompetitive effects of that strategy are accomplished. It has to be taken into consideration that anticompetitive effects result from the exploitation by a dominant firm of its substantial market power vis-a-vis customers and/or suppliers due to the lack of effective competitive constraints and so exploitative conduct can be caught by Article 102 TFEU. To that extent, the Court held that EU competition law is concerned with both actual and prospective consequences and so prospective outcomes activate intervention based on the ex ante evaluation of concentrations.<sup>102</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that the DMA will be enforced hand-in-hand with the existing competition rules, as currently enforced both at European and at national levels. Hence, the DMA does not replace antitrust enforcement in Europe but rather complements it with a set of rules that are safeguarding contestability of particular platform services, and abolishing certain forms of unfair gatekeeper behavior.

## 10.12 DMA and Competition

The DMA<sup>104</sup> is founded on the belief that competition law alone is inadequate to successfully address the challenges and systemic problems caused by the digital economy. Undeniably, the scope of antitrust is rationed to certain instances of market power such as dominance on specific markets and of anticompetitive behavior. Also, its enforcement takes place ex post demanding extensive investigation on a case-by-case basis of what are often very complex sets of facts.

The DMA invokes regulatory intervention to match conventional antitrust rules by launching a set of *ex ante* obligations for online platforms defined as gatekeepers. Moreover, the DMA guarantees that markets where gatekeepers are present remain fair and independent from the actual or presumed consequences of the conduct of a given gatekeeper grounded on Article 114 TFEU. It is worth noting that the DMA is not an instrument of competition law not affecting how antitrust rules apply in digital markets.<sup>105</sup> On the other hand, the DMA discloses the same objectives and protects the same legal interests as competition law and so its list of prohibitions is an outline of past and ongoing antitrust cases.<sup>106</sup> The DMA states the promotion of fairness and

Additionally, the DMA imposes a prohibition on granting preferential treatment in ranking services to the gatekeeper's own products and contains provisions blocking self-preferencing via mandated distribution channels or via compatibility restrictions in operating systems, virtual assistants, or web browsers.<sup>107</sup>

In the United States, multiple administrative and judicial bodies operate on the same level but Regulation 1/2003 decentralizes antitrust enforcement by increasing the involvement of national courts and national competition authorities. How should the DMA implement national competition laws? It has to be taken into account that inconsistency in implementing DMA impedes the success of both the DMA and national competition laws. The DMA dictates how some large online platforms operating as “gatekeepers” should act in digital markets before employing a practice to make certain fair and contestable digital markets and so DMA focuses on critics against slow and selective competition enforcement blocking its effectiveness in digital markets.<sup>108</sup> Moreover, NCAs will only back the Commission in enforcing and monitoring the DMA, embracing and collecting complaints and handling market investigations into cases of probable non-compliance. Nevertheless, the member states will implement their own national competition rules, involving DMA-like legislations, insofar they engage in other public interest purposes than guaranteeing contestability and fair markets. It has to be taken into account that ensuring contestability encompasses preventing exclusionary or discriminatory behaviors by gatekeepers obstructing entry by innovating competitors or restricting their capability to expand and attract users which takes place by removing needless barriers to access to data when these represent a major barrier to entry in a market.

The European Commission contemplates antitrust tools unfit to successfully cope with the conduct of digital gatekeepers since they are applied ex post and at the end of extensive investigations of complex facts on a case-by-case and context-specific basis. Hence, the *raison d'être* for the DMA's *ex ante* regulation is grounded on the speed of intervention and enforcement failures than on market failures. Thus, the DMA diverges from the existing regime of antitrust liability more in degree than in the nature of the law and so Articles 101 and 102 TFEU remain applicable to digital gatekeepers. In addition, digital platforms may be prosecuted in parallel cases for the same conduct, which is in conflict with the legal principle of “he bis in idem.” Furthermore, the risk of overlap with competition law is amplified by the DMA's proposed designation process. To that extent, the DMA is covering a gradually large number of corporations rather than Big Tech and native tech firms considering that platform business models materialize in a growing number of businesses.

Undeniably, even though the DMA forbids EU member states from imposing further obligations on gatekeepers, member states remain free to adjust their competition laws to digital markets. Also, member states may exploit national rules on economic dependence to deal with prospective imbalances of bargaining power between online platforms and their business users.

Moreover, the DMA may grant NCAs extra freedom in evaluating cases of refusal to access and so in line with the Europe's essential facility doctrine (EFD), a refusal to deal activates an antitrust violation only when exceptional circumstances are met which means that access to the essential product or service has to be essential for a company conducting business in a market. To that extent, the refusal has to be unfounded and eliminating competition on a secondary market and so if the refusal implicates licensing of intellectual property, it must inhibit the materialization of a new product for which there is prospective consumer demand. Also, in line with the Bronner decision,<sup>109</sup> access to an input is indispensable if there are no technical, legal, or economic hindrances that make it unworkable or unreasonably difficult to copy it. Nonetheless, in Slovak Telekom's decision,<sup>110</sup> the Court of Justice (CJEU) indicated that antitrust enforcers do not have to evidence indispensability when access to the facility has been allowed as a result of a regulatory obligation, instead of voluntarily. Moreover, the EFD exceptional conditions do not apply when the dominant company gives access to its infrastructure but makes that access subject to unfair conditions.

It is worth noting that the German Bundestag adopted an amendment to its national antitrust law and so entrusting the Bundeskartellamt with new powers to ascertain positions of precise market relevance such as companies with dominant importance for competition across markets and the potential anticompetitive outcomes in digital ecosystems where corporations have a gatekeeper function.<sup>111</sup> Moreover, the elements in designating such a company are its dominant position on one or more markets, its financial power or access to other resources, its vertical integration and undertakings on related markets, its access to data significant for competition, etc. and, after the designation has been made, the German competition authority excludes the corporation from engaging in anticompetitive practices. Besides, the corporation can display that the conduct at stake is objectively justified. To that extent, the list of prohibited practices is comparable to the DMA as to be functionally equivalent. On the other hand, the differences are that the German rule considers the list of prohibited practices as exhaustive, and the rule does not deem the practices at stake to be per se prohibited and so embracing a reversal of the

It has to be taken into account that Google has been the first platform to be designated as of dominant importance for competition across markets and the German competition authority has compelled obligations on large digital platforms well before the DMA will enter into force and so thwarting the EU law's effort at harmonization and undercutting its objectives and scope. The Italian AGCM indicated the introduction of a similar rule.<sup>112</sup> Thus, the digital economy regards a single way of implementing legal rules especially in a digital market requiring standardization and automation which means that a federal EU will apply digital rules more effectively due to a harmonized interpretation and so implementation of DMA and competition rules.

Several legislative initiatives reveal leaders' willingness to count on abuse of economic dependence rules to tackle digital platforms' conduct.<sup>113</sup> In 2020, Belgium amended its Code of Economic Law by inserting a rule on the abuse of economic dependence, rationalizing the alteration with specific reference to the legislative gap regarding digital platforms.<sup>114</sup> Moreover, EU member states have endorsed sector-specific legislative initiatives in order to protect weaker parties from the superior bargaining power of digital intermediaries.<sup>115</sup>

It is worth mentioning here that the Federal Supreme Court backed the Bundeskartellamt's strict approach, ruling that a narrow price-parity clause used by an OTA was unlawful under competition law which means that a price-parity clause is not an ancillary restraint exempt from the application of Article 101(1) TFEU and does not fulfill the conditions for exemption set out in Article 101(3) TFEU, because any advantages related with combating free riding do not balance out its anticompetitive effects in the form of a considerable barrier to hotels' own online distribution.<sup>116</sup>

The DMA averts regulatory fragmentation protecting the functioning of the Digital Single Market, as a result of the development of large digital platforms

performing EU wide. Hence, owing to the cross-border character of services offered by platforms, national rules have been considered incompetent to tackle the acknowledged competition problems. On the other hand, the vague connection of the DMA with competition law thwarts the attempt at harmonization.

It has to be taken into account that DMA will not displace competition rules but will be employed alongside them and so the parallel function of the DMA and antitrust rules creates risks of double jeopardy and conflicting decisions, which means that it endangers the integrity of the internal market by destabilizing both the DMA's justification and its legal basis.

Taking into account that market forces alone are unable to discipline digital platforms due to the barriers to entry integral in digital platform markets, traditional antitrust law is incapable of protecting effective competition in the digital market. To that extent, concerning Big Tech conduct, EU decisions outlawed conduct that had happened several years before it was brought to the attention of the Commission and so enforcing Article 102 TFEU years after the fact is challenging in markets for services based on rapidly advancing technologies. DMA regulates the conduct of powerful gatekeeper platforms boosting the contestability of core platform markets and guaranteeing fairer conditions for users. The European Commission has regularly examined Big Tech conduct under the EU Merger Regulation. Recently, the Commission applied the EU Merger Regulation, even if the transaction is not caught by the EU Merger Regulation's own jurisdiction threshold or the national jurisdictional thresholds of the referring member states.<sup>117</sup> It seems that courts underestimate the danger of false negatives concentrated on short-term efficiency consequences to the detriment of long-term harm to the structure of competition and consumer welfare.<sup>118</sup>

It is worth noting that the legal effect of a prohibition decision under Article 102 TFEU is inherently case specific. Moreover, the Article 102 TFEU protects competition against the abuse of market power not dealing with barriers to entry that are inherent in a market and that are not the outcome of anticompetitive conduct. The Article 102 TFEU prohibits exclusionary conduct that is not a competition on the merits.<sup>119</sup> It has to be taken into account that the Commission favors of in-depth case-specific analyses and so endorsing in-depth economic assessments in individual cases alike US approach which comes in contrast to the line followed by DMA<sup>120</sup> which was enacted to address the strong concentration of digital platform markets. It has to be taken into account that the conduct rules in the Article 5-7 DMA are per se

rules reducing barriers to entry by forbidding conduct that is expected to exclude competitors. DMA safeguards contestability and fairness in digital markets by offering several presumptions based on thresholds relating either to the annual turnover and market capitalization of the corporation or to the number of its active users in the EU. Hence, gatekeepers have to comply with a set of rules and will be banned from engaging in conduct such as combining personal data from different core platform services.

Furthermore, DMA contributes to the appropriate running of the internal market by laying down harmonized rules that make certain contestable and fair digital markets across the EU which means that undertakings overcome barriers to entry and expansion and so disputing a gatekeeper on the merits of their products and services. In other words, the DMA bans gatekeeper practices increasing barriers to entry resulting from network consequences, economies of scale, and strong returns on the use of data and so lowering barriers to entrance. One of the cons of DMA is the fact that the DMA's conduct rules do not apply to any digital platform service but only to "core platform services" offered by "gatekeepers" only.<sup>121</sup> Furthermore, the DMA only applies to core platform services presented to users established or located in EU and so not regulating gatekeeper services run by gatekeepers to users established and located in other jurisdictions.

As mentioned earlier, the DMA constitutes a new regulatory instrument<sup>122</sup> designed to limit the economic power held by "gatekeepers," that is digital platforms that operate as "gateways" between business and end users by centralizing implementation within the European Commission, generating a notification procedure for gatekeepers relying on litigation before national and European courts to resolve interpretive disputes and raise compliance incentives. Moreover, DMA drops the threshold for intervention compared to competition law and so exemplifying presumptions of monopoly power and anticompetitive effects which means that economic study of the facts underpinning market structure or business conduct is no longer a condition for the application of the law. Also, DMA focuses on three "kinds" of competitive relationships that might be vulnerable to exclusionary impacts: "interplatform," "intra-platform," and "extra-platform" competition.<sup>123</sup> To that extent, DMA Recital 33 recognizes that there can be an inter- and an intra-platform dimension to competition in stating that "the obligations should also address situations where the position of the gatekeeper may be entrenched to such

an extent that inter-platform competition is not effective in the short term, meaning that intra-platform competition needs to be created or increased.” Hence, DMA identifies an extra-platform dimension and so the prime function of the DMA is to guarantee that markets where gatekeepers are present are contestable and fair, irrespective of any wrongdoing or change to the industry structure through corporate reorganization to make possible the entry of new competitors in CPs.

It has to be taken into consideration that the DMA does not encompass an efficiency defense which is in line with its legal objective, that is not to improve consumer welfare directly, but to eliminate barriers to entry by generating conditions for effective competition and so abolishing the necessity to carry out complex economic assessments which means speeding up enforcement and dropping enforcement cost. To that extent, the Commission enforces the DMA by way of decisions establishing noncompliance with the conduct rules.<sup>124</sup>

It is argued that per se rules may outlaw conduct that does not have any detrimental consequences in individual cases and they can fail to catch conduct that instigates actual harm. On the other hand, the *ex ante* prohibition of particular actions allows that well competitively functioning of the market as a whole and so promoting competition and prohibiting anticompetitive process. Moreover, *ex ante* rules may be improved to catch up any conducts triggering actual harm on the market. Furthermore, the DMA complements the EU competition rules considered incapable of protecting effective competition in core digital platform markets and so by banning many forms of exclusionary conduct *per se*, it tackles the core shortcomings of Article 102 TFEU but not launching any new substantive principles for assessing gatekeeper acquisitions. To that extent, it has to be taken into account that Article 22 of the EU Merger Regulation<sup>125</sup> in conjunction with gatekeepers’ duty under the DMA to notify the Commission of any planned acquisitions, the likelihood of the Commission being unable to call in an acquisition it would like to scrutinize more thoroughly is drastically downgraded. The DMA’s conduct rules outlaw a broad array of exclusionary leveraging strategies via acquisitions and so tackling certain non-horizontal concerns arising from gatekeeper acquisition. It is worth mentioning here that the DMA establishes per se conduct rules for designated platforms precluding national gatekeeper regulation by EU member states, thus the legality of the German sec. 19a GWB has to be re-examined. Any bypassing actions taken by digital platforms can be dealt with an improvement of merger rules.<sup>126</sup>

It is worth noting here that mergers in digital markets have often slipped the attention of competition agencies. In 2023, the European Commission is simplifying procedures with another merger control package, yet without changing the

thresholds.<sup>127</sup> Moreover, merger cases in the digital world have characteristics that make them avoid the filters due to the fact that corporations run with free offers so as to create a large user base which means that where a legal filter relies on turnover such as price-based parameters, it fails to recognize the power of the target. The European Commission acknowledged a new strategy in the digital economy, “where services regularly launch with the aim of building up a significant user base and/or commercially valuable data inventories, before seeking to monetise the business.”<sup>128</sup> Hence, a merger control regime built on a double turnover threshold assumes that both parties need to have some significance as signaled in revenue for markets in order to be relevant for competition. Moreover, current merger control does not function well when financially strong corporations acquire companies with very little revenue, but a strong prospective for competition. DMA encompassed a specific rule targeting the merger activities of digital gatekeepers<sup>129</sup> and so digital gatekeepers have to notify all merger activities in the digital sector to the European Commission. Also, the European Commission informs national authorities that, in turn, may refer the mergers to the European Commission for merger control in line with Article 22 of the Merger Control Regulation. Thus, the notification under Article 14 DMA in connection with referrals under Article 22 ECMR leads to increased merger control but it relates to a small number of designated gatekeepers. In the Towercast case,<sup>130</sup> the Court of Justice was asked to rule on the formal question whether Art. 21 ECMR prohibits the French authority to investigate a merger for an abuse of dominance and the Court held that the ECMR does not stand in the way. Thus, in its Towercast judgment of 16 March 2023, the European Court of Justice ruled that national competition authorities (“NCAs”) and courts can review acquisitions by dominant entities under the abuse of dominance rules, if those acquisitions are not notifiable under EU or national merger control laws and so generating legal uncertainty and risk for dominant corporations, along with openings for rivals and customers to challenge such transactions.<sup>131</sup> Hence, the ordinary inapplicability of ex ante merger control, either at EU or national level, does not prevent an assessment of a transaction under Article 102 TFEU by NCAs after the concentration has been implemented. thresholds, and, at the same time, have not been referred to the EC pursuant to Article 22 of the EUMR, may be subject to Article 102 TFEU which indicates any concentration between undertakings that have not been notifiable under either European or national merger control law is subject to an ex-post review in light of abuse of dominance rules. In other words, strengthening a dominant position via an acquisition is not in itself sufficient for finding an abuse and so the merger must “substantially impede competition” denoting that the acquisition of the target must make a material difference in the competitive landscape and signposting that the merger must have in reality resulted in near-total abolition of competition which is in line with the test in Continental Can,<sup>132</sup> where the Court settled that a conduct “can be regarded as an abuse if an undertaking holds a position so dominant that the objectives of the Treaty are circumvented by an alteration to the supply structure which seriously endangers the consumer’s freedom of action in the market, such a case necessarily exists if practically all competition is eliminated.”

It could be said that mergers and acquisitions in the EU are subject to either an ex ante review under Article 22 EUMR or ex-post review under Article 102 TFEU which means escalating uncertainty in deal-making. An approach that all non-reportable transactions could be reviewable under Article 102 TFEU generates in fact an obstruction of competition in the market by transferring trading advancement in the courtrooms instead of in the market function.

The proof of anticompetitive effects is increasingly taking the form of a dialectic process, where the Commission is required to adduce sufficient proof that the conduct is capable of producing anticompetitive effects relying on certain presumptions or assumptions, but the dominant undertaking may present evidence to the contrary that is evaluated.<sup>133</sup> To that extent, the court concluded that there is no need of proving the loss of consumer welfare and it is appropriate to prove that that practice is impairing the effective competition structure of the relevant market, without it being required to prove that that practice may also instigate direct harm to consumers.<sup>134</sup> and so the content of competition law is expected to consist largely of formalistic legal rules.<sup>135</sup>

Albeit *ex ante* regulation has many advantages, DMA although friendly towards speed, efficiency, and legal certainty while enabling actions for damages leaves the scales very unbalanced particularly concerning the freedom to conduct a business as a fundamental right, irrespective of wealth or economic power, and the protection of

It has to be taken into account that AI is highly opaque which means that anticompetitive contact is difficult to be spotted even for well-equipped public enforcement authorities and so antitrust intervention will be instigated too late to prevent irreparable harm.<sup>138</sup> In addition, Thomas Höppner and Luke Streatefield<sup>139</sup> argue that “the characteristics of the AI stack have all ingredients for winner-takes-all battles with significant collateral damage affecting third party businesses. . . the rise of AI is prone to make big tech companies even more powerful. Their vertical integration across the AI value chain creates conflicts of interest that may quickly lead to anti-competitive leveraging conduct.” It seems that the DMA does not address the specific competition issues around AI. On the other hand, gatekeepers have the most powerful devices to suppress the diffusion of any rival AI offerings.<sup>140</sup>

DMA protects competition as a process by ensuring and advancing competition for the gatekeeper market, in the market, and other related markets.<sup>141</sup> Thus, competition is seen as a device for leveling the playing field in digital markets and so advancing competition on the merits and in terms of better services for consumers, which is protected and boosted with the help of the DMA. Hence, the DMA strives to not only limit corporations’ data extraction and consumer exploitation practices but also stimulates data access and data and user mobility by permitting multi-homing and switching and so giving users a certain level of data sovereignty and real choice in the digital realm. It is characteristic that the DMA chooses a centralized model with concentrated enforcement powers at the EU level rather than decentralized or parallel enforcement at the EU and nation-state levels. ## 10.13 Data and Competition

It is worth mentioning here that Art. 102 TFEU protects undistorted competition covering competition on the merits applying when there is harm to the competitive process and all the requirements given under Art. 102 TFEU are proven.<sup>143</sup>

Digital data generate new modes of control and new repositories of economic and social power and so platforms and algorithms are products of data given that they operate due to data. To that extent, while digital data are amassed in manners that have governance implications, digital data flows stimulate platforms’ growth. State data-collection infrastructure ranges to all sorts of smart installations and remote-sensing technologies. Hence, digital data are expressive of particular, social, legal, and economic relations which means that the use of digital data is capitalizing greater precision than statistics have previously exhibited.

Modern administrations gain their power from information and capitalism prosper via the accumulation of knowledge. Information has become a corporate asset to be valued on its own terms for the stream of services that it produces which means that digital businesses boost their value because of their databases and the scale of subjects encompassed by these data points. Thus, companies exploit information to make their production process more effective and sorting people and things in line with value potentials.

Consumers access digital platforms for a variety of reasons, and in doing so are turning themselves into unpaid data producers. The spread of cyberspace and communication technology has aided the widespread availability of global data. It has to be taken into account that data conveys noteworthy social, economic, and political power and so unequal control over data, being a prevalent form of digital inequality, is a problem for economic development. Hence, data inequality is a function of unequal control over the infrastructures that produce, form, process, store, transfer, and use data. It is characteristic that geopolitical contests and transnational competition between companies refer to data’s value and the “free flow” of data across borders and the need for “data sovereignty.” Data is of value to acquire AI technology dependent on large data sets, and is valued, when there is a market for

datasets or when the value of data is embedded in the value of a corporation, appreciated upon sale or merger. Moreover, data is an input for a wide array of activities in the digital economy expanding the notion of complementarities usually taken into consideration in the process of economic production and so verifying interlinkages between activities.

AI has advanced rapidly and is nowadays widely used in customer-service contexts. Electronic payment systems connect multiple participants and make certain complex technological operations linked to the movement of huge flows of payment information and data.<sup>144</sup> It has to be taken into consideration that threat springing from Big Tech using big data is not only just market dominance but it is also the potential to transform free contracting and markets into a dominated space offering an advantage to sellers over buyers. Thus, sellers retain the predictive power of data to their advantage against their own clients, who are also the data producers. To that extent, Big Tech corporations collect personal data, use it inferentially to rank and segment individuals, and then sell those inferences to others or use them to develop new products and service and so generating a new form of “differential rent.”

It could be argued that data as a source and as a process of governance will be expected to replace both markets and the law. Also, it could be said that the law will govern the utilization of data. AAI rule of law will govern all society’s function based on AAI laws endorsed by an AAI society via its AAI governance.

It seems that in an AAI society, data is not as an object of transactions or an object of governance, but as a tool for governing others will surpass nation-states with their law. Hence, the rise of Big Tech corporations and their accumulation of vast amounts of data, not available to any state, generates the “rule by data.” Of course, during the period of the technical governing of the functioning of AI, Big Tech will necessitate a rule of data, but AI law will govern the functioning of Big Tech companies. An anarchic/chaotic way of rule of date will prevent the autonomous function of AI companies and all the needed transactions in an AAI society.

In the era of digitization, picks about which data is produced are matter of infrastructures enabling data collection through devices, sensors, and platforms. To that extent, governments authorize access to data via statutory and regulatory mechanisms necessitating public reporting or provision of data to particular government agencies, competitors, or consumers. Moreover, companies utilize legal instruments like contracts or licenses, often embedded in regimes of personal and intellectual property, to prevent access to data or to establish conditions for such access.<sup>145</sup>

As technology companies grow more economically dominant, the centrality they place on data collection advances the stakes of data-governance law ruling how data about people is collected, processed, and used. While data becomes an indispensable factor of informational capital, the law regulating data production becomes the

principal regarding how and why to regulate informational capitalism. Thus, there is evidence of the role that digital technology plays in assisting social and economic inequality.<sup>146</sup>

Data is an asset that is tangible and its value is stemmed from using or exchanging it. Most of the data's value is stemmed from economies of scale such as the capacity to process, analyze, and use them with the purpose of inducing behavior in others. What counts is their predictive power which is monetized by the data controllers when selling access to the raw data or the results of algorithms that produce the required predictions. To that extent, the transference from anticipated returns on assets to the predictive power of data to assess consumer behavior is considered as a new act in the evolution of property rights.<sup>147</sup>

It has to be taken into account that data is an economic asset and is considered as a factor of production which means that the data market is ensuring high-quality development. Hence, big data is a “fundamental strategic resource” and countries adopt policies to facilitate the development of big data industries by advancing strategies relying on big data-driven solutions. Countries informatization strategy based on data to back and transform their state functions such as policing, surveillance, social control, and delivery of government services.

Data regarding people generate revenue in three ways: corporations can sell it directly; use it to advance services; or use it to predict, change, or adjust behavior. Most data collected about people are governed by contractual terms of service, subject to the Federal Trade Commission Act's Section 5 and state consumer-protection oversight. Moreover, specific privacy laws have granted extra rights to consumers over specific kinds of data, such as consumer credit data, health and financial information, and educational information.<sup>148</sup>

It is worth noting that data play a central role in both descriptive and critical accounts portraying the contemporary digital political economy as “informational capitalism” which denotes production centrally oriented around extracting and processing information so as to extract and stockpile wealth and so transforming information in the form of data into a crucial productive resource. Hence, it could be said that among competing technology corporations, greater access to high-quality data is a central competitive advantage permitting them to develop better algorithmic products, get better insights into their customers and price goods, services, or bids more strategically. In other words, corporations involved in data collection view data production as a fundamental element of what makes the digital economy profitable.

It is worth mentioning here that Big Tech companies have monopolized the informational content and governance power of data and monetized it by permitting only selective access to it. In addition, Big Tech corporations are transforming raw data in order their use to become worthy. Hereafter, digital platforms rely on gathering and processing different types of data constituting a source of market power or dominance. Hence, user data can be a source of escalating returns, as a result of either economies of scale and scope or learning effects to the extent that more user data enable the digital platforms to train better the algorithms underlying their services. Moreover, platforms functioning in many markets collect data from different markets and so creating a “richer model of consumer behaviour.”<sup>149</sup> Business-facing publications underline the significance of data for maintaining and achieving competitive advantage.

Data is central to machine-learning-based products and services and is deemed strategic as a result of its externalities for industries, governments, and society. Hence, these externalities produce new forces within a business altering competitive dynamics, and so calling for new strategies and management practices which means that there are substantial consequences for regulators.<sup>150</sup> Especially, data availability generates a growth cycle between data volume and algorithmic quality because more data advances a better quality of products and services and so, in turn, demand is augmented leading to an even higher volume of data completing the cycle.<sup>151</sup>

Facebook is a private corporation owning its existence as a legal entity to state law and its relations with customers are embedded in contract law and the firm guards its assets such as its users' data protecting against hacking that is akin to property rights. Also, digital corporations are much better equipped to protect their data and data devices than law enforcement agencies and so Facebook excludes users who do not accept its conditions from access to its platform, and, by offering a “take-it-or-leave-it” option, compel its own rules on its users without the help of state courts.

Is there a “clash” between data protection and competition law? First of all, data protection law and competition law engage in different primary objectives but there are three relevant common objectives connecting these two legal regimes such as protection of the internal market, protection of consumers against unfair conditions, and protection of competition. Moreover, it could be said that competition law and data protection law both aim at protecting competition as it comes out from Articles 101 and 102 TFEU in tandem with Article 20 GDPR aiming at protecting not only

To that extent, the European Commission termed privacy as a factor of competition<sup>153</sup> and the Court of Justice denotes that the access and processing of personal data is a factor of competition in the digital arena.<sup>154</sup> Thus, the GDPR scrutiny by antitrust regulators and imposing strict limitations on the personalized use of consumers' personal data by social media platforms are permitted. To that extent, Klaus Wiedeman<sup>156</sup> argues "that the objectives of competition law and data protection law are not contradictory per se and that it is oftentimes possible to apply these legal regimes in a complementary manner and with positive synergies."

## 10.15 Data, Information, and IPRs

Taking into consideration that data is at the heart of the digital transformation, access to and use of personal data and no personal data perform an imperative part in all sectors of the economy. To that extent, data is often an important input for online service, production processes, logistics, smart products, and AI and so the competitiveness of corporations is increasingly grounded on timely access to relevant data.

It is worth noting that digital firms, especially Big Tech, strengthen their market power by establishing ecosystems, or “enclaves”.<sup>168</sup> Also, Big Tech’s dominance is underlined by the mass collection and use of personal data restraining the capability of new entrants and startups to even enter a market which means lower competition leading not only to higher prices for customers or other companies but also societal harms by strangling innovation. Hence, a central problem is the capacity of Big Tech companies to produce massive data “enclaves” offering a noteworthy competitive advantage when it comes to the utilization of algorithmic technologies and AI. Besides, it seems that the Canadian Supreme Court based on the logic of economic efficiency favors large corporate entities and concentration market.<sup>169</sup>

Moreover, the CJEU has held that limitations and exceptions to the exclusive rights of copyright must be interpreted narrowly as they are exceptions to the general rule that right holders must enjoy "a high level of protection" in relation to their protected subject matter.<sup>176</sup> In the EU legal order, proportionality<sup>177</sup> establishes an imperative analytical mechanism to decide the permissibility of limiting certain rights and interests. In copyright law, proportionality has already become almost synonymous with the concept of a "fair balance." The CJEU is not so clear on the relation between copyright and freedom of expression but the two rights are internalized in copyright law. To that extent, in Pelham<sup>178</sup> case, the CJEU ruled that the owner of a right in a sound recording cannot preclude the use of a sample of that recording if the user mixes the sample in a new work "in a modified form unrecognisable to the ear" and so such use does not amount to a reproduction within the meaning of Article 2(c) InfoSoc Directive. Additionally, in Funke<sup>179</sup> and in Spiegel<sup>180</sup> cases, the Court held that in certain cases full reproductions of protected works do not need authorization if such uses fall within one of the exceptions encompassed in Article 5(1)-(3) InfoSoc Directive.

Databases are either protected as original databases,<sup>181</sup> if they display originality in the arrangement of the data,<sup>182</sup> or as sui generis databases,<sup>183</sup> if the creation of the database requires significant investment in the collection of the data. Moreover, the CJEU<sup>184</sup> is excluded from the scope of protection databases in which the investment established the creation of the data, instead it emphasized that the protection is granted for investing in "the resources used to seek out existing independent materials and collect them in the database." Taking into account that the rationale of the sui generis right is to protect the significant inversion made by the database maker in the obtaining, verification, or presentation of the contents of his/her database, only those “extraction” and/or “re-utilization” acts that trigger noteworthy detriment—evaluated qualitatively or quantitatively—to the investment of the database maker are prohibited and be contrary to Article 7(1) of Directive 96/9/EC. Hence, it is needed to strike a fair balance between, on the one hand, the legitimate interest of the makers of databases in being able to make up for their substantial investment and, on the other hand, that of users and competitors of those makers in having access to the information encompassed in those databases and the likelihood of producing innovative products based on that information. Concerning the use of search engines and hyperlinks and their relationship, from a copyright perspective, with databases, the CJEU is balancing the legitimate interests at stake and so the CJEU prohibits the existence of an “extraction” and “re-utilization” of the content of a database without the consent of its maker as long as such acts deprive the database maker, or endanger its right to redeem the cost, of his/her investment.<sup>186</sup>

It has to be taken into account that algorithmic decision-making can deliver discriminatory outcomes even without discriminatory intent owing to bias in the data that the algorithm is trained with and so data governance rules diminish those biases by shaping such data.<sup>187</sup> The Data Governance Act (DGA)<sup>188</sup> creates a legal framework for data sharing for the benefit of the European single market, guaranteeing neutral access to data and interoperability and so DGA increases trust in data sharing by introducing new EU rules on the neutrality of data marketplaces and so augmenting trust in data sharing, strengthening mechanisms to boost data availability, and overcoming technical obstacles to the reuse of data. There is an effort of boosting secure global digital connectivity along with the digitalization of the public sector and the employment of digital technologies for public services. To that extent, European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs) are one-stop shops backing corporations and public sector organizations to respond to digital challenges and become more competitive.<sup>189</sup>

The Data Act<sup>190</sup> complements the DGA by amplifying the value of data in the economy and so making certain that a wider range of stakeholders get control over their data which means that more data is available for innovative use, while safeguarding enticements to invest in data generation. Moreover, the Data Act eliminates barriers to access data, for both the private and the public sector, while protecting investments in data generation by safeguarding a balanced control over the data for its creators. Hence, the Data Act gives individuals and businesses more control over their data via a data portability right, copying or transferring data easily from across different services, where the data are produced through smart objects, machines, and devices. Also, the EU Data Act offers a regulatory framework to govern and make easier the sharing, use and re-use of cyberspace product-generated data making easier to switch between cloud providers.

It is worth noting here that large corporations with many users, predominantly digital platforms and intermediation services, data aggregators, social network providers, and search engines have come under scrutiny for supposedly collecting vast amounts of data from their users, raising prospective fears around their capability to use such data to place competing corporations at a competitive disadvantage. While the DMA subjects “gatekeepers” to its data access needs, and existing competition laws do not instruct data sharing between corporations outside of the needed facilities framework, the Data Act has been expected to promote competition in aftermarkets for IoT products by giving users the power to demand that the data created by their use of a product or linked service be shared with a third party for reasons determined by the users along with preventing the sharing of data with corporations described as “gatekeepers” under the DMA.

## 10.16 Market Power and Platforms

Articles 101 and 102 TFEU protect competition from distortion that results from the use of market power but it seems that digital platforms have entrenched market power controlling entire ecosystems and so there is long-term harm to innovation and consumers.<sup>191</sup>

It has to be taken into account that in order to apply EU competition law, one has to prove a certain degree of market power<sup>192</sup> and so considering the market power of digital platforms is required by competition law in the EU preceding the

It has to be taken into account that algorithms are utilized in the examination of large datasets to detect cases of anticompetitive conduct due to the fact that algorithms have the capability to assess the influence of mergers and acquisitions on competition, predict the future market trends, and ascertain behavioral patterns denoting the occurrence of anticompetitive practices. Moreover, in the EU, the appraisal of the market power of an undertaking is an indispensable factor in merger control and when judging the anticompetitive effects of agreements which means that the existence of barriers to entry is at the heart of persistent market power.

Also, digitalization is transforming the structure of many markets and payment services. Hence, the application of competition law necessitates establishing a certain degree of monopoly power and its anticompetitive use to be ascertained in each individual case and thereby in the case of Article 102 TFEU, the provision tackles only conduct by “undertakings of a dominant position within the internal market.” On the other hand, Article 101 TFEU tackles collaborations between undertakings in the form of agreements or concerted practices that have as their object or effect the restriction of competition which means that the provision covers anticompetitive restrictions on the premise that they stem from the exercise of a certain degree of market power.<sup>193</sup> To that extent, it is well-defined that a competition law infringement is established because undertakings had coordinated their behavior which means that a restriction of competition as required by Article 101 TFEU is established grounded on the foreclosing outcomes of a bundle of similar contracts between undertakings and their clients.<sup>194</sup>

It is worth noting that competition law is generally reluctant to recommend conduct that energetically advances competition from other firms and so the refusal of a market-dominant company to permit prospective competitors to access a certain facility or an input can only be considered as “abusive” under Article 102 TFEU which means that where the facility or the input is indispensable for entering an adjacent market and the denial of access abolishes all competition in this neighboring market.<sup>195</sup> Anyway, the “digital gatekeeper” standpoint nonetheless has no jurisprudential foundation under Article 102 TFEU to constitute a self-standing legal test of dominance.<sup>196</sup>

## 10.17 Digital Power of Platforms in Digital Sovereignty and Data Ruling

### 10.17.1 Introduction

Digitization has altered economies, societies, and access to information and so providing new products and new services. It has to be taken into account that a state is an entity implementing power over a given territory that is inhabited by people to whom the sovereign's power extends.<sup>199</sup> Moreover, it has to be taken into consideration that states still could invoke their legal and regulatory powers to reign in Big Tech's digital powers.

It is characteristic that the race for monetary sovereignty in the digital world is underway and particularly, in China, the state has gained dominance over digital technologies and is using them to strengthen its power both domestically and globally.

Law is a social organizing mechanism which means that as long as legal authority is considered legitimate, law is used to govern large, heterogeneous social groups and so law is a powerful device for ordering the horizontal relations among individuals, corporations, state, and even the legal global order. It has to be taken into consideration that the digital code is a scaling technology on equal footing with, if not more powerful than, national law even if it diverges from state law in several respects. In fact, a digital code is not the product of legislation but people who rule the digital code work, either on their own account or on the account of corporate or state employers, are the ones in charge. Hence, by using a digital platform, users

### 10.17.2 *Digital Sovereignty*

Digitalization alters conventional politics and the way political decisions are made. Additionally, digitalization modifies democratic and state rule-making by altering forms of political governance owing to the transformation of the law into AI law by inserting automation which means the transformation of norms such as conventional transparency due to a kind of anonymity in digital society but, on the other hand, AI technology should encompass proceedings of avoiding anonymity and so averting any illegal political action grounded on biased data, etc. Governmental digitalization has ascertained technology corporations' products and staff as influential mediators of governmental and intergovernmental relations globally.<sup>203</sup>

State law is based on borders and jurisdiction. Legal rights and responsibilities are, therefore, dependent on where one is located in space.<sup>204</sup> Territorialism is the practice of nations exercising exclusive jurisdiction over assets and parties within their borders. Moreover, state law determines court jurisdiction within constitutional boundaries. Sovereignty is founded upon the fact of territory, and, therefore, without territory, a legal person cannot be a state. It is worth mentioning here that technology primarily models digital sovereignty and concerning digital sovereignty, G.I. Zekos<sup>205</sup> specified that 'state sovereignty coincides to cyberspace sovereignty creating the state cyberspace sovereignty... states regulate many kinds of electronic actions having in mind the old legal principles adapted to accommodate the digital type of actions... The establishment of universal cyberspace jurisdiction for this electronic place allowing all courts around the globe to deal with the cyberspace transactions and disputes will bring harmony and certainty in electronic trading taking into account that the electronic transactions have the potential to affect simultaneously all jurisdictions.'

Cyberspace governance is not only a vastly dynamic but also an essentially reactive policy field seeking to reconcile the technical and policy heritage of cyberspace with its ever-growing modern-day weight boosted by AI and AAI systems. Will AAI technology with the emergence of AAI humanoids and AAI society generate AAI digital/electronic states of another dimension with AAI state sovereignty? The answer is yes as long as AAI humanoids have the capacity to be transformed into electronic entities of a digital dimension build their own AAI environment of life and existence. It could be argued that there is a state's adaptability in the AI era. Technology strengthens not only the tools of government but also the legitimacy of the government through heightened transparency and

Finally, it is obvious that digitalization along with AAI technology and the emergence of autonomous AAI humanoids, having unpredicted qualities and dimensions, will alter not only the essence of conventional and electronic territoriality but also even the human understanding of territory because of the immaterial dimension of AAI humanoids and AAI world running within an endless electronic Cosmos. The ambit of the AAI electronic Cosmos will be demarcated by the level of the AAI technology. Will the notion of state jurisdiction be abolished in an AAI world? It is forthcoming the AAI state jurisdiction within AAI world. It could be said that in an AAI world, the holder of the more advanced AI technology will govern this world where borders will not have the essence of the conventional borders regulated by the conventional international law but the AAI law will identify electronic borders, the inter-changeability of conventional and electronic borders, etc.

### 10.17.3 Digital Power of Platforms

Digital power is less dependent on territory and it is exercised not through physical coercion, but by modeling the behavior of individuals and groups indirectly and so digital power is augmented from information asymmetries between the data harvesters and their customers on the one hand, and the data producers who also function as targeted customers, on the other hand, which means that this type of digital power grounded on data and selling of goods and service is not enclosed by territorial boundaries. Thus, digital power grounded on the level of digital advancement and centered on the high-tech level of the utilized technology can be exploited to conquer digital sovereignty. Of course, the digital power of digital companies/platforms is implemented in a digital environment being part of digital sovereignty fitting to a conventional sovereignty as long as access to any electronic technology takes part via devices located on conventional sovereignty due to humans' capacity.

Corporations are creatures of the law having a special status as legal persons, that is, entities that have a status akin to humans in that they can own property and contracts, sue and be sued in their own name. Moreover, high-tech platforms/ corporations still rely on state law for their own organization and are organized as corporate entities under the laws of some jurisdiction.

Consumers have a few digital platforms to choose from and their choice set has been declining as platform providers have created powerful network structures and reduced competition by pre-emptively buying up potential challengers. Furthermore, consumers do not enter into a transaction in which their valuation of the platform service is priced, if not in money, then in the value of the data the Big Tech companies expect to harvest from them. Instead, consumers are given free access in return for pretty much unconstrained access to their data. Without price discovery, these transactions benefit the party that has better access to the true value of what is exchanged, namely the costumers' data; and this is the platform provider.

The expanse of digital power of high-tech platforms/companies is restricted by the scope of the digital platform, which is not as fixed as the territory. It could be said

that digital platforms are the new territory, and the rules that govern platform access and use are the new law. Furthermore, the range and scope of platforms reach beyond the size of any nation-state today and so global digital platforms have users around the globe serving not only as service providers but also they control their digital platforms unconstrained by their customers. It has to be taken into consideration that corporations routinely use information to make their production process more effective, getting value from knowledge and so identifying opportunities for revenue. Information has become a corporate asset and digital corporations exploit the information from the millions of people in their databases.

It has to be taken into account that in an effort to get digital sovereignty, the EU opted for a constitutional approach to protect fundamental rights and democratic values. Cristiano Codagnone and Linda Weigl consider<sup>210</sup> that “the EU’s regulatory activism in digital policy-making is a case of a positive policy bubble characterised by an oversupply of policies and legal acts, as opposed to policy underreaction driven by emotional sentiments in the case of a negative policy bubble.”

It is worth noting that technology not only amplifies and threatens existing rights and obligations but also activates the demand and recognition of new digital ones. Hence, it is argued that digital constitutionalism defends constitutional threats caused by MNEs functioning in the digital environment. Per se, EU digital constitutionalism is grounded on the codification of the European Court of Justice’s mission to protect fundamental rights and democratic values, and on the struggle to restrain online platforms’ powers through regulatory instruments. Thus, technological sovereignty is displayed as a device safeguarding the rights and wants of citizens and businesses and in that way associated with consumer protection and matters of competition.<sup>211</sup>

Digital platforms unveil powerful network consequences, making true competition all but elusive<sup>212</sup> due to global tolerance based on the summation and realization of the needs of the states from digital platforms.

### 10.17.4 Data Ruling

It is worth noting that regarded as sovereigns in their own right, platforms are institutions from which users have no realistic option of escaping and it seems that

Does the rule by data become the new rule of law in the digital economy? Taking into account that data will be the moving force in AAI technology since AAI humanoids will be a mush of data, then the rule by data becomes the rule of existence not mentioning that even in the human’s world, the rule by data is the canon.

The rise of Big Tech digital firms and their accumulation of vast amounts of data presents yet another prospect of data-ruling. It seems that Big Tech is not promoting competent markets by collecting and sharing information with its customers or its clients; rather, it is implanting digital platforms into the exchange by extracting information from consumers and selling processed information<sup>214</sup> to numerous customers and so these customers utilize data’s predictive power to make their predictions which means not only ruling the demand and supply of the digital market but also generating a market.

In other words, Big Tech corporations have monopolized the informational gist and governance power of data and monetized it by granting only selective access to it. To that extent, Big Tech corporations are altering them such that their use becomes marketable which means that the Big Tech business is triggering asymmetries of power. On the other hand, consumers access digital platforms for a range of rationales, and, in doing so, are transforming themselves into unpaid data producers and so allowing the data ruling in the digital market which is transferred according to the conventional one as well.

It has to be taken into account the foundations of capitalism<sup>215</sup> and so looking out for the sources of economic value which means that the foundations of digital capitalism are based on big data. Moreover, the economic value is eventually derived from the utilization in achieving the expected economic outcome which is legalized by law and the legalized value is the foundation of capitalism.

Data is a fundamental production factor and so data storage and inefficiencies in data storage construction restrain data-driven endogenous growth. To that extent, Danxia Xie et al.<sup>216</sup> argue that “An economy with higher knowledge stock or greater data output elasticity exhibits heightened market distortion and increased inefficiency... the provision of an appropriate total computing power and equitable distribution among departments is the key to mitigating these distortions.”

It is worth noting that the predictive power of data is produced due to their utility as such without any legal assistance and so differentiating data from the notion of expected returns and other intangible assets, such as intellectual property rights or financial assets, which owe their existence to law. Also, data controllers count on technological barriers to accessing their databases which mean that they have technological channel to govern access to the data they have stockpiled and so Big Tech considered the data it captured as “*res nullius*,” or wild animals things” that belong to no one but can be claimed by whoever catches them first.<sup>217</sup> Moreover, raw data have less value than the value of processed data denoting the added value with data processing made by Big Tech companies and so demanding ownership of data which means legalization. Data are non-rivalrous goods and they are available in infinite quantities which means that the data gatherers only have to capture them and so, in other words, only the processed data and the algorithms that permit data controllers to extract predictive value from them are rivalrous. The General Data Protection Regulation compels prior consent from individuals, or an alternative legal basis, for harvesting any personal data which is given by cyberspace users in order to have access to the offered services<sup>218</sup> which means that the data collectors avoid any legal consequences to a great degree. Data harvesters obtain the economic value from data not by reselling the aggregate data at a higher price but by selling the data’s predictive power which is achieved due to processed value added by Big Tech companies handling. Hence, data harvesters are monetizing their access to raw data by processing these data and giving exclusive access to them. Thus, a new market has been generated that of information which is a new input in the digital economy creating power for the digital collectors.

## 10.18 *Ex Ante Competition Rules and Platforms*

It has to be taken into account that the basis of the tech platform business model is to intermediate the movement of goods or services between upstream suppliers and downstream customers by distinguishing the dominant tech platforms from dominant retailers owing to that supplier to the platforms function with greater autonomy

Digital markets generate network effects, collect data, and enhance their inter-mediation services which increases with the size of its end user basis and so data further reinforces the network effects on both sides of the platform. In addition, digital markets reach a point where the whole demand “tips” toward a single winner attracting so many users that it will virtually become the sole viable system in the market as it has taken place with the Big Tech platforms. To that extent, new platform entrants must reach a minimum efficient scale in terms of the size and scope of their customer basis, data sets, and network effects and so user and data-driven network outcomes constitute imperative barriers to entry for new platform competitors but even lock-in effects making costly for end and business users to switch to competing platforms.

It is characteristic that network effects and market tipping are drivers of market concentration and diminishing contestability of digital markets. Hence, several digital markets are displaying symptoms of increasing consolidation and concentration of economic power in the hands of a few large-scale incumbents who achieved the entrenchment of their market position. Also, it is representative that the existence of decreasing average costs, the global nature of markets, favored access to capital sources, along with the existing features as key players which deter any new entry into the markets denote tipping which means that the market tips in favor of a single dominant platform and concentrates around it. To that extent, tipping generates intense competition between digital platforms in the beginning which eventually drops down to a single or a few powerful platforms that impose their status in the market.<sup>220</sup> Thus, the competition within a digital terrain is not simply to compete in the market but for the market itself because the digital platform by its emergence opens the particular digital market. Also, in such a digital market which is susceptible to tipping, a prospective entrant overcomes the incumbency advantage of established networks through revolutionary innovation generating a new digitally superior market which overtakes the overwhelming advantages the incumbency may have over the new entrant in the form of a large compendium of user behavior data permitting them to overrule any new entrant's attempts to steer consumers in the other direction.

Digital markets accomplish vertical integration and the emergence of conglomerate “ecosystems” and so offering up-stream, down-stream, or complementary services and expanding their presence into neighboring markets. Nonetheless, digital platforms enable the interaction between business users and end users and so controlling an imperative “input” for reaching end users which means that also

Will the platform regulations implicate the future of antitrust law? First of all, the likelihood and magnitude of anticompetitive harm in digital markets may be great. As discussed earlier, the new platform regulations rely on a broad set of ex ante rules that establish presumptions of illegality for specific types of platforms conduct and so the new regulations diverge from the “effects-based” analysis as the default mode of assessment of the “more economic approach.” Hence, the new platform regulations underline the value of economically informed rebuttable presumptions in antitrust analysis and so making antitrust intervention on the simple basis that particular kinds of conduct by powerful platforms may cause prospective anticompetitive harm of noteworthy level. Thus, “probabilism” of the new platform regulations denotes an imperative divergence from the expanding trend in conventional antitrust analysis to make the discovery of unlawful conduct provisional on exhibiting that anticompetitive consequences/outcomes are more likely than not. In other words, the new platform regulations make certain market openness and contestability.

To that extent, a designation practice is established making certain that the new platform regulations only apply to the most powerful digital platforms<sup>226</sup> which have to be expanded to all platforms in order to boost the competitive process. Hereafter, the traditional concepts of “dominance” or “monopoly” fail to account for the fact that digital platforms may exercise significant “intermediation power” permitting them to harm competition, even though they do not hold a dominant position in a plainly defined relevant product market.<sup>227</sup> It could be said that platform regulations are promoting a new model of economic growth in the digital economy, justified in a broad-based distribution of innovative and economic opportunities for many competitors.

It has to be taken into account that the regulatory basis of the new platform regulations echoes the multidimensional harms deriving from the horizontal and vertical incentive structure digital platforms are subject to. Hence, by stimulating contestability, the platform regulations condense structural factors that make easy the entrenchment of incumbents’ market power and so neutralizing their purposes to harm horizontal competition by foreclosing or acquiring competitors which means that by safeguarding fairness and equality of opportunity, the platform regulations diminish the vertical competition matters resulting from running a synchronized marketplace and sales function.
