## 10.19 Competition and Platform Work

Technological developments have been bringing about modifications in the field of work and so the emergence of platform work has brought up all kinds of problems. Is the platform worker an employee and falls within the scope of labor law? Taking into account that platform workers are solo self-employed, it seems that they combine features of the employment relationship with aspects of the self-employed relationship.<sup>229</sup> Also, platforms label workers as self-employed on the basis of the legal system in question and so commercial law applies which means that workers and the platform are accepted to be equal parties before the law with freedom of contract. The platform worker is considered to be an undertaking, which means competition law will apply and so the construction of the relationship first settles whether someone can be held liable for a possible infringement of Article 101 TFEU.

On the one hand, the ECJ<sup>230</sup> shows that it is not inconceivable that a platform worker will be regarded as self-employed. On the other hand, employees are integrated into the undertaking during their relationship not constituting an undertaking themselves by performing work for, and under the direction of, their employer and do not bear the financial risks linked with that work which means that an employee is not respected to be an independent entity and is not an undertaking.<sup>231</sup> In Becu, the Court related the concept of worker within the meaning of Article 45 of the TFEU to that of employee within the meaning of competition law denoting that employees can conclude collective labor agreements without competition law concerns. EU competition law, as a whole, targets the activities of undertakings, understood as economic units and the concept of “undertaking” in EU competition law and its consequences in the field of private enforcement is defined in Skanska judgment.<sup>232</sup> It has to be taken into account that private liability for platform workers can also be detrimental owing to the fact that all corporations of a single economic

Thus, victims of anticompetitive agreements can claim follow-on damages from subsidiaries of firms that were the object of a competition law infringement decision. Article 101 TFEU is applicable to agreements between entities that form part of the same group but do not share related economic activities.<sup>234</sup> Article 101 TFEU precludes any national law stipulating the possibility of establishing joint and several liabilities.

A single economic entity exists looking at the level of decisive influence exercised and so if decisive influence is present regarding the relationship between the platform and the platform worker, then there is a single undertaking and Article 101 TFEU will generally not be applicable. Nonetheless, if platform workers are self-employed, then Article 101 TFEU is applicable which means that Section 3 application arises in the vertical relationship between the platform and the platform worker, but more possible also in the horizontal relationship between platform workers. ## 11.1 Introduction

One of the key values of blockchain technology is the capacity to conduct transactions without a central monitoring organization, such as the government. The decentralized, collaborative approach of the open-source community-generated programs such as the Linux operating system is utilized by large businesses and denoting transference in the industry away from the information-technology-dependent services of the past. Furthermore, many blockchain applications are being developed under open-source licenses. Any business that relies on database integrity can apply blockchain to diminish costs and generate a more efficient, robust system.

IP portrays the knowledge and competences of a company and its employees, stipulating freedom of action in innovation and growth strategy. Moreover, IP is a flexible asset class offering access to new markets, the capacity to advance existing products, and openings to generate new revenue streams which means that IP is a fundamental asset for any company competing in a global knowledge economy.

It has to be taken into account that blockchain platforms empower digital contracts among corporations, persons, and even AI systems. Smart contracts based on blockchain technology are already used for insurance agreements, sales contracts, and more. Moreover, due to its unique characteristics, such as being open-ledger, encrypted, decentralized, and accessible, blockchain technology has the prospective to replace governmental registration systems such as those for land, copyright, trademark, and patents.

Fintech's exceptional features such as reliance on intelligent algorithms and big data strengthen existing trade-offs in regulating financial markets. Information asymmetries comprise a noteworthy contest to international standard setting and enforcement and so concealing the risks to global market integrity which instigates a need for creating straightforward standards in order to defeat differences in national legal systems, markets, and administrative procedures. On the other hand, it seems that financial regulatory transformations due to the economic crises have failed to

take into consideration the quickly shifting face of financial services owing to AI developments.<sup>1</sup>

It has to be taken into account that algorithms provoke concerns for regulators because algorithms automate existing financial functions such as picking stocks, deciding whether to make a loan, or aiding savers to invest for retirement. Moreover, algorithms within a specific business such as money management use common statements and responding in comparable manners to new information, possibly amplifying the reaction.

## 11.2 Outlining FDI

FDI is a non-debt source of development in the finance funding investment projects in the economy expanding the stage of technical progress in the host country and technology transferred to developing countries via FDI is newer than that transferred via licensing. FDI advances managerial knowledge and skills increasing effectiveness and productivity, and provides an extensive selection of goods and services to the economy.

With globalized marketplaces, today's worldwide FDI is out of all proportion to the past. Large foreign companies are expected to have established technologies that they want to transport to the host state and engaging in a large consumer market.

FDI is an imperative source of capital, with a high contribution to the development of the economies, given the positive spillovers generated in host economies. As regards the determinants of FDI, it is valuable to distinguish between horizontal and vertical ones; the former appears among companies functioning in similar lines of business, while vertical FDI encompasses entities that are active in different segments of a value chain. Also, FDI drives the participation in global value chains (GVCs) of local companies and enhances value-added trade. GVCs permit nations, and corporations, to functionally concentrate on fine-grained value-chain stages rather than entire industries and so functional specialization is valuable for many developing countries permitting them to fast-track industrialization even if they lack the capabilities to back entire industries.<sup>2</sup> The institutional environment, the economic development level, the geographic location, and the logistics systems environment are attracting factors of FDI.

Vertical FDI is made by corporations that geographically break their production into stages, typically on the basis of factor intensities, utilizing lower factor prices overseas or dropping transaction costs by internalizing upstream or downstream

<sup>1</sup>Chris Brummer & Yeshu Yadav, Fintech and the Innovation Trilemma, 107 GEO. L.J. 235, 237–42 (2019).

<sup>2</sup>Carlo Pietrobelli, Roberta Rabellotti and Ari Van Assche, “Making sense of global value chain-oriented policies: the trifecta of tasks, linkages, and firms,” JIBS, vol. 4 (2021), pp. 327–346.

activities.<sup>3</sup> If several phases of the production process are portrayed by different levels of labor amount, there is an allocation of the phases with high labor intensity to countries with low levels of labor costs and the phases necessitating lots of skills or capital to high-income countries. Hereafter, there is a complementarity between a company's foreign and home operations, for the reason that both are compelled to produce the good. In the short run, substitution between the employment's levels at home and abroad takes place if an activity beforehand conducted at home is relocated overseas.<sup>4</sup>

It is worth noting that Hellenic corporations that were formerly export oriented turned into MNEs controlling export platform FDI in the Balkans. FDI improves the competence of Hellenic MNEs<sup>5</sup> having a positive effect on Hellenic GDP. Moreover, Hellenic FDI in European Countries follows different patterns in terms of volume, sector, and industrial activity attracted either by lower production costs and taxation or effectiveness-seeking strategies such as the expansion into new markets and searching for synergies and strategic partnerships.

It is characteristic that the establishment of Investment Promotion Agencies (IPAs) has gradually dispersed as one of the leading policy initiatives to draw FDI and so the endeavor of IPAs is an element of both national and local government strategies to draw inward investment. Moreover, IPAs target the general economic improvement of the host economies focused on knowledge-intensive areas where collaborative systemic conditions are more relevant. IPAs have had noteworthy positive effects on the probability of MNEs establishing a first foreign affiliate and expanding their presence<sup>6</sup> but IPAs face the encounter of staying relevant and further increasing their effectiveness within an uncertain global environment distinguished by the digital transformation of the economy and global supply chain vulnerabilities. Thus, IPAs should adopt specialized digital devices to expand their portfolio of digital services by offering their customers more effective assistance which means that by applying AI technologies, IPAs predict the probability of specific MNEs establishing affiliates and so guiding promotional endeavors.

## 11.3 FDI Developments

It is argued that even though FDI offers economic benefits to host nations, government and private reports overstate the value of foreign investment and understate its costs and risks.<sup>7</sup> Moreover, attention has been given to the acquisition of technology-based assets with prospective repercussions for recipient economies in terms of national security.<sup>8</sup>

It is worth noting that foreign investment gives value to states, but it may contribute to income gaps among individuals. It is characteristic that positive reverse technology spillovers represent an indicator of whether home countries could benefit from outward FDI and so the reverse technology spillovers of outward FDI help absorbing and transfer foreign high-tech. Nonetheless, reverse technology spillover by outward FDI is absorbed by the home country as long as there is absorptive capacity. Transfer and imitation happen when the innate endowment of a region reaches a certain level, referred to as the threshold value.

It has to be taken into account that IFDI and OFDI are often intimately connected, with economic benefits flowing from the two-way internationalization of the local economy. Moreover, OFDI increasingly serves as a complementary channel driving home-country development.<sup>9</sup> Vertical OFDI encompassing the relocation abroad of certain parts of the value chain causes substitution consequences between national and foreign labor in the short and the medium run. Equally, cost-saving OFDI augments productivity through a scaled-up demand for national labor due to corporation growth stemming from internationalization. Horizontal OFDI implicating the relocation abroad of whole business pursuits such as production causes negative home-country employment consequences as a result of offshoring. Additionally, OFDI offers opportunities for structural revolution in less developed regions, by assisting local activities to advance the global value and knowledge by investing abroad.<sup>10</sup> It has to be taken into consideration that OFDI generates reverse knowledge spillovers to emerging markets, which spreads knowledge-sourcing channels for bringing innovation to the next level.

Owing to inward and outward FDI, companies circumvent taxation by functioning in tax haven nations, thereby furthering inequities. In addition, sovereign wealth funds and state-operated companies are investors with political motivations that may spoil host countries' interests. To that extent, the Supreme Court stated redistribution

China has become a hotspot for FDI making investments easier by removing barriers, and pushing forward investment protection agreements and double taxation avoidance agreements to protect the lawful rights and interests of investors. The new Foreign Investment Law<sup>13</sup> removes serious hurdles to FDI offering greater legal certainty and so the liberalizing of capital flow is vital for economic growth. According to the IMF cross-border investment “fosters inter temporal optimization of consumption, helps finance the balance of payments, and promotes efficient allocation of world savings.”<sup>14</sup>

China's attitude towards FDI is embracing the accumulation of capital utilized in tandem with working force advantages and so transforming China into a super economic power. Certainly, mergers and acquisitions are vital FDI modes in China, and foreign investors preferably enter the Chinese market by acquiring leading domestic companies.<sup>15</sup> In China, Article 28 of the Anti-Monopoly Law refers to prohibiting a merger only in the event that the conclusion of the investigation is that it “leads, or may lead, to elimination or restriction of competition.” It seems that merger control is strategically employed to restrain the entry of non-national businesses into local markets. Foreigners are not authorized under any circumstances to purchase a majority interest in a large and successful established Chinese company. Besides, in the EU, the European Commission has established the use of merger control for the competitive assessment of concentrations and so Regulation 2019/452<sup>16</sup> came into force, with measures destined at confirming adequate FDI screening in the EU on grounds of security or public

Inward FDI means that companies functioning in a host nation are controlled by corporations rooted in another nation. Hence, FDI encompasses foreign parent companies' equity contributions, reinvestments of earnings of affiliates, and loans to the affiliates. Equity contributions embrace the parent companies' establishment of new affiliates or the acquisition of further interests in existing affiliates; capital contributions to affiliates; and the use of stock to acquire existing corporations. It is characteristic that OFDI is a strategic decision requiring board-level approval reflecting the board's effectiveness as a monitor and advisor for the management.

It has to be taken into consideration that host countries have presented MNEs tax incentives to attract FDI and their prevalent use has resulted in a "race to the bottom" in international taxation which means that countries propose progressively lower tax rates when competing to attract FDI.<sup>17</sup> Taxation avoidance, alone, contributes to inflated estimates of the value of FDI. But, also, FDI has noteworthy direct and indirect costs. Nations have significant incentives to attract FDI even while "casting a wary eye on it."

FDI generates risks to national security since it places the employees of nations and their companies in sensitive and non-sensitive positions within host affiliates offering products or services in support of national security. In control of the affiliates, the nations or foreign corporations have access to high-tech information or materials that are used commercially and also in support of national security. To that extent, crimes associated with FDI are often theft of trade secrets, economic espionage, and bribery, all of which can be foundations to greater harm. Has knowledge been transferred unlawfully from western economies to east and far-east economies via FDI or labor? Has AI technology assisted in a way "illegal" imitation of products around the globe?

Furthermore, FDI offers economic advantages to host countries. On the other hand, the value of FDI has been overstated and the costs and risks linked with foreign investment have been understated. When foreign corporations establish or purchase affiliates in a host country, the corporations bring critical competition and new ideas to the marketplace, through which they make products and workers better. It could be said that the competitive presence of foreign companies has a positive impact on the capacity of national corporations to participate in innovative activities via knowledge spillovers and improvement in product quality and export is boosted by the inflow of FDI.

It has to be taken into consideration that the geographical composition of FDI has switched over time and the most remarkable long-term development being the continual growth of developing Asia as a source of FDI. The international investment regime is undergoing extensive reform and there is a decline in global FDI that coincides with rising IIA protectionism and IIAs enforced under the new IIA regime

<sup>17</sup>Lorraine Eden, "Taxing multinationals: The GloBE proposal for a global minimum tax," Bloomberg Tax Daily Tax Report (Dec. 6, 2019).

no longer stimulate FDI activities which means that rising IIA protectionism has adverse FDI outcomes.<sup>18</sup>

MNEs from developing and transition economies have become central investors in many LDCs. To that extent, a number of MNEs from developing and transition economies have risen to principal worldwide positions in industries such as automotive, chemicals, electronics, shipping, information technology services, and construction. MNEs take into consideration various factors, such as administrative, economic, geographic, and political characteristics, when making investment decisions and the rationale of IIA is to reduce barriers influencing both horizontal and vertical FDI. Dongin Kim and Sandro Steinbach<sup>19</sup> provide evidence “for adverse effects of IIA termination on FDI, more pronounced for brownfield than greenfield FDI and equally significant for both investment margins. An analysis for vertical and horizontal FDI shows adverse termination effects more potent for horizontal FDI. We also find substantial treatment heterogeneity according to industry characteristics, minor for manufacturing and mining and more substantial for agriculture, construction, and trade.”

Privatization magnetizes new entry of the host country companies by reducing the output of the public company which means that more remaining market is left to the prospective domestic companies.<sup>20</sup> G.I. Zekos considers that selective privatization of state-owned enterprises should be the most advantageous strategy in advancing development by introducing new technologies in production line and managing corporate governance via AI systems. Hence, higher competition in the host country market attributable to the domestic enterprises’ entry shrinks the residual demand for foreign corporations negatively touching the foreign company’s incentive to embark on FDI.<sup>21</sup>

FDI is more and more supply global and regional markets, often in the framework of international production networks and the spread of such networks offers new aptitude for developing countries and economies in transition to profit from FDI in the manufacturing sector. To that extent, retaining dynamic scale economies demands succeeding innovative investments and learning means via new AI technologies. Hence, FDI improves competitiveness and creates employment by increasing the welfare of the host nation.<sup>22</sup> To that extent, higher welfare spending by

It has to be taken into account that FDI restrictions lead to lower FDI and possibly reduced competitiveness and so corporations should pursue FDI reform, promotion, and facilitation to sectors that are digital enablers across the new economy. Furthermore, it has to be taken into consideration that social brokers include private individuals who have international commerce expertise and established relations with local corporations and institutions. ## 11.5 AI and MNEs

MNEs started to grow from comparatively simple cross-border structures mainly motivated by the search for natural resources and international markets to more complex global value chains exploiting differences in labor costs and productivity. Technological development rests on localization, as MNE innovation is gradually recognized to count on the knowledge production and absorptive capacity of its subsidiaries. Cross-border mobility of inventors is underlined as a crucial mechanism for global knowledge production by MNEs.

AI technologies in the international production of global MNEs modify the configuration of GVCs due to supply chain digitalization and additive manufacturing and mass customization. Hence, MNEs implement new approaches to business operations augmenting agility and flexibility and so MNEs must handle increasing volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and opacity of the global business environment which means that there is an alteration in the pattern of global investment flows involving diversification, reshoring, and nearshoring.

As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, developments in technology, along with changes in the macroeconomic and socioeconomic dynamics of globalization, the globe is undergoing digital and AI transformation at a rapid pace. To that extent, as corporations have gone virtual and digital, consumer needs and desires have altered considerably.

It has to be taken into account that technological innovations have led to digitized, efficient, and interconnected supply chains and so firms are making certain that digital capabilities are a part of comprehensive risk management strategies for future crises due to the fact that digital supply networks let firms adjusting to the effects of crises by exploiting technologies such as AI. Furthermore, taking into consideration that globalized trade and supply chains have spread in step with upgraded transport networks and corporate enticements to lower production costs, leverage a specialized workforce and get into various markets, the pandemic amplified weaknesses in globalized production strategies since many corporations counted on single specialized suppliers or factories in other countries.

It seems that companies with operations in multiple countries and those with international supply chains have been particularly vulnerable to the upsetting consequences of the pandemic. Hence, the pandemic has caused uncertainties concerning the benefits of a global supply network and so forcing corporations to diversify and develop new supplier networks in multiple areas or upgrade domestic production. Omrane Guedhami et al.<sup>37</sup> argue that “a stronger financial system mitigates negative crisis returns, especially under stringent government responses, while real factors, such as the firm’s supply chain, investments in human capital, research and development, exacerbate negative crisis returns.”

The interconnectedness of networks together with AI and machine learning technologies are transforming how corporations run and compete and their scope and scale, facilitating corporation growth. Hence, in keeping with these dynamics, AI has become an enterprise-wide imperative for most MNEs. Given the breadth and importance of AI, General Counsel (GCs) of MNE legal departments are under anxiety to embark on AI technology with the purpose of delivering improved legal services and advancing internal client and customer experience.<sup>38</sup>

Moreover, digital transformation places noteworthy economic antagonism, embracing pressure on revenue and profit growth, by making possible more competition and separating winners from losers and so leading GCs are taking advantage of productivity-enhancing AI technologies, particularly planned for the legal services market, embracing efficiency and collaboration devices, such as contract management, e-discovery, and transaction support technologies along with transparency devices, including e-billing software, online bidding platforms. Hence, with the purpose of backing the demand for upgraded productivity, legal departments are expanding their use of technology.<sup>39</sup>

AI and related technologies are modeling the dynamics and modifying the operational and structural foundations of MNEs and so the top purposes for a digital strategy are refining process efficiency, augmenting customer experiences, improving employee productivity, and powering revenue growth. To that extent, the majority of CEOs of MNEs are organizing major investments in data and technology in order to remain competitive in this environment where customer desires and expectations are varying rapidly which means that AI technology has become an enterprise-wide imperative for most MNEs. In other words, digitization is a top priority among CEOs at large MNEs across the globe and they are investing in

Antitrust and intellectual property policy enhance an innovative, dynamically competitive marketplace augmenting effectiveness and improving consumer welfare. Moreover, IPRs' role is pivotal by fostering competitive advantages grounded on the capacity for developing and sustaining innovation which demands protection via intellectual property rights. Also, IPR boosts dynamic competition by stirring up investments in new methods and differentiated products.

Is antitrust and the protection of intellectual property complementary or conflicting? How do the antitrust laws associate with the intellectual property laws? It could be said that the interface between competition policy and intellectual property protection trade off short-term inefficiencies but the two bodies of laws seem complementary due to the fact that both pursue a welfare objective. To that extent, competition law protects dynamic competition in the marketplace, while IPRs law safeguards the capability to receive a return on the investments required to innovate which means that both push competition among competitors to be the first to enter the marketplace with a required technology, product, or service.

Likewise, competition law draws a line between allowed business strategies and abuse of IPRs, a line which is often distorted by horizontal agreements, exclusionary licensing restrictions, tie-in agreements, disproportionate utilization of IPRs, and other selling practices. Also, there is a probable abuse of monopoly pricing, in particular in developing countries where operative substitutes to IPR-protected products may not be straight away available.<sup>7</sup> The limited monopolies established by IPRs are not per se anticompetitive or very exploitative but they only turn into anticompetitive when the IPR holder broadens those rights further than their intended and proper scope.

Even in digital markets, entry and exit takes place, shares change, and dominance comes and goes. In digital markets, technology alters quickly. ## 12.2 Property Rights and Competition

Taking into account that vehicles of innovation are intellectual property rights, the use of competition law to promote innovation is principally controversial for the reason that the integration between these two—sometimes opposing—forces is needed.

Patents are counted to be property rights resulting in a strong legal protection that “could lead to a weak application or even nonapplication of competition law.” On the other hand, in many sectors, competition authorities make certain that competition law is applied in patent-related cases. Consequently, even if patents are considered as being strong property rights, competition law still applies to the advantage of consumers and competitive markets.

IP rights and particularly patents are special since they confer exclusionary rights upon the holder, which fits trickily with competition values. On the other hand, the possibility of companies to look for patents is part of competition.

On the patent law side, this means that the patent cannot be modified in its existence by any competition law consideration which means that the full protection of the patent system cannot help the patent holder to validate a possibly abusive behavior under the competition rules. On the competition law side, this means that the fundamental values of the competition rules, such as the abuse of a dominant position, can never be validated by patent law which means that even though a patent confers some kind of market power to the patent holder, it is validated by the need to incentivize innovation. To that extent, competition law is not impeded from being applicable but must accept the granting of IP rights.

The D.C. Circuit and the European Commission place intellectual property inside competition policy and the concept of placing intellectual property within antitrust, and limiting the scope of intellectual property, has common law roots in the English Statute of Monopolies of 1623.<sup>9</sup> Intellectual property rights are granted only to provide an incentive for innovation.<sup>10</sup> Competition analysis sees marketplace competition as an imperative tool for motivating innovation and loss of marketplace competition from a broad grant of intellectual property rights might result in less innovation over time than the broad grant produces.<sup>11</sup> Intellectual property right and the capacity of a competitor to contest markets that are competitive must be balanced

and there is a need to weigh the benefits of allowing competition against the cost to the economic policies advanced by the intellectual property right.

Competition law is connected to IP when it comes to producing growth and innovation in the economy. To that extent, on the balance between IP and competition law, the ECJ's conception is disclosed in the AstraZeneca judgment where the Court ruled that “the illegality of abusive conduct under Article [102 TFEU] is unrelated to its compliance or non-compliance with other legal rules and, in the majority of cases, abuses of dominant positions consist of behavior which is otherwise lawful under branches of law other than competition law.”<sup>12</sup> In other words, even if an undertaking acts lawfully under the patent rules, general law and administrative procedures of a member state, competition law affects the undertaking's conduct if there is an abuse of competition law. Yet, if the conditions of Art 102 TFEU are met, competition law solves a market failure problem. The court ensures continued innovation and dynamic competition in pharmaceuticals and related sectors. In Lundbeck,<sup>13</sup> the Commission considered that the originator and generic firms were prospective competitors that the agreement led the generic firms to reduce their independent efforts to compete on the market and that the motivations to compete were diminished by the value transfer from originator to generic companies. The European Commission found that the pharmaceutical undertaking Lundbeck had abused its dominant position in violation of Art. 102 TFEU.<sup>14</sup> To that extent, the dominant purpose in the specific facts of the case was to make possible market entry and keep competitive efforts in the market for the particular drug. Hence, the Lundbeck decision of the European Commission promotes the understanding that it will be very difficult to demonstrate that patent strategies are abusive, especially since the application of competition rules could interfere “with the patent regime itself and its very rationale”.

It is defined in the Reckitt Benckiser decision<sup>15</sup> that competition law only interferes with patent law, if the domain of the lawful exercise of the patent is left and the patent holder employs practices that are not fully covered by the patent and so in such a situation the competition authorities in the United Kingdom and the EU suspect anticompetitive behavior that cannot be rationalized by the simple exercise of the existing patent. Since a concentration does not create or strengthen a dominant position, effective competition is not considerably impeded in the common market

## 12.3 Liability and AI

AI systems undertake to improve societal well-being and boost efficiency. On the other hand, liability rules have to tackle who bears responsibility for accidents in which AI systems are implicated. Also, the appearance of autonomous AAI systems moves control over these systems away from owners and users and so brings forward the need of human society to attribute in a way full legal personality which will mean liability of AAI systems/humanoids. As AI systems become more autonomous, it also becomes difficult to trace back outcomes to human decisions, and to assign liability to a certain player.<sup>17</sup> In other words, autonomy removes control away from users, and probably from manufacturers. It has to be taken into account that AI systems that can act independently will be unpredictable and so the more autonomy AI systems accomplish, the more unsubstantiated it becomes to assign legal responsibility for their actions to humans.

It is worth noting that a natural person cannot recover noneconomic damages for any emotional or mental distress attributable to the defendant's infringement. Moreover, the European Communities' 2004 Intellectual Property Rights Enforcement Directive (IPRED) compels member states of EU to grant the prevailing plaintiff compensation not only for the "negative economic consequences," such as lost profits stemming from infringement but also for "appropriate cases of . . . moral prejudice"<sup>18</sup> by encompassing both reputational harm and mental anguish and so European courts have awarded such damages in copyright, trademark, and patent cases.<sup>19</sup> Likewise, artists can file suits under a portion of the US Copyright Act

## 12.4 Authorship Under AI and AAI Technology

In many jurisdictions, authors can be solely natural persons and no legal entities and accordingly, creations of copyrighted works are closely linked to the features typical just to humanity. It is characteristic that the US Copyright Office permits to register only the works produced by humans as copyrighted works declining to register the works produced by AI machines or produced by animals. While its refusal does not bar granting of copyright protection to such works, registration can be indispensable for enforcing copyrights in the US works before courts.<sup>34</sup>

AI challenges another prerequisite that needs to be met that of originality and a work is originally eligible for copyright protection if it is the author's own intellectual creation.<sup>40</sup> In Infopaq,<sup>41</sup> the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) has harmonized the standard of originality for every subject matter, not only for databases, computer programs, and photographs. On the other hand, AAI will have the intentionality, creative agency, and understanding needed to participate in authorship as a relational and communicative act in the AAI world. In other words, the technicality and spirituality of AAI creations will be far away from the current human creations through the use of current AI technology since the basis of AAI copyright will be the functionality of an AAI world where humans have to find a place if they abolish the control of the world and the technology.

## 12.5 Copyright and AAI

Copyright law serves a public interest by encouraging authorship as a social and creative practice and the spreading of works to contribute to a vibrant public domain. To that extent, copyright protects original works of authorship, irrespective of the medium in which a copy of the work is reproduced and the Supreme Court<sup>44</sup> held that copyright can protect the pattern printed on a cheerleading uniform, but declined to determine whether the patterns at issue were sufficiently original for copyright protection. Correspondingly, many works of minimal and conceptual art undoubtedly lack any original elements that qualify for copyright protection. Copyright cannot protect works that consist of a single color or a modest pattern of colors and lines.<sup>45</sup>

The law should be technologically neutral and so copyright law should be written to be independent of any particular technology continuing to apply equally across technologies as they occur, without favoring or discriminating between new and old and so the conventional balance between authors and users should be preserved in the digital environment<sup>46</sup> which means that copyright should be treated by AI technology accordingly. Tech-neutrality is about the equal treatment in law of effectively analogous activities and so a digital streaming service may be subject to the same legal rules as a cable broadcaster if their activities have the same outcome, despite the different technological processes involved. Thus, reading online should be regarded by law in the same way as reading a physical paper, since the act is functionally the same no matter the medium. Likewise, selling a digital copy online should implicate the same copyright interests as selling a physical copy over the counter.<sup>47</sup>

Copyright law offers exclusive rights in expressive works so as to incentivize creative activities. On the other hand, fair use prevents copyright from excessively stymying public access and so when access to and use of present works is required for new creativity. It has to be taken into account that analogies can create false equivalents while also concealing the disruptive force of technological change and so we cannot assume that neutral legal treatment will produce a functionally equivalent legal effect which means that when the risks and opportunities shift considerably with the affordances of novel technologies, the costs and benefits of copyright control should be re-evaluated. Moreover, the emphasis is not only on the

The real AI-copyright challenge is to prevent AI's latest technological innovation from upsetting the copyright balance, obstructing its normative objectives, and by this means challenging the social value of authorship, creative progress, and the public domain. In other words, letting humans be the creative creatures in a world dominated by humans because otherwise humans will get the second place on the globe where AAI will bring forward another form of life and so in another AAI dimension, it is questionable if humans can cope with. Thus, the protection of AI-generated works and the tightening of AI development via the expansion of copyright control may spell an uncertain future for human creators, users, and audiences, spoiling rather than advancing the public interest that copyright is meant to serve for the human world but not for the parallel AAI world. It could be said that legal interventions and reform efforts must be undertaken to steer AI and its development in service of the public goals, human interests, and social values. Under the current AI, the programmers direct the authorship of AI and not the AAI itself. The protection of AI-generated works would advance "creative progress" with which copyright is concerned not stultifying creative practices in a thicket of privately owned algorithmic productions. Thus, even the current AI creation has to get copyright ability in order to achieve a progress.

It is worth noting that there is a risk that a human-authored work will be identified as noticeably comparable to a protected AI work due to the growing use of algorithmic copyright enforcement—technology is trained to detect "matches" between works and equipped to investigate claims of independent creation, non-substantial taking, or fair use. Hence, the actual AI-copyright challenge is to prevent AI technological innovation from overturning the copyright balance, blocking its normative objectives, and so undercutting the social value of authorship, creative progress, and the public domain. AI should take copyright into a new dimension for humans' utility.

It is argued that granting any copyright protection to the results generated by AI destroys the human incentive to still invest in intellectual undertaking because creators would feel degraded if machines were treated equally to humans. Moreover, any prospect of equal treatment between creations generated by humans and AI machines is considered as denigrating art to "a mere commodity, producible and consumable upon pushing a button."<sup>80</sup> Taking into account that a subject matter is to be capable of being considered as original, it is both indispensable and sufficient that the subject matter displays the personality of its author, as an expression of his free and creative choices which will be attributed to the programmer of AI machine but in an AAI environment, the AAI creator, acting in more advance manner than any

<sup>80</sup> "make[] illegal copies of pre-selected movies [on discs] and then sell[] streams . . . in a different format than that in which they were bought";

<sup>80</sup> Cofemel – Sociedade de Vestuário SA v. G-Star Raw CV, C-683/17 (C.J.E.U. 2019) (E.U.)

human, will be the creator generating originality expressing his personality and encompassing his creative choice according to the AAI world.<sup>81</sup>

It is argued that the contemporary copyright law and policy should provide AI works with appropriate protection and so amended in order to accommodate AI types of literary and artistic works due to the fact that AI technologies necessitate extensive investment of personal, material, and financial resources. Thus, the awarding of copyright protection to the results generated by AI technologies encourages investment and progress in this field of technology.<sup>82</sup> In the United Kingdom and a few other common law jurisdictions, the existing copyright laws already contain distinct provisions for works produced by computers but they are still applicable to the AI works. Pearlman<sup>83</sup> argues that when AI technologies generate a work comparable to copyrighted works created by humans, they should be treated equally to human authors and consequently should be considered as an author of that literary or artistic work.

## 12.6 Patents and AAI

Innovation incorporates a recombination process across knowledge networks providing significant innovation-specific insights improving upon present economic and psychological understandings of patentability. It is worth noting that there are very aggressive patent owners' attempts to nullify competition. Moreover, exceptionally valuable technologies are worth the cost of war. Thus, technological innovation in fintech and the prospective for patented innovations play a central role in the future of finance.

There is a patent war between high-tech industry against small fintech companies or startups. High-tech industry executives sue disruptors mainly to control competition and preserve market share, or in some cases, to generate licensing fees. Moreover, big corporations leverage their greater resources and patent experience to achieve a competitive edge, even when their infringement claims are not robust, encompassing a litigation tactic.<sup>84</sup>

Congress derives its authority to create the patent system from the US Constitution and federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over patent claims.<sup>86</sup> It is worth noting that what subject matter is eligible for utility patent protection is controversial.<sup>87</sup> Furthermore, under patent law, an idea per se is not protectable, even though an embodiment of the idea is eligible for patent protection. The Supreme Court has created a framework for classifying patents that claim laws of nature, natural phenomena, and abstract ideas from those that claim patent-eligible applications of those concepts.<sup>88</sup> It has to be taken into consideration that the line between technology that belongs in the public domain and technology that is eligible for private property is protected by conferring a patent. In Reese v. Sprint Nextel Corp., the court uncovered that the claim was for a patent-ineligible abstract idea and the court did not find the presence of an inventive concept for the reason that the patent merely utilizes conventional prior art telephone equipment.<sup>89</sup> To that extent, a method of product promotion was considered as an abstract idea that was a basic economic activity.<sup>90</sup>

It has to be taken into consideration that innovators face limitations in using successive patents to track innovation due to the fact that if the upgraded invention is too similar to the original one, the firm may not be able to patent the advances, even when those enhancements are significant and so making the invention commercially prosperous or fixing a setback discovered in the original design.

In patent law, the purpose of nonobviousness should be to reward and incentivize the production of the most socially substantial innovations.<sup>91</sup> Hence, the nonobviousness doctrine averts the patenting of low-hanging inventions that are not costly to discover and develop because of a low likelihood of failure. Judicial opinions have articulated what makes an invention substantial or nonobvious and how to measure nonobviousness in particular cases, and in current conceptual definitions of nonobviousness, a causal theory of innovation is missing. In spite of its uniqueness to patent law, nonobviousness has long been considered a principally vague and unpredictable doctrine. Judge Hand<sup>92</sup> considered that nonobviousness was “as fugitive, impalpable, wayward, and vague a phantom as exists in the whole paraphernalia of legal concepts.”

The necessity of nonobviousness is the crucial condition of patentability because of its central purpose of keeping technically trivial inventions out of the patent system<sup>93</sup> and so nonobviousness encompasses considerable novelty.<sup>94</sup> It is worth noting that the government grants the monopoly linked with a patent when the inventor has generated something adequately different from what came before. By guaranteeing that only substantial technological improvements gain patent protection, the nonobviousness doctrine both incentivizes socially noteworthy innovation and keeps minor technological progresses that do not necessitate patent incentives in the public domain.<sup>95</sup> KSR in particular emphasizes the role of “predictability” in assessing nonobviousness and the nonobviousness doctrine is conceptualized as a device to shift the choice of research projects toward socially preferred ones.<sup>96</sup> It

It has to be taken into account that AI involvement in the invention development falls on a technological spectrum and is provocative for the conventional patent system. It is argued that incorporating AI-generated inventions in the framework of the existing patent system would mean that a natural person should qualify as the inventor, such that a “proxy human inventor” would be named even if this was not the actual “deviser.” Nevertheless, such a patent could be questioned and nullified before courts if it was verified that an AI system was responsible for the invention and that the natural person had been wrongly delegated.<sup>98</sup>

First of all, an AI-based device aids a human creator without contributing to the conception of the invention but, on the other hand, an AI-based device creates AI-generated output satisfying patentability if otherwise made by a human. Nonetheless, dispute arises over whether patents’ disclosure function is restrained when an AI-based tool’s procedure is unexplainable or the production of AI-generated output is inherently not comprehensible as to how, or from which method it was generated. Thus, AI poses a new contest owing to the opacity and its speedy usage acceleration demanding a reevaluation of disclosure theory. It could be said that AI profoundly contests disclosure in patent law, which has not kept up with rapid progressions in AI technology seeking to stimulate the objectives that patent law’s disclosure function is serving for society.

It has to be taken into consideration that the conventional and more modern theories for the patent system are not mutually exclusive and, surprisingly, but little attention to the role of disclosure in the patent system’s treatment of AI inventions is paid. As technological progressions in information and data have formulated, it is easier for inventors to veil and conceal their innovations and so patent law has doctrinally refocused to the disclosure theory. To that extent, the USPTO grants more patents covering AI-based devices as a policy objective and due to the fact that AI is altering patentability with multifaceted algorithms to create AI-generated output, it was chosen the mode of ds inventors delivering greater disclosure of AI in patents. Furthermore, no intuitive data links between AI-based devices and AI-created output induce AI inventors to strive for greater patent disclosure.

The USPTO endorses the predictability and reliability of IP rights relating to AI technology and so the USPTO has acknowledged the significance of patent disclosure as AI patent filings have rapidly boosted. Hence, the US Supreme Court has

It is argued that there is a lack of transparency denoting the use of algorithms and their interpretation even when records are disclosed.<sup>101</sup> In other words, transparency necessitates, at a minimum, a portrayal of the decision's "provenance," embracing an accounting of its inputs and outputs and the key elements that made it. Hence, a lack of transparency indicates the anonymity in the AI context and so transparency occurs where the learning dataset and source code are disclosed together within information concerning its design and factors.<sup>102</sup> Thus, transparency can be achieved via the use of advanced AI explaining in a conventional way of the whole process. In other words, the algorithm's complete decision-making will be made fully understandable to the appropriate human audience.

Under an AAI technology, AAI humanoid robots will understand that the whole AAI patenting process implements the AAI patent system utility, necessity, and functionality in an analogous to conventional patent system utility.

While patent law protects “functional” products and processes, copyright law protects “expressive” works and so patent law is the appropriate means for protecting software if the software is solely (or perhaps primarily) functional, and copyright law is the appropriate means for protecting software if the software is solely (or perhaps primarily) expressive. Hence, if software is both functional and expressive, then software is susceptible to protection by both patent and copyright law. G.I. Zekos<sup>109</sup> considers that software will be patentable as long as there is an invention, and the included creation must not be merely science, but it must include spirit expressed materially or be an intangible content expressing functional effect.

New technology<sup>110</sup> requires technology-specific legislation if there is no possible way to interpret it according to old legislation and so courts typically place an emerging technology in an existing context by analogizing it to previous technologies. Taking into account that one is not allowed to patent solely abstract ideas, nanotechnology as a new field creates problems because patents on basic inventions are inclined to cover larger areas than the final products, with the expectation of developing them in the future into more explicit inventions. G.I. Zekos argues that the patenting of pure science abstract ideas in nanotechnology and the discovery of the nature of human beings or other materials or chemicals cannot be permitted unless there is an invention underway, which means that the idea is transformed into an invention directly and it is not the idea which is to be patented, with an expectation to license it for others to work toward an invention based on the theoretical idea. The technique of arriving at the nanotechnology abstract idea is patentable as an invention, not to mention that if the idea creates a nanotechnology produced phenomenon—probably imitating a natural one—then this is patentable as

<sup>110</sup> G. Zekos, Patenting Abstract Ideas in Nanotechnology, The Journal of World Intellectual Property (2006) Vol. 9, no. 1, pp. 113–136

a purely nanotechnology creation. Otherwise, if abstract ideas are patentable in nanotechnology merely in order to cover the companies' and universities' profits, then all the old scientific theories must be patented retroactively, because many inventions are based on the transformation of those ideas.

Can AI scientific theories be patented? The economic importance of patents has diminished the tendency towards dissemination and sharing among scientists. Patent disclosures have informational benefits across a broad range of technologies but have pure science become patentable as against scientific development is a question that begs answers.<sup>111</sup> With patent standards constantly in flux, it is essential to have up-to-the-minute information on how best to protect inventions in upcoming technologies. Computer/software industry, biotechnology, nanotechnology, bio-nanotechnology, and biochemistry bring forward new scientific theories and knowledge every day which means that it is essential to have something more than merely the scientific theory and knowledge in order to decide on patentability. Thus, in an analogous way, AI scientific theory has to comply with in order to be patented. The functionality of AI inventions concerning computer/software industry, biotechnology, and nanotechnology, bio-nanotechnology or biochemistry products involves a high degree of uncertainty and risk. Hence, AI inventions need to be better incentivized than other types of inventions if they are to make it to the market.

## 12.7 Trademarks and AAI

Trademark law is protecting the public by acting as an indicator of origin and a guarantee of quality and so reassuring the consumers that they are getting the goods they want to get. Moreover, the owner of the trademark, who “has spent energy, time and money in presenting to the public the product,” is protected in his investment from its misuse by pirates. Furthermore, trademark law serves business interests by protecting a business’s valuable rights in its trademark due to goodwill.<sup>112</sup> Firms seek marks that are clear and memorable signifying something about the goods with which they are linked.

First of all, generic terms and descriptive marks, which describe a quality, function, or purpose of the relevant goods, are not protectable.<sup>113</sup> The Lanham Act precludes registration of any mark that is so similar to an already-registered mark “as to be likely, when used on or in connection with the goods of the applicant, to cause

<sup>111</sup>G. Zekos, *Denying Patentability of Scientific Theories*, Vol 19, September 2014 (Journal of Intellectual Property Rights pp. 337–346)

<sup>112</sup>Two Pesos, Inc. v. Taco Cabana, Inc., 505 U.S. 763, 782 n.15, (1992) (Stevens, J., concurring) (“[W]here the owner of a trade-mark has spent energy, time, and money in presenting to the public the product, he is protected in his investment from its misappropriation by pirates and cheats.”).

<sup>113</sup>U.S. Pat. & Trademark Off. v. *Booking.com* B.V., 140 S. Ct. 2298, 2301 (2020) (allowing registration of some “generic.com” marks). U.S. PAT. & Trademark Off., *Trademark Manual Of Examining Procedure* § 1209.01(b) (2018)

confusion, or to cause mistake, or to deceive.”<sup>114</sup> Moreover, multiple factors go into an appraisal of whether an applicant’s mark is confusingly similar to someone else’s, but predominantly noteworthy one is the similarity or dissimilarity of the mark as to appearance, sound, connotation, and commercial impression.

The Lanham Act also prevents registration of marks confusingly similar to no abandoned unregistered marks.<sup>115</sup> Furthermore, trademark rights are an intangible form of property rights in intellectual property, involving the right of sale and the right of licensing. The most vital trademark right, as with other forms of property, is the right to exclude meaning that a trademark owner has the right of exclusive use of its trademark and so making trademarks valuable business assets.<sup>116</sup> Also, trademark rights extend only to the specific business in which a trademark owner uses the mark. Additionally, trademark rights are not rights in absolute perpetuity due to the fact that a trademark owner loses its right to a mark by not using the mark. Consequently, a trademark right does not confer a monopoly upon its owner to prohibit all use of a mark by others which means that the right to disregard another’s use of a trademark extends only so far as that use is triggering consumer confusion with the trademark owner’s own use.<sup>117</sup>

It has to be taken into account that trademarks accomplish “information transmission” function by assisting consumers more easily to locate the products they want diminishing search costs in economic parlance. Moreover, the link between trademarks and reputation is embedded in the common assertion that trademarks symbolize a product’s “goodwill.”<sup>118</sup> Trademarks offer a condensed form of the information that consumers relate with the mark and so revealing that the quality of products is directly derived from the origin function of trademarks, as consumers must be able to identify products as coming from one firm “which is accountable for their quality” knowing as the quality function of trademarks.<sup>119</sup> It is characteristic that the origin and quality utility ascertain transparency on the market, enabling consumers to make valuable procuring decisions and so both roles serve the rationale of accomplishing undistorted competition in the internal market.

It has to be taken into consideration that trademarks protect consumers from marketplace confusion and deception by letting consumers individualize between the makers of similar products.<sup>120</sup> To that extent, the Lanham Act’s Sections

<sup>114</sup> 15 U.S.C. § 1052(d).

<sup>115</sup> In re E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 476 F.2d 1357, 1361 (C.C.P.A. 1973).

<sup>116</sup> Hanover Star Milling Co. v. Metcalf, 240 U.S. 403, 413 (1916) (“[T]rademarks and the right to their exclusive use are of course to be classed among property rights . . .”).

<sup>117</sup> United Drug Co. v. Theodore Rectanus Co., 248 U.S. 90, 97 (1918) (rejecting a comparison of trademark rights to patents and copyrights).

<sup>118</sup> Uptown Grill, L.L.C. v. Camellia Grill Holdings, Inc., 920 F.3d 243, 248 (fifth Cir. 2019 Gvantsa Gugeshashvili, Is Goodwill Synonymous with Reputation?, 16 JURIDICA INT'L 126, 127–28 (2009) (noting that “goodwill and reputation are very often considered to be synonyms,” but that goodwill is the broader concept in common law countries);

<sup>119</sup> Case C-10/89 SA CNL-SUCAL NV v HAG GF AG [1990] ECR I-3711, para 13

<sup>120</sup> Top Tobacco, L.P. v. N. Atl. Operating Co., 509 F.3d 380, 381 (seventh Cir. 2007)

32(1) and 43(a) stipulate remedies for infringement of registered and unregistered marks, respectively. In other words, without a way to know who makes what, reputations cannot be generated and assessed which means that the process of competition will be less operative. The expanding capacity of businesses to make their commodities more extensively available, along with consumers' growing capability to access those commodities, has blurred conventional, territorially restricted market boundaries and so diminishing the doctrine's inherent assumption that geographic distance decreases the likelihood of confusion between two similar marks. To that extent, cyberspace has augmented this effect by adding new subjects to the question of trademark territoriality. Thus, consumers in geographically distant markets are more likely to be confused by two similar marks than when the doctrine was born which means that companies have a greater need to protect their interests in territorial expansion.<sup>121</sup> On the other hand, cyberspace offers the tools to check about the utility of any mark.

As a result of their character, trademarks usually do not enable their holder to obstruct the making of a new product, or of a new market for the reason that, contrasting copyright and patent rights, trademarks do not offer the input for a new product or process which means that they usually do not block the formation of an innovative product or of an improved process. Nevertheless, they generate barriers to entry. A trademark interconnects basic information about the product to consumers, without competitors interfering with that communication and so trademark protection is defensive in nature by protecting trademark holders against confusing use of the trademark.<sup>122</sup>

In HAG II,<sup>123</sup> the CJEU explained that trademark rights are “an essential element in the system of undistorted competition which the Treaty seeks to establish and maintain.” Furthermore, in L'Oréal, the CJEU identified that the purposes of trademarks are multiple and that, beside the indication of the origin of the products, they seek at protecting the quality of products, communication, investment, and advertising and so adding at competition implementation.<sup>124</sup> It is characteristic that in EMI,<sup>125</sup> the CJEU ascertained that cross-licensing of trademark is forbidden between competitors, for the reason that it leads to market sharing, captured by Article 101. Hence, the exercise of a trademark right may, under particular conditions, create an anticompetitive infringement in those cases in which it “manifests itself as the subject, the means, or the consequence of a restrictive practice.”

<sup>121</sup> Anonymous, Shrink World Theory and Blockchain, MEDIUM (Jan. 29, 2018), <https://medium.com/@icography.team/shrinking-world-theory-andblockchainbea65e0cad48>

<sup>122</sup> Directive 2008/95/EC approximates the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks [2008] OJ L 299. Directive (EU) 2015/2436 approximate the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks [2015] OJ L 336 refers to augmenting the competitiveness of European businesses <sup>123</sup> Case 192/73, Van Zuylen frères v. Hag AG., 1974 E.C.R. 744. Case C-10/89, SA CNL-SUCAL NV v. HAG GF AG, 1990 E.C.R. I-3758.

<sup>124</sup> Case C-487/07, L'Oréal SA, Lancôme parfums et beauté & Cie SNC and Laboratoire Garnier & Cie v Bellure NV, Malaika Invs., Ltd., and Starion Int'l Ltd., 2009 E.C.R. ¶ 58.

<sup>125</sup> Case 51/75, EMI Records Ltd. v. CBS United Kingdom Ltd., 1976 E.C.R. 848

According to the CJEU, free movement of goods and competition law do not avert owners of trademarks in all the EU member states from exercising their rights with the aim of preventing the sale or manufacture by a third party in the EU of products bearing the same trademark that is owned by a third party in a third country. Besides, this conduct could be forbidden if it was applied through an agreement or a concerted practice with the object or outcome of isolating or splitting the internal market. Additionally, the use of a trademark to artificially generate barriers to entry in a market that is already controlled by an undertaking seems to have been less frequent in reality.

Can territoriality apply to cyberspace transactions and AI ones? The answer is no and there is a need for global application of e-trademarks. Different jurisdictions acknowledge the critical function of trademarks to indicate the origin of a product and so making trademark holders accountable for the product's quality. The general common law rule of territoriality considers that trademark rights are limited to the geographic territory in which a mark is utilized and the Lanham Act embraces territorial provisions. The courts in the United States have confirmed the extraterritorial reach of the Lanham Act, as the Supreme Court has done so in Bulova.<sup>126</sup>

Courts conferred the infringer's own profits only in cases of intentional or willful infringement and the Supreme Court held that the Lanham Act does not necessitate proof of willfulness as a criterion to an award of profits.<sup>127</sup> and so willfulness is a vital consideration in awarding profits under § 1117(a), but not an absolute precondition. Moreover, courts defined 'willfulness' to embrace a series of culpable mental states and so courts commonly award economic damages in the form of lost profits or reasonable royalties.

Which are the effects of AI technology on trademark law? Will trademarks still fulfill their role in a world in which consumers are assisted by AI technology when procuring in the online marketplace? It is worth mentioning here that electronic marketplaces are assisted by AI technologies, such as search engines, customer service bots, or AI assistants. Undoubtedly the most vital characteristic of AI technologies in online shopping is that they forecast what consumers require or like before consumers know it themselves. In other words, AI's prediction in online shopping is a central advancement in online shopping in many ways. To that extent, the capability for AI technology to reach that high level of sophistication based on the evolution of the technology and the data that it utilizes. AI can make decisions in an objective way as long as the used data are unbiased, not mentioning the capabilities that AAI technology will bring forward. Concerning current AI, a certain bias can trigger their mechanism because of human input at the stage of training the algorithm, setting the hyperparameters and selecting training data.

<sup>126</sup> Trader Joe's Co. v. Hallatt, 835 F. 3d 960 (ninth Cir. 2016). Bulova Watch Co. 344 U.S. 280, 73 S. Ct. 252 (1952).

<sup>127</sup> Romag Fasteners, Inc. v. Fossil, Inc., 140 S. Ct. 1492, 1494, 1497 (2020) (while "a trademark defendant's mental state is a highly important consideration in determining whether an award of profits is appropriate," there is no "categorical rule" that the plaintiff must prove willful infringement).

A very common form of AI in online shopping is product recommendations and so AI technology collects data about the consumer's previous views or purchases which means that AI can make a list of items encompassing similar features that the customer seems to have a preference for.

It is worth noting that AI technology with unlimited time and augmented capacity clearly reduces the requirement for simplified information on the market and via AI technology, consumers count on assistance in collecting and processing far more distinguishing context than humans which means that consumers will be able to find optimal products without the help of trademarks serving their needs, presuming that this is the standard for the AI technology.<sup>128</sup> While trademarks may not anymore perform the purpose of simplifying information and so making the buying process more effective, they still convey significant information to the consumer when he/she consumes the product. Moreover, trademarks by guaranteeing the origin and quality function will still be useful in AI-assisted online shopping.

It could be said that trademarks continued to be useful in assuring undistorted competition on the market. In other words, while AI technology is able to classify fully counterfeit products, competition would nevertheless be harmed where the communication between producers and consumers is obstructed by confusing information from competitors. Also, both justification of plummeting consumers' search costs along with assuring fair competition on the market continue to be relevant functions for trademarks in online marketplaces.

Trademarks are highly unique and have acquired certain recognition by communicating information beyond origin and quality. Moreover, the capacity to communicate values and images has been accepted as accessory functions of trademarks. Also, in line with the advertising function, trademark holders can use the mark successfully to inform and win over consumers. In other words, the CJEU recognizes that trademarks are valuable in informing and convincing consumers and trademark owners should be able to successfully advertise their mark.<sup>129</sup> The communication function has also been recognized by the court.<sup>130</sup>

AI technology is much better in searching context by presenting optimal options for consumers and so advanced AI can predict consumers' preferences in relation to certain trademarks. The functions of trademarks are expected to continue playing a role for purchases done in the online marketplace with the backing of AI tools. It could be said that AAI technology is also able to influence behavior of consumers on an emotional level.

<sup>128</sup> Michael Grynberg, 'AI and the Death of Trademark Law' [2019–2020] 108(2) Kentucky Law Journal 198

<sup>129</sup> Case C-236/08 Google France SARL and Google Inc. v Louis Vuitton Malletier SA [2010] ECR I-02417, para 59.

<sup>130</sup> Case C-487/07 L'Oréal SA v Bellure [2009] ECR I-05185, paras 58 and 63 Case C-129/17 Mitsubishi Shoji Kaisha Ltd. and Mitsubishi Caterpillar Forklift Europe BV v. Duma Forklifts NV and G.S. International BVBA [2018] ECLI:EU:C:2018:594.

It is argued that extraterritoriality and international trademark norms leading to global trademark reflect globalization, not mentioning the demand for rules governing the forthcoming AAI trademarks.<sup>131</sup>

## 12.8 Methodology and Data

Successful protection of intellectual property rights depends on both the existence of intellectual property protection laws and the enforcement of the laws. The changeability of legal theory and the new laws coming into force all the time along influence the outcome and consequently our index.

Moreover, all the national laws in force by the end of 2012 of the 79 investigated jurisdictions have been examined and used in the raking of the various factors taken into account in constructing ZEKIPR6 index. Therefore, all future changes in intellectual property laws and their enforcement environment will continue to cause an alteration upon our indices which means a need for a nonstop updating of IPRs<sup>1</sup> index:

$$\begin{aligned}\text{ZEKIPR6} &= \text{membership in international treaties} + \text{index of patent rights} \\ &+ \text{index of copyright} + \text{index of trade} - \text{mark rights} \\ &+ \text{enforcement legal rating(legal tradition(rule of law))} \\ &+ \text{legal education} + \text{economic level}\end{aligned}$$

Enforcement legal rating (legal tradition (rule of law) + legal education + economic level) is made according to this author's evaluation.

$$\begin{aligned}\text{ZEKIPR1b} &= \text{membership in international treaties} + \text{index of patent rights} \\ &+ \text{index of copyright} + \text{index of trade} - \text{mark rights} \\ &+ \text{enforcement rating((legal and political environment (LP))} \\ & \quad (\text{judicial independence} + \text{rule of law} + \text{political stability}) \\ &+ \text{control of corruption}) \quad (\text{International Property Rights Index} | 2010 \text{ Report})\end{aligned}$$

A linear model is in the form

$$Y_i = \beta_0 + \sum_{j=1}^{p} \beta_j X_{ij} + \varepsilon_i$$

<sup>131</sup> James Darnton, 'The Coming of Age of the Global Trademark: The Effect of TRIPS on the Well-Know Marks Exception to the Principle of Territoriality' (2011) 20 Michigan State International Law Review 11.

where for the  $i$ th case,  $Y_i$  is the response variable,  $X_{i,1}, \dots, X_{i,p}$  are  $p$  regressors, and  $\varepsilon_i$  is a mean zero error term. The quantities  $\beta_0, \dots, \beta_p$  are unknown coefficients, whose values are determined by least squares.

A linear model is in the form where for the  $i$ th case,  $Y_i$  is the response variable, are  $p$  regressors, and is a mean zero error term. The quantities are unknown coefficients, whose values are determined by least squares.

GCI (the Global Competitiveness Index 2010–2011) and Global Competitiveness Index 2011–2012 (GCI) are variables.

In detail, the following are the econometric models used in our investigation in order to find the impact of IPRs, GDP, and GCI on FDI inflows/outflows, and GDP growth:

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{GCI}_{it} + b_2 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_3 \text{Inflation}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.1)$$

$$\begin{aligned}\text{GDP}_{it}/(\text{GDP}_{ci}) &= b_0 + b_1 \text{GCI}_{it} + b_2 \text{FDI}_{it} + b_3 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_4 \text{Inflation}_{it} \\ &+ u_{it} \quad (12.1a)\end{aligned}$$

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{zekipr1b}_{it} + b_2 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_3 \text{Inflation}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.2)$$

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{GCI}_{it} + b_2 \text{GDPGR}_{it} + b_3 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_4 \text{Inflation}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.3)$$

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{Zekipr6}_{it} + b_2 \text{GDP}_{it} + b_3 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_4 \text{Inflation}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.4)$$

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{GCI}_{it} + b_2 \text{GDP}_{it} + b_3 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_4 \text{Inflation}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.5)$$

$$\text{FDI}_{it} = b_0 + b_1 \text{GCI}_{it} + b_2 \text{Trade}_{it} + b_3 \text{Inflation}_{it} + b_4 \text{GDPGR}_{it} + u_{it} \quad (12.6)$$

## 12.10 Conclusions

Copyright laws grow as technology develops to accomplish an adequate balance between private rights and public interests. The existing legal environment does not offer sufficient protection in the changing technological environment but there is a need to go on with supporting technological advancement while protecting users' data and interests. Currently, technology is changing at a faster rhythm than the development of law and the rule of law which means that this failure is transplanted

into IPRs regulation. Competition is a vital factor regarding industry value and so utilizing the econometric models finds that competition is a significant factor in attracting FDI.

The brief econometric analysis further shows the significance of the competitiveness and ZEKIPR index in attracting FDI inflows.<sup>152</sup> As mentioned earlier, the analysis of the legal background of copyright and trademark law shows a continuous development of the legal regulation and enforcement of IP rights. Copyright law must advance the creation, dissemination, and preservation of works that are valuable to society, expressed not only by traditional means but also by electronic means. For instance, developing digital goods and services makes the introduction of electronic trademarks necessary. The current legal environment does not tender sufficient protection in the changing technological environment, but there is a need to support technological advancement while protecting users' data and interests.

Hence, antitrust enforcement at the EU level is driven by the European Commission, a political body, and fundamentally unreviewed and unchecked by EU courts which means that EU antitrust is less economically grounded, and certainly more politicized, than in the United States.

Formalistic per se rules that used to portray US antitrust doctrine gave way to a case-by-case assessment of the economic effects of company conduct which means that antitrust enforcement gradually began to count on economic and econometrics theories that are now all but mandatory in antitrust litigation and so the Chicago School incorporated in competition price theory and concepts such as market power, entry, and efficiency.<sup>1</sup> It seems that the US Supreme Court abandoned most per se rules, leaving only naked horizontal price fixing and market division, in addition a reformed per se rule for tie-ins, under per se treatment<sup>2</sup> and so even practices that resemble per se offenses are tested for possible efficiencies.<sup>3</sup> It is specified that that price fixing is good for consumers when it initiates ruinous competition, such as price wars that drive prices below costs.<sup>4</sup>

The Court's "rule of reason"<sup>5</sup> leads to considering pronouncements that contradict the legislative intent not mentioning that it is well recognized that the courts are ill-suited to participate in the searching economic analysis regularly necessitated by the rule of reason.<sup>6</sup> In other words, it seems that competition law has moved away from the competition ideal encompassing the diffusion of economic and political
