Taking into account that AI boosts competitiveness, the question to be answered is if the essence of competition has altered due to the use of AI technology. The answer is that current AI technology utilized by companies in a human-centered economy has not modified the context of competition but AI has made it more difficult to detect activities which are anticompetitive in comparison with the same activities contacted via conventional humans' agreements. Meanwhile, an advancing AI may bring the "end of competition as we know it" and so AI will bring competition in swiftness and speed on searching data along with dig data collections which means that anticompetitive conduct will encompass technical electronic blocking of searching or collecting data since humans' involvement will not take place in an AAI economy. Anticompetitive agreements, under current human understanding, among AAI systems functioned by AAI humanoids might take place but they will have a different impact on a fully automated system fortified with various technological devices precluding any anticompetitive activities. Cartel agreements, under current anticompetitive understanding, among AAI systems might bring only advantages for AAI society instead of generating any anticompetitive collision in a fully automated economy. Thus, in an AAI economy run by AAI humanoids, where is questionable if humans will have any impact on AAI economy, the context of competition and activities that will be considered as anticompetitive will be modified due to the fact that AAI technology will function objectively which means that the imposition of an objectively fair competition will be the target and so a self-correcting AAI system will prohibit any malfunctions not only concerning competition but also of the whole AAI in an AAI society.

G.I. Zekos<sup>26</sup> has written that "Various electronic forces are fighting every day to overtake control of the global electronic network but at least there is an intention to utilize it as democratic as it is possible and in compliance with their plans for global hegemony. The goal should be to prohibit a "crazy hegemony" to use the electronic network to bring catastrophe (καταστροφή) and chaos (χάος) over earth" and so, concerning the advancement of AAI technology, there is an urgent need of prohibiting any "crazy hegemony" to use AAI generating catastrophe (καταστροφή) and chaos (χάος) over earth by eliminating human life.

The rise of digital platforms generates concerns around their effects on markets and society leading to alterations in the regulatory landscape and so authorities should impose more stringent remedies as they increase their certainty on the

<sup>26</sup>G Zekos, Demolishing State's sole power over Sovereignty & Territory via Electronic Technology & Cyberspace, 2013 Journal of Internet Law, Volume 17 Number 5 November 2013 27-41 Aspen Publications- Wolters Kluwer p15.

negative effects of a particular conduct. E-commerce platforms have a greater advantage over individual merchants for the reason that they have access to insights spawned from information from all their merchants, which can be unfair particularly if the platform sells the same products to their merchants. Large corporations participate in anticompetitive practices by steadily applying for patents and monopolizing related IP in a particular space and so generating a barrier for small-tech businesses and start-ups. G.I. Zekos considers that the stimulation of competitive structures, specifically in digital markets, rests on setting positive standards and principles enabling market access for new technologies and business models.

Data are part of AI innovation and denoted that IP laws had been set up to support start-ups to protect their innovation from competition by protecting their data. Nonetheless, IP laws do help start-ups handle competition, competition in various industries has encouraged the adoption of AI and the software development has moderated the barriers to augmenting AI innovation further. Nevertheless, the adoption of AI diverges from one industry to another.

Legislatures and antitrust agencies must form legal requirements for data-sharing to make certain that all corporations provide needed data access to antitrust authorities. Moreover, international regulatory cooperation and even data-sharing will also be imperative.

Finally, it could be said that the purpose of antitrust laws is to offer “a free and open market economy” along with fair competition providing low prices, high-quality products and services, more choices, and illustrious innovation which means that the objective of antitrust laws is to guarantee fair competition by overturning activities like price fixing, and monopolies which is applicable to an AI environment.
